description:
I love the vibe of this place for games, particularly warriors games. I made a reservation for a table during a finals game, which worked out wonderfully since it was incredibly crowded but I was able to get a table.

Solid German beer hall with food options.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Stopped by Schroeder's to grab a quick bite.  This place needs to be featured on Gordon Ramsay's kitchen nightmares. Yikes.  Started with the soft pretzels. Specifically asked for no beer cheese. Got beer cheese.  These pretzels were microwaved from frozen. The texture and freezer burned taste were not appetizing. And as soon as they cooled down they were rock hard. Like not even edible rock hard.  

Ordered a burger which came with tots. The tots were from a school cafeteria. The burger was over cooked and came with little side dishes of mayo and ketchup.  These appeared to have been pre filled and stored in a cooler. How hard is it to fill little containers of condiments to order.  These condiments tasted off. The only highlight was that the pretzel bun was not bad. 

I get that this is not a culinary destination, but this food bordered on inedible. I wouldn't even go there to drink the beer on tap because there's nothing edible to snack on. Come on Schroeders. A soft pretzel is not rocket science. And they are inexpensive to make. Charging $15 for two rock hard pretzels and a little side a mystery cheese is highway robbery. Even for SF standards. 

I'd stay away from this place.
author: Paul W.

description:
I like Schroeder's - it's an honest-to-god beer hall in the Financial District.

It's got a laid back atmosphere, with lots of long tables, the game on the tube, and beer on tap. Burgers are fairly priced too (they've got the Impossible Burger too), and they've got some good German fare too.

I'm just questioning the avocado toast on the menu. I guess it wouldn't be San Francisco without it.
author: Casey S.

description:
Came here for a friends surprise 23rd birthday and it was a huge success. We could be as loud as wanted, order as much beer as wanted, and generally have a relaxed casual time. 

They do not have very many options for vegetarians unless you want to stick to a pretzel or avocado toast. So I ended up getting a Bratwurst which was delicious. It came with mashed potatoes, sauerkraut, braised cabbage, and pickles. 

Fun for work events, birthdays, or a night out with friends.
author: Sydney G.

description:
So I've been coming here since I was a kid in the 60s. I have always had found memories of this Rathskeller.

Seriously this place has not changed in 50 years...maybe 100 for that mater!!!

Great beers on tap!

Great German comfort food....wursts, burgers, Schnitzels, and the like.

Great to view sports at the bar.

Food is still good and hearty.

Service was great.

If you want to go back in time to  a classic San Fransisco restaurant have Lunch or Dinner here!
author: David G.

description:
A after work happy hour classic! German beer house meets sf cuisine. You can get a schnitzel or an avo toast....I went full Biergarten and got a chicken schnitzel. While I wish there was more currywurst sauce on my schnitzel, the huge pretzels and super spicy mustard as appetizer made up for it. 

I went here for a friends surprise birthday party and they were super friendly and accommodated our large party tu happily.

One star minus because the service (even beer service) was über slow
author: Heather W.

description:
I've walked by here so many times and always wanted to check it out. Finally came here for a work function. I was disappointed. 

It's got the feel of a beer hall. So, if you're coming here just for drink and to hang out then this spot would be great. 

If you're coming here for food then I would go elsewhere. Seriously, the food wasn't good. I wouldn't even say it was decent. And especially not for the price IMO.
author: Matt M.

description:
Went to Schroeder's for a friends going away lunch. Very hipsterish in terms of its wooden tables and walls. I do miss the older European style pre-renovation look but the new logo is pretty cute. Also, you can still get the extra large boots full of beer and well, that might be the most important aspect of this place for some people. Lots of beer in a very large boot and you can pretend you are in your own 'Beerfest'. Food-wise, I think it's pretty expensive but the portion sizes are pretty reasonable. I got the schnitzel with mushroom sauce and beets. Not enough sauce at all but I asked for more and they gave it to me. We got a side of the fried spaetzle, meh, I would pass next time. No flavor at all. 

Note, this place is located in central downtown/financial district so expensive is the norm. Also note that you will be surrounded by financial district patrons. Overall, I think there are better German places in the city, but it's not bad for lunch and/or if you are in the area and no doubt, they have an expansive beer selection and plenty of boots and steins to drink from!
author: Cicely T.

description:
Came to Schroeder's with some colleagues to enjoy some light bites and drinks. It was a time to celebrate a 2 day offsite and what better way to reward our hard work than over some German food! 

When you enter, you're greeted by a host stand to the left, a bar to the right and lots of picnic style seating throughout. I thought it was odd that although we had reservations, there was no "reserved" sign on our table when we arrived. Not a big deal at the time because no one was occupying the table but the joint filled up quickly and seating seemed to be on a first come first serve basis. Since only part of our party arrived at the same time I did, we kept having to tell people that our table is reserved while we waited for the rest of the party. The service overall was helpful and quick. There was a 'hmm' moment but overall, good service. 

For starters, I asked my server to recommend a bourbon or whiskey drink and that I usually go for Manhattans and he immediately recommended the Back in Black for $12: wild turkey bourbon, averna and chocolate bitters. GREAT CHOICE for a drink! Tasted exactly like a Manhattan, which I appreciated. Here's what our table ordered for food: 

-Kartoffel tots for $7: a bowl of tater tots with a couple of dipping sauces. Nothing out of the ordinary, loved that it was nicely salted

-Two Barvarian pretzels for $12: served with a Bourbon mustard and bier cheese. Although I love pretzels, this dish was WAY TOO salty. Even after scrapping much of the salt off, still too much. 

-Fried pickles and mushrooms for $9: I mean who wouldn't love this dish?! Served with a fill ranch dipping sauce, this dish went fast!

-Kase Spatzle for $9: soft egg noodles in gruyere, goat Gouda and cream. Tasted like a boujie version of Mac and cheese. Not mad about it one bit.

-For dinner we shared the Schnitzel platter for $55. 3 kinds of schnitzels-pork, veal and chicken, served with corresponding dipping sauces and pickled veggies. I had a chance to try the veal which I though was really good and the pork which unfortunately was a little too dry. 

Overall, I'd give this place an OK in my book. Not bad but certainly not top for me. I'd be open to coming back, and enjoying a cold beer, maybe during Octoberfest.
author: Rockne H.

description:
Stopped in for a couple beers after work because we saw the "Happy Hour" sign out front. Was told by the waiter that happy hour is 2-4. :(
That's the last time we fall for that!
I can't fault the place for me not reading the sign completely. 
Anyway the beer and pretzels were wonderful. There was German writing on the walls so I could practice my reading skills.
By 5:30, on a weekday night, the place was getting packed. Good crowd. Good service. Alles gut. :)
author: Marvin M.

description:
On 6/17/2018 when I was arrived in San Francisco, CA, I was heading to this local German Pub located within the Financial District neighborhood that has been served for many customers for the past generations. It's called, "Schroeder's." Schroeder's brings the vibes of visiting actual German Pub by serving their traditional and modern German cuisines and endless of German style beers every year! The atmosphere is very active and ongoing as I welcomed there. The concept is much old fashioned, yet it does have a good, modern flare for this generation filled with classic designs and illuminating dimmed lights across the whole room. Much traditional for the wooden furnitures and interior walls especially the bar side too.

The employees here from servers, hosts, bartenders and cookers are doing a great job for making the customers like me an incredible service despite the busiest environment. No cons.

Now onto the food and drinks! During the World Cup 2018 match for Germany vs Mexico on Father's Day morning, I ordered one of their World Cup food menu specials called, "German Breakfast." It contains a Bavarian style Pretzel with two dippings: strawberry jam and bourbon mustard along with a side of baked potato. As a result, that German breakfast was pretty good cause the pretzel baked perfectly and warm. Perfectly seasoned thanks to the beagles style seasonings. Both strawberry jam and bourbon mustard also tasted amazing compared to Knobs & Knockers sauces in Sacramento. Homemade and crafted for perfection! For the drinks, I simply ordered a glass of Mimosa and that cocktail was quite refreshing! Not too strong and wonderfully elegant. I haven't tried their German beers so far after my first visit, so I'll be back in the near future for my next visit. I do know that some customers liked the "Weihenstephaner Hef" cause that beer tasted completely refreshing and amazingly bold. Interesting imported beer!

Speaking of the World Cup, their watch party coverage of the World Cup was simply energetic and magnificent! I really loved the visitor's reactions about the game between two competing countries of the world cause it makes more lively and entertaining! Of course, they also have good yearly holiday themes from St. Patrick's Day to Oktoberfest too!

Parking at Schroeder's can be challenging to park. You can park at nearby surface metered street nor the parking garage if it's available. Alternatively, you can also ride a bike, walk, carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Schroeder's is an unbelievable and striking local German Pub that I've discovered and visited right here in San Francisco's Financial District. Perfect for friends, family and co-workers gathering. A well received! My rating: 4 solid stars.
author: William L.

description:
A rare FiDi spot that's actually open on weekends, Schroeder's fulfills a need for those of us who actually LIVE in the area rather than slog through Mon-Fri only. 

That said, there's not a whole lot of standout elements here. Granted, there aren't that many German-fare pubs around, so if that's what you're seeking out, then this place technically ticks that box. Arguably, the food is "fine," but given the city we live in, you can do a lot better than just fine.

the real rub here is the service we received. on a VERY slow Saturday, multiple elements of our orders were messed up (requested a salad with dressing on the side, got a salad drenched in dressing, had to send back, got served an incorrect beer, got served an incorrect entree ... sigh) in addition to the food getting messed up a bunch of times, the service was a bit salty-to-rude as the evening progressed. i understand that servers can be bored on a slow night, but that doesn't really excuse eyerolls, sarcastic retorts, and suggestions to "just try it" when asking to get an order that was incorrectly made fixed.

when my friend's dish came with the 5$ upcharge of egg and sardines (he hates sardines), he mentioned this error and the waitress grabbed a side plate and asked him to just "slide the egg and fish off the top" rather than offering to re-fire a new plate for him. i mean really? even if that's all you're gonna do when you take the plate back to the kitchen, you could at LEAST fake it / pretend to remake it. 

overall, i wouldn't return, and I hate leaving a bad review for a place that's generally fine, but the crappy service really set it off. if the staff wasn't so icy and indifferent, it would've been a much different experience.
author: Vicki L.

description:
We had a big group and so most restaurants weren't able to house us but Schroeder's has big tables in the back so they're great for large parties!

We tried a bit of everything, from the tator tots (decent), to the pretzels (amazing and nice and soft), to a schnitzel platter with a bunch of different types of schnitzels (some were a bit dry but overall was acceptable), and a selection of all the sausages (the platter).

The sausages were excellent, and they were all a little different which was quite nice, and you got a good assortment of mustard to try everything with. Food tasted great, and everything was quite enjoyable.

The cocktails were a bit strong, and some of the "sweet" ones didn't end up being all that sweet, so make sure you have a good understanding of what you're ordering, or else it might come out quite unexpected.
author: Tyler T.

description:
This is cool place to visit if you're ever in the Embarcadero area. The interior is something to marvel at, it looks like it hasn't
 changed since the 1920s. The staff is informative and patient, especially if you're not familiar with German food. Of course you have to try a German beer, but if you're going to do a boot, be aware of how much liquid you are pouring down your throat. Whatever you order there, make sure you get a side order of pretzels.
author: Joel G.

description:
This was a really nice pub. Some of their beer prices were a little bit wild, but they do have some unique beers to try. Their happy hour prices were rather reasonable. If you're really into beer, I think you'll be incredibly happy with their selection. 

The staff was great, and they were able to create some rather nice mixed cocktails. (Especially for a pub) 

Thanks for the great experience!
author: Jonathan H.

description:
The food is superb (particularly the chicken sliders), the service fast and friendly, and the atmosphere lively.

Our server (Mike) and even one of the managers (Aran, Aram?) came over to check on us often, were very friendly, and explained all the beers and food dishes to us.

They do a great job of making you feel welcome and important here, and the food and beer is amazing. 

We will certainly be back.
author: John B.

description:
After the renovation and change of ownership, this place lost its vibe and it's character. To start with: I received a beer without head. Yes, you read it right. German beer restaurant. Lager. No foam, almost completely de-gassed. And it happened to me twice.

Im not sure what else to add. The food has always been just ok, and it stayed that way. Beer selection lost some European items and added some local ipas.
author: Alex S.

description: I am just visiting here and stop by at this place their food is incredibly yummy. And they have daily specials for all day. If you are around here, definitely it should be the place which you should stop by.
author: Alp O.

description:
We come here pretty often for work happy hours as it's in a very convenient location. 

Interior and service is excellent. It's all newly remodeled, and there is plenty of space and the airflow is also quite good, even when it gets crowded. Service is generally pretty good, most of their servers and experienced and courteous, we've always really enjoyed them. 

The beer selection is great, but the food is not good. A lot of it is over processed and doesn't taste like they were made fresh. 

Overall, come here for the drinks, but don't expect the bar food to be anything but decent.
author: Sophie W.

description:
Nice German bar with great, welcoming atmosphere. 

Good hospitality, however open Saturday till 9:30 PM only. 

Will be back for more.
author: Slava C.

description:
A few things that I wasn't impressed with:
1. Although we were seated quickly, we felt totally ignored for 15 minutes, possibly because we were the only women in a roomful of men?
2. We tried several times to make eye contact with a couple of waiters- they wouldn't meet our eyes.
3. Beets were served with the meal although not mentioned in description.  They totally ruined my meal.  I would have specified "no beets" if I had known.
4. Sneaky fee.  There is a note at the bottom of the menu that 4.5% will be added to the bill because it is San Francisco!!! WHAT?? Be honest with the menu prices.  There is only the one location, just list the actual price.
author: Andrea P.

description:
Plus:

Its bit quieter then a typical san francisco bar, beer was good and staff was friendly

Con: 
Their food needs improvement.  Not sure how you burn tator tots.  Also, could you more of a beer selection, its a bit limited, especially when it comes to german brand
author: John K.

description:
Prior to coming here, my friend and I were watching this movie with these German guys getting drunk and drinking "the boot". I forgot what the movie called. Whatever, but he was hyping it up and telling me this place in San Francisco has "the boot". I thought it was pretty dope that there was beer inside this glass boot. 

I thought this place was OK. The music was super loud and it was a little hard to hear my friends across from me. We tried their supersized pretzel. It was salty. My friends ordered their sliders and they didn't mention anything bad about it so might have been good? Lol I solely came here because he told me about their "boot". 


We both finished the boot, it's possible between two people within 15 minutes. You might just have to pee every 5 minutes though....lol.
author: Priscilla L.

description: What a load of fun here during Mid October. Had a full Octoberfest band, Octoberfest games, very personable and cool host who was the manager named Aram. They have there cool steins all over the place, lots of folks wearing lederhosen and dancing traditionally.
author: Allen Y.

description:
If you love sausages and can't stop dreaming about going to Germany for their juicy bratwurst one day, I'd recommended stopping by Schroeder's instead! Their sausages are juicy and thick and perfectly spiced, pair that with their supersized pretzels and great draft beer and you're almost there. 

If you're not into beer and sausages, however, I'd recommend their "Elderflower Fizz" and their chicken schnitzel sliders! 

-1 star because the music is too loud and doesn't go with the already loud ambience of the restaurant :/
author: Seerat J.

description:
Surprisingly great food for such a centrally located restaurant. It's a MASSIVE beer hall with big screens all over, but the food was exceptional. Perhaps needless to say, but anything potato-product this German place has nailed... tater tots, mashed potatoes, etc. all delicious.

Service was a tad bit on the slow side, but frankly I didn't expect anything else during happy hour during a (Warriors) game day. I'd definitely head back again.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
Talk about a face lift!  I remember when this place had a sticky floor, perpetually smelled of stale beer and let portion-size be the only defining attribute of their food.  Now the interior looks extremely posh and the dishes are somewhere between gastropub and haute cuisine.  And thankfully they still have a very extension beer menu!

Bavarian Pretzel w/ Warm Bier Cheese: Completely destroys the overly salted movie theater pretzels served with cheese product.  These taste freshly made with a super soft and yeasty center surrounded by a crunchy malty exterior.  The warm bier sauce is totally worth the upgrade; it's like having your own little crock of cheddar fondue.  I could seriously make a meal out of just these pretzels.

Wiener Schnitzel: The texture seemed a bit off.  The fried coating around the veal wasn't very crunchy at all.  And the veal seemed a tad too firm.  The taste was awesome though.  And paired nicely with the mashed potatoes, red cabbage and pickles so I was able to overlook the shortcomings.  A very hearty meal filled with Germanic goodness.  However, next time I might opt for one of the sausages.
author: Adam B.

description:
I work in Soma, and I come here with a friend not too infrequently after work. It's usually pretty loud, and the crowd on weekdays is the typical Fidi crowd, with most people in button downs and slacks.

Schroeder's has a decently large German beer selection. I rarely know what any of the beers are, so I usually just pick one somewhat randomly, but I've been pretty happy with my selections so far.

Smothered tots - This is probably my favorite thing here. It's a huge plate of tater tots, covered with mushroom gravy, sausage slices, and jalapenos. It's more than enough for a group to share, but I usually just order it as my main.
Jager schnitzel - Can't complain, comes with mashed potatoes and cabbage on the side. 

Not the best German food in San Francisco, but I'll probably still come after work every so often for beer and some tots.
author: Tiffany P.

description:
Not sure why Schroeder's doesn't get more love here on Yelp because it rises above being just a mere beer hall by having strong beer, drink, and food offerings.

As for the beer, there's plenty on offer, whether from Germany or the U.S. - so much so, in fact, that you can get flights of offerings from either country, It all goes down well with their food, which has plenty of German items like wursts, schnitzels, and spaetzle. Their house burger - which came with 39-day aged chuck served with lettuce, tomato, and onion on a pretzel bun, was especially delicious. 

Service from the bartenders was especially prompt and attentive. There are sports screens everywhere, and the vibe can be as boisterously social or as privately intimate as you want it to be, as you can generally spread out if it's not too busy. It looks like Schroeder's has had a bit of a reset in the last few years after some renovations, so perhaps its Yelp reputation carries a bit of baggage from older days, because otherwise I can't see why the average rating is so middling.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Stumbled in here after our offsite across the street.  It's like a German beer hall with long rows of tables; community style seating. In the back they have these huge square tables where if you're across from one another they are far away; good for private conversations.  

Beer selections are quite good.  Very good variety.  This night I had the Anderson Valley; a bourbon cask stout.  Had a sip of the sour; definitely sour and refreshing. 

We only had appetisers.  Tater tots were okay.  But the pretzels were awesome.  Come very hot, sea salt on a thin hard crust.  The inside was soft.   Comes with a ground mustard and this other dipping sauce that looks like Russian dressing but it wasn't.   

Definitely want to try their schnitzel.  

Next time
author: P.Y. H.

description:
My coworkers and I stopped by on a barhopping night. This place is always really fun because we get the beer boots from here. We usually get a couple of them to play several rounds of games. It's a great place to bond with your coworkers. Eventually you'll start telling each other secrets and all the bad things in life that you get involved in. You rack up as many HR violations as possible and go home satisfied.

The food is just alright though. But we come for more than just the appetizers
author: Michael L.

description: Best pastrami sammie in the FiDi.  I'm not a beer drinker so I can't comment on their taps, but its seems like a popular bar.  Tasty tater tots too.
author: Suzy Q.

description: Came here with my team from work. Fun and unique atmosphere with the German Oktoberfest feel the food was pretty good. Yummy pretzels, spaetzle, and Wiener schnitzel. Seemed like a fun after work place, but definitely not for intimate conversation. It was loud!
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
We came here tonight with a group of 7. My friend had made a reservation, and they had a table waiting, which was great.

The water took our drink orders but didn't come back for our food orders for awhile. There was a fairly large private party going on at the same time. 

We put our food orders in, and most of them came out quickly. I don't mind starters coming out with mains, but we had pretzels and sausages, another couple friends had entrees, and one friend didn't see her food for over 30 minutes. The restaurant must have lost her order, but they didn't say so--we asked about it after all the other plates had been out for 15-20 min.

The food was ok. Pretzels were fine but not amazing, beer cheese is an extra $3 which seems lame when you're already paying $12 for base pretzels. Hubs and I got the Knackwurst (with an extra sausage for $6), which was kind of like fat hot dogs. I didn't taste any paprika, and I wish we'd gone for a more sausage-y/less hot-doggy option.

The drinks were also on the pricier side, which I expect for for the area, but the wines were really small pours for $11-13 a glass. The cocktails are a better bang for your buck, and the beer selection isn't bad.

It's a fine place to gather friends in the FiDi but be prepared for slow service.
author: Lydia C.

description:
Tater tots are really good. I am inclined to believe that they are not from bags of frozen assembly line production --- but I could be terribly wrong on that front. They are deliciously crispy on the outside while moist and pillowy on the inside. The accompanying dip served to enhance it even more (the mayo, not the ketchup).

A buddy and I decided to order different wurst plates and split them as the sides were the same --- red cabbage, pickles, and mashed potatoes. We split the Nuneberger and the Bratwurst.

The Bratwurst might visually resemble your nathan's ballpark hotdog sausage, but it's anything but. The seasoning is subtle but pairs deliciously well with the mustard and pickled red cabbage.

The Nuneberger is shorn of any casing and strongly resembles a seekh kebab. It was lightly charred and served on a bed of German red cabbage, with a side of creamy mashed potatoes, with a few slices of gherkins. This was seasoned a little stronger and, in my opinion, much tastier than the Brat.

I thoroughly enjoyed them both, and will definitely be trying the other sausages too.

On a prior visit, I had the Kraut Burger. It was served with a generous bowl of crispy, moist, and delicious tater tots, and dips of mustard aioli and ketchup. I don't care for the ketchup but the aioli was the perfect match. The burger patty was medium done and moist, topped with a generous dollop of sauerkraut, and cheese. It too was delicious but paled against the sausage platters.

Speaking of the sausage platters, you can select more than one sausage for your main course and aren't relegated to selecting only one.

I look forward to coming back soon.
author: Umesh T.

description:
I came here for dinner and had a decent meal. Inside it looks like a fancy German beer hall.

I had the Bratwurst which came with mashed potatoes, braised cabbage, sauerkraut, pickles and mustard. I especially enjoyed the braised cabbage and sauerkraut. 

We also ordered Smothered Tots (mushroom gravy, horseradish, cheddar and pickled peppers). This was also very tasty, although the mushroom gravy made the tots soft if you didn't eat them quickly. 

I think the pricing here is on par with prices in the Financial District and service was okay.
author: Nette T.

description: If you're looking for authentic german cuisine don't go there. I am german and I was surprised when I ordered a schnitzel and they served it with curry sauce ?! And the Bratwurst with Pickels in a hotdog bun? The sauerkraut didn't taste good either. First and last time tried better german restaurants in SF.
author: Sarah L.

description: Everything is so delicious!  I find the menu interesting as it's got a California spin, including avocado toast. If I go to Schroeder's, I'm thinking German food though not California cuisine. That being said, I feel like they have something for everyone. I do wish you could just get a choice of one sausage as a side instead of an entire plate - like an appetizer with just mustard. Last night I had the knackwurst which comes with mashed potatoes which I subbed out for spaetzle, bread and butter picked, and braised red cabbage. It was a really great meal.
author: Danielle S.

description: Great place to enjoy good food, drinks and fun times. My server was awesome. He was so funny and honest about what to order and what not to order. We ended up getting a meat and cheese platter as well as a sausage assortment. I left there very full. But I really would like to go back and try the pretzel, it looked so fabulous! Oh yeah, and for dessert, we all tried the chocolate cake, it was very rich, but the best part of it was the coconut ice cream. Delightful!
author: Mercedes M.

description:
Hoo ray! My Schroeder's has re upped their game. I am thrilled to report that I had a delightful meal tonight. I ordered the Jaeger snitzel and the chatuterie plate. Followed by the Anderson Valley Boubon stout. The quality was very high and made for an excellent evening meal. I will be coming back soon!

Our server was attentive and checked in a couple time to ensure everything was fine.

Five stars to my neighbor : )
author: Steven B.

description:
I used to love this place, but it seems like it has progressively gotten worse and worse. Today was the straw that broke the camel's back. We ordered the soup of the day, Corn chowder and it tasted really doughy. Then we found we were literally spitting out chunks of flour. 
My Bratwurst was ok but not remarkable like it used to be. My guest's chicken wurst was awful, it smelled and tasted putrid. 
Sadly I have to say I will not be coming back.
author: Steven B.

description:
Despite the decent happy hour menu, beer selection, and tater tots, I was disappointed to see my tip thrown out the door 30 seconds after I put it down.  Sure, I gave them 3 rolls of pennies (pre-rolled mind you), but I'm not sure it required the waitstaff breaking the rolls in half and throwing them at me...

Next time (if there is one), I'll be sure to tip them a high five followed by a middle finger.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Dinner review. 

Pretzel knots - 5/5
Burger - 3/5
Weiner schnitzel (Ala Holstein) - 5/5
Knackwurst - 4/5
Bratwurst - 4/5

Overall, "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
Hands down the best dinner experience in a LONG time.   From welcome to bill an A+ .    Quite honestly, who are these people...friendly host, waitress and bus service?   Not joking people...and I haven't even gotten to the fabulous food.   The pretzel was kick a** (must have the cheese with it) and the "impossible burger" was a huge hit with the veggie eater in the family.   The Beerwurst was awesome, snitzel amazing and the spetzel a treat.   

Cool crowd of folks and liked the atmosphere...easy eating is a bonus.   Beer was great...didn't go to load on the buzz, but could have if i'd left the kids at home.  

Anyway...if you pass on this experience your a fool.   I will be back to eat my way to another stomach ache...so much great food to enjoy!   SHOUT OUT TO OUR SATURDAY STAFF..YOU ROCK!
author: K C.
Miko B.

description: Big juicy Impossible burger! I'm a fan. A bit pricy at $20 a pop plus more for add-ins like fried pickles and sauerkraut. I split one with my pal and it was enough to fill me up. Also love their tots and pretzel bun!
author: Tiffany C.

description:
As an aficionado of the "old Schroeder's" I've been prepared to resist change - So hubby and I have only dropped in once or twice for a beer at the bar. Last evening, however, we were trapped downtown at rush hour, and literally could not get on MUNI to go home, so we opted for an hour at Schroeder's.

It was rush hour in there, too - the place was utterly packed, and we almost opted out - but we saw a few tables at the far back of the room marked "reserved" with times on them. A very kind server told us we could sit at one up until the time of the reservation, so we plunked down and had drinks (beer for hubby, a German rose wine for me) and the slider trio: turkey pastrami, corned beef and chicken schnitzel. The food was excellent and quite innovative in flavors. Service was superb, with just the right amount of checking on us - and an offer for us to take a small table if we wanted to stay past the reservation time on the table. Truly, the service could not have been kinder.

The joint was really jumping, and it was fun to see the crowd - mostly young men - having a blast, drinking das boot, and generally having the closest experience to hofbrau possible in our city. The menu is somewhat limited (I'd love it if they brought the sauerbraten back) but solid - there are several things I'd like to try when we go back for a real dinner, and not just a snack. And the wine list is a huge improvement over old Schroeder's. So - sometimes things DO get better!
author: Amy B.

description: Two of us ordered the schnitzels for lunch. I had the chicken and my bff ordered the original veal.  We split the kale salad and apfel strudel with rum caramel and poached grapes The strudel was a bit dried. The whipped creme fraiche goes along well to offset the dried strudel.
author: R L.

description:
I'm torn between 2 and 4 stars. I guess because my experiences here have not been consistent. I love the idea, the large, shared tables make it interesting,  there is a good variety of sausages, the food is generally good and they are great with the beers, but the service varies too much. 

I've had service people who were super friendly and helpful, taking their time to explain the different wursts and beer flights and others who were just going through the motions, even a bit on the rude side

the front of the house is always friendly and nice

get the pretzel knots to share before the mains come

today, the chips that came with the Reuben were stale (completely inedible) and my Reuben sandwich was barely warm. if this weren't a serious business lunch I would have complained but because of that I didn't want to make a scene. very disappointing
author: Bob U.

description: So my friend works in the financial district and told me to check this place out. Bae and I went for a date night and had so much fun. Can you say beer boot?? Food and drinks aren't cheap, but it makes sense for the atmosphere - this isn't your local dive bar! We thoroughly enjoyed the upbeat vibe, the crowd, and all of the beer hall. Our waitress Rachel, was cracking us up the whole time. She was quick, knew her stuff and didn't try to oversell us on food. We'll be back with a bigger group next time!
author: Lola D.

description:
Great beer here and long happy hour! I enjoyed a bourbon barrel stout and a dark ale from Oakland. I also tried my boyfriend's happy hour margarita and it was well crafted, with great balance of bitter and sour (not too sweet).

Pretzels are fantastic and arrive extremely HOT. Cheese dip is reminiscent of movie theater butter. I could eat these all day. Others ordered food which looked and smelled excellent and authentic. The prices seemed a bit steep though, considering it's pub food.

Friendly service and fun games thrown in--stein drinking, stein holding (a strength competition for the ladies), and tater tot eating (no hands). There were people of all different nationalities competing. Great live music. They accomodate large groups well, but ordering food can be chaotic, especially with the loud ambient noise.

Perk: one wall is covered in coat hooks, so convenient.
author: Victoria S.

description:
Really nicely done German gastropub. Delicious beers, friendly service, great food. A little pricey, but really in a way that you should be expecting for the upscale vibe.

Definitely worth a check-out. German food often slips off of my radar, ethnically... but it was quite good, I'll be back.
author: Sean B.

description: The drinks are average but pricey, the food is mediocre, and the service is appalling.  Being nice with 1 star because they didn't spill our beers, but the waitress was incredibly rude and gave unsolicited criticism.... if you work in the service industry (as I have) and expect a big tip, please provide good service.
author: Vee S.

description:
Like I read on so many posts: 

'I really wanted to like this place'.  

Well, I really wanted to like this place.

I mean it IS a cool setting.  I mean, really...the oldest German restaurant on the west coast!  Dating back to the 1890s as a business and to the post '06 quake for this location, it has history, which to me is very important.  And the Hermann Richter murals on the walls are awesome, no doubt.  The beautiful wood throughout rings true its Bavarian heritage.  The beer selection is impressive for sure.  But the food, albeit quite good, at least this my first try, was not worth what I spent there.  

$27.00 for a .3L Hefeweissen and a Jager (sweine) Schnitzle with mash pototoes, purple kraut and Gerken...for lunch...for one person...well....I was more impressed at Stein on Clement with the food frankly.  At least for the price. Again, I wanted to really love this place.  But even as much as I loved the decor, I wish that I had seen it before it was remodeled.  It is cool, but for my taste a little too hipsterish.  But hey, SF is hipster and yuppie and techie central...they gotta cater to those types.  

However, I was hoping for more of an 'authentic' Hofbrauhaus, ya know, more heads on the wall...more, I don't know, German-ish.  And more gritty old school San Francisco.  And don't get me wrong, It's got the German thing going...but my memories of eating in Germany, especially Bavaria are working class and peasant; loud Ratskeller drinking buddies with lots of 'Prost!!"  

I'll give it another try sometime and go for the Knackwurst or something along that line.  Let me say again that it was good food, yes...but for me, not so sure about the price.
author: D.J. L.

description: Food was good (pretzels and kase spaetzle are highly recommended).  Service was good (although we were there on Saturday night so it wasn't too busy).   Also, they have happy hour specials on Saturday outside of the normal happy hour time slot.
author: Matthew J.

description:
I'm done with this place. I've come about a dozen times because coworkers keep having happy hours here. The only thing good about it is the beer selection. 

Everything else (food, atmosphere, music, seating) is pretty weak. On top of it all, the staff is rude and condescending, like our existence is somehow an inconvenience to them. 

There are so many other restaurants and bars in the fidi. Go to one of them instead. If you want good German food, yelp will show you several others that are much better.
author: Dave R.

description:
First time coming here and definitely won't be my last. Great space to accommodate a large group of co workers and friends. They have TVs and large tables and bar tables. You can also sit at the bar or stand, whatever you feel like doing that day. This place is in the middle of FiDi so expect to see a lot of people in suits. I'm pretty sure there's no dress code here. If you're looking for a place for good beer, come here. Hahaha

I came here today for my friend to celebrate her new job. We arrived there around 4 and there was a lot of people. Thankfully we found a spot and was able to get a table when people started leaving. They have a large menu for beer and food. Loved the tater tots and the pretzels. Will definitely be coming here again to try the rest of the menu.
author: Tina M.

description:
MY BOSS' RETIREMENT PARTY

When the new, renovated Schroeder's was opened I wasn't a fan. I felt the modern German food was too posh. Really salmon flatbread is German cuisine? Where's the pork knuckle I used to have from the old Schroeder's? Despite that I would still come here for a drink beer and watch important soccer games. There are two things I did like about the renovation. First and most important was that the old bar was still intact. Second inside the restaurant the seating feels more like a beer hall in Germany.

About a month ago my boss had a retirement party here. Our party was at the back of the restaurant. After taking a further look the inside the restaurant I like the furbishing inside Schroeder's as the décor has the classic yet modern beer hall. My boss and our clients had a great time at Schroeder's. 

When I originally wrote my review of the renovated Schroeder's my rating, which was 2-star, was based on the lack of German food. However during the retirement party there were classic German food as sausages yet modern twists such as chicken schnitzel sliders and pretzel knots. The day before the retirement party I came to Schroeder's to eat for lunch. I even noticed that the menu wasn't posh but had some German classic food. (I know tater tots isn't German food but it's still delicious.)  Even though the menu has improved with all the different selection of beers I wish there were more items that would compliment with the beers that are served. If Schroeder's ever serve the pork knuckle again I would consider revising my rating. The old Schroder's served the pork knuckle that had soft skin. The type of pork knuckle I'm looking for has a crispy skin like the ones I had in Germany. If Schroeder's ever serves this this type of pork knuckle then I'll give this place 5 stars.
author: Gerald R.

description:
Been here a couple of times after work for coworker parties and one time because BART was shut down due to a fallen tree on the tracks.

From the food perspective, I've tried their tater tots and their cheese/charcuterie plates.  The servers were very knowledgeable on helping us decide on what cheeses to select for our tastes.  The first cheese plate was so great that we ordered the remaining selections on a second plate!  The charcuterie was a decent plate of food too although a bit priced higher than I expected.  The tater tots were a nice starchy option that can be shared among two to four people each.

I have never gotten an entree as I was drinking beer.  I usually got the Anderson Valley Barrel Aged Oatmeal Stout as I'm not partial to German beer options.  Based on the few times I've been here, I didn't see a lot of rotating beer selection.  That may be my only minor complaint based on my times I've been here.

Otherwise this is a great place for small or large group meetups.  Lots of seating at the bar and at the tables.  Oh they have that boot of beer thing if you want to try it but be prepared to have your clothes soiled in beer or your memory to be severely compromised for the rest of the night.
author: Ben H L.

description:
The one star is for the horrible waitress on Tuesday, 5-22-2018. She is some disgusting piece of work! I didn't catch her name but she looked Middle Eastern or Latin wearing a red shirt. I don't know what her problem was with my friend and I but she's lucky I didn't throw my drink in her face! My fault is that I didn't complain to the manager when we left. She needs some serious training or they need to fire her!

Here's what happened: my friend and I ordered our drinks at the bar and then we walked over to the long community table they have; it's to your left when you walk in. 

SO there were 2 ladies sitting at the table facing the bar and I asked them if it was ok if we sat there and they said yes with no issues. However, one of the ladies mentioned that there was a reservation for the rest of their party at 7:15 pm and we would have to move when they started arriving. NO PROBLEM. They were extremely pleasant and we thanked them. A few mins later, this hideous waitress comes over with THE BIGGEST, UGLIEST attitude and tells us, "you guys are going to have to move because you are not part of this reservation!" my friend was about lay into her when I stepped in and calmly said, "we know that we're not part of their reservation but these ladies said it was ok for us to sit here until their party started arriving." The ladies saw everything and told the waitress it wasn't a problem. She stomps off. We're all looking at each other confused and horrified of how this girl treated us. So the party started to arrive, my friend and I moved over - no biggie. I saw the same waitress and asked her for a glass of water and that's when she really pissed me off: she slams the glass down as she stomped away spilling some of the water on the table. She didn't even bother to stop and that's when my friend had to tell me to calm down because I was ready to throw that glass of water in her face! There was NO reason for her behavior. We were polite, watching the game and everyone else was pleasant. We left soon after because it was going to get ugly.
author: This Is M E.

description:
I went here to try the Impossible Burger and grab a German beer. It was an awesome spot to hang out, with swift service and tasty food. 

I also got the pretzel appetizer, and while it was good, I later realized the Impossible Burger is also served on a pretzel bun. So if you get that, I suggest avoiding the appetizer and pretzel overload!

The Impossible Burger here is quite thick and hefty; probably double the size that they serve it at other restaurants I've been to (The Counter, Bareburger, Crossroads, Beelman's -- all in LA). So while it's a little pricy, you get more Impossible bang for your buck at Schroeder's. 

For my vegans out there, this is a great place to come with coworkers when you're in the FiDi. It's super hard to find vegan options in that area (especially in a nice setting with fab cocktails), so this will be my new go-to for business dinners if they keep the Impossible Burger around.
author: Nicole V.

description: My brother and I visited Schroeder's for lunch. Schroder's has a rather extensive array of German beers. Our bartender "DJ" was very knowledgeable of all the German beers. He is an  awesome bartender. We especially enjoyed the weihenstephaner beer. As for food we had the Schroeder's sausage plate. You get seven kinds of sausage a smoke nurnberger, knackwurst, bratwurst, frankfurter, weisswurst, kasekrainer and chicken calvados. All seven sausages were good, but the weisswurst was my favorite; it was bold and juicy with hints of cinnamon and ginger.  The manager came over and described each type of sausage along with a list. Nice touch. There really isn't anything better. It was fantastic meal. The food was good, solid German comfort food. Very hearty and well-prepared.
author: Jaime S.

description: Awesome German restaurant in downtown San Francisco financial district. This place has been around since 1893! And it looks like a cool old beer hall inside. They have all these really cool beer steins on the shelves. The food is great. I had the crispy pork knuckle and it was very good. Though, I wish they had some more choice in German hefeweizen, all they have is Weihenstephaner.
author: Peter K.

description:
I have visited Schroeder's for over ten years any time I visit the City and have time to enjoy some dinner.  It seemingly just improves every time and my most recent experience was incredible.

I spent the day on the Rock with my family and friends which worked up a great appetite for dinner.  I called ahead to insure that our party of 15 would be seated when we arrived while we waited for our boat to bring us back to Pier 33.  Schroeder's was very accommodating and worked out a nice loooong table for us to sit at upon arrival.  In fact, when we arrived 30 minutes early, the table was already set and awaiting us.  

Our waitress. Hanna, was fun, fast, friendly, and even spoke German!  She along with the rest of the staff tended to our needs the entire two hours we feasted.  The service for our parties size was top-notch.

We ordered the Vesperplatte, a combination of cheese, meats, bread, and other delicious items.  Everything on this tray was amazing!  If the platter had been made of something other than wood, I would have licked it clean.  We also ordered the Smothered Tots that are tatter tots covered in mushroom gravy, horseradish, cheddar, and pickled peppers.  Um, these were absolutely amazing!  The kids gobbled them down and had no clue they just ingested horseradish. :)  My only complaint was that we ate them too quickly.

The menu is filled with many German selections from schnitzel to wurst.  My wife selected the Jäger Schnitzel and said it was fantastic.  I was looking for something I have not yet encountered and discovered the Kasekrainer that is your standard pork sausage filled with garlic and Emmanthaler cheese, one of my favorite cheeses.  When I asked Hanna what she thought of it, she replied, "It has cheese in it, that's all you need to know." :)  She was absolutely right.  It was one of the best sausages I've ever had!  If I never find this anywhere else, it will be my staple at Schroeder's for certain.  The mashed potatoes, red cabbage, and kraut that accompanied the wurst was very good.  Oh, the mustard that topped the wurst was crazy good as well.  Everything was cleaned off this plate.

Others orders ranged from franks to burgers and everyone - and I mean everyone - was very impressed with their meal.  That's a 15 out of 15 from ages 4 to...well, matured diners. :)  My beer, the Andechser Doppelbock, was great and the flights were well enjoyed by the two ladies at our table.

Now, if there would be any complaint about Schroeder's it would be one and it really is more silly than a compliant.  I spotted German Chocolate Cake on the menu and it is a disappointing thing to find on a menu of a German establishment.  See, this dessert isn't German.  Not even close.  It was invented by an American baker whose last name was, you guessed it, German.  Generally, caramel and coconut are not ingredients you find in German desserts or sweets in general.  I just found this interesting since everything else on the menu was pretty spot on with common German food.

The atmosphere was great, the food amazing, the staff incredible, and the experience well worth your visit.  Any native from Germany will be comfortable ordering off the menu while they enjoy a little bit of home in San Francisco.  Oh, you don't have to be a native to enjoy it here, either. :)
author: Sven R.

description:
So this place rocks.  I have never been but love German food and beer and was blown away.  

The reason for no 5th star.  THE DJ IS TERRIBLE.  Like not even funny.  Super loud, no flow, crappy choices,  you name it, he cannot do it.  You know your old roommate who had horrible taste in music and thought he could DJ, well he can evidently.  Not sure why this is happening (and neither is the waitstaff who apologized and wished it would end).

Food, atmosphere, beer all 5 star but for gods sake, get rid of the DJ.  I would pay to cut his set short and go home.
author: brett b.

description:
This was my go to place for happy hour with my coworkers. Love the ambiance of the place and there are tons of long tables for seating. 

It does get hard to get the bartenders' attention during happy hour but they have a great selection of drinks. I like that they also have a place to drop your coats/bags if you don't want to carry them in the place. 

The pretzel knots here are delish! They are a bit salty but when you pair them with the dip it's a great dish for your drinks
author: Keizzel C.

description:
I agree with a prior Yelper - my opinion on Schroeder's is very torn. The drinks are very pricey, but you're in the FiDi so it's to be expected.  It's the first place I was taken to by some friends during my first week working in the neighborhood, so I figured it was just a favorite local haunt.  But once I (quickly) realized that pretty much everywhere else in a 3-block radius has cheaper drinks and better service, I was left wondering, why do my friends insist on meeting at Schroeder's after work?  I concluded it's because of the well-dressed executive men that my single girlfriends enjoyed looking at - but this married lady needs cheaper beverages and more of them, so I haven't been back to Schroeder's in a while.

I can't speak for the food because I haven't tried it.  I've rarely had good service here though.  The bartenders & servers act like you should feel privileged to be acknowledged.
author: Jessika S.

description: What a great place to grab a casual lunch in SF. Easy access and great ambiance. The sandwiches are terrific, and don't miss the tots. Check website for happy hour too!
author: Patrick L.

description: Schroeder's is a loud German beer hall that has a huge selection of beers and a select variety of small bites and dishes on the menu. The decor here is so nice--you're surrounded by beautiful murals and decorations that transport you straight to Europe! I came for a happy hour with a large group of co-workers, and though the atmosphere was loud and rowdy, it still made for a good place to sit around and chat over a pint. I ordered the Weihenstephaner beer from Germany, and we also shared the huge pretzels, which were hot and freshly-baked, covered in salt and poppy seeds. They were served with mustard and cheese on the side, and these dips both added great flavor! We also got the "Vesperplatte," which was a charcuterie-type board with bread, a few different cheeses, a few different types of preserved meat (like hams and mortadella), as well as pickles, grapes, and dried apricots. This variety platter was fantastic for sharing, and it was fun to combine different ingredients and flavors into perfect bites!
author: David K.

description:
Drink and eat like Germans do!

A friend of mine who lived in Germany for a few years suggested we meet in this place and as soon as I stepped in through the doors I knew that I'd like the place! The space is vast and laid out nicely. They have a nice bar you can sit at, but the benches are the way to go.

The beer is awesome, but you must watch for the alcohol content! Some of them are pretty high and you may be surprised if you do not pay attention to the description on the menu.

I tried two different beers both of which were above 10% in alcohol content, but not surprisingly I do not recall their names! We tried an order of Chicken Schnitzel Sliders, A+! I then tried the Jäger Schnitzel; delicious but very rich. You may consider hitting the gym the next day because you will have a few extra calories stored before the night is over! My friend ordered the Wiener Schnitzel. I did not try it, but it looked good and he was happy with it. Judging from his very clean plate at the end, I have no reason to not believe him! 

Get a group of friends together and meet there for some fun!
author: Afshin A.

description:
Food: 4.0/5.0
Service: 2.5/5.0
Value: 2.5/5.0
Decor: 3.0/5.0
Overall: 3.5/5.0 

Interesting spot.  Fun spot to down a boot in a chic faux beer hall.  The food is actually surprisingly good - never disappointed.  Sadly, while usually friendly, the substance of the service has at some been hit or miss - forgetful and/or lazy.  Prices are a tad high for FiDi but not too bad.  An aggressive spot for lunch but great for drinks/dinner.  Awesome for big groups but call ahead.
author: Damian W.

description:
The atmosphere and staff are pleasant, but both beer and food are vastly overpriced. The käsespätzle (a German dish similar to mac and cheese which is sometimes served with a light dusting of breadcrumbs) was 50 percent breadcrumbs and bereft of any taste. The staff kindly replaced it, but the second one was little better. We were then not charged for the dish, but ultimately would have far preferred just to have been served something palatable.

A litre of local beer served in a German-style Maas beer glass will set you back at least $18 apiece, with a German beer costing you about $24. Pretty steep by any standards.

The interior is akin to a German beer hall, but you pay an exorbitant premium for it.
author: Alex W.

description: great place for a large group. a little pricey but worth the experience and atmosphere. food was excellent
author: George R.

description:
Great experience.  I was hanging out with some family in the City and they wanted to try Das Boot beer, which probably has about 33oz of beer in there.  To order the beer boot, you would have to put down a $50 deposit in case the glass breaks -- which totally makes sense.  

We ordered a few plates to share.  The chicken wings weren't that great because it tasted like it was boiled before being thrown on the grill and covered in the sauce.  I personally wouldn't order them again.  

The bratswurst sampler was pretty neat.  They had 6 different types of brats, which all had unqiue flavors. If you want to try the different brats, this is a good platter to try.  However, I wasn't thoroughly impressed with them.  I would probably prefer them charbroiled for a better flavor.  

Overall, good vibe and hangout place if you need a few beers after a long day of work.
author: Mee M.

description:
REUBEN REUBEN REUBEN! 

Came here with my boss for lunch since he always craves German food. I really like the vibe here, it has a bunch of long tables and seats, very casual and comfortable. Recommend this place for hang outs and team outings!

I tried their Rebuen sandwich, it was hot and juicy, it also came along some sea salted chips. Portion size was reasonable, this place is more towards the pricey side, but then again you are in Fidi, so what isn't over priced?

I would definitely come back here for happy hour, I am intrigued by all the appetizer pictures I see here :)
author: Natalie L.

description: So have not been here in years. Food was good. Service was good. Guess live music is done. Kind of sad. Don't get me wrong, brew house. Still great. Was a lot of fun before. Hope it all works out.
author: Michael O.

description:
Cool place to go after work! I went for a company happy hour and we got to order drinks and tried a bunch of appetizers!

- Pretzels
- Spatzle
- Sliders (beef w sauerkraut and pork)
- Tater tots 
- Charcuterie plate
- Sausage plate

Everything was good but my favorites were the tater tots, breaded pork sliders, and the spatzle!! Service was really friendly and there are a lot of tables for people to sit. It's definitely a legit beer hall, just a little fancier haha!
author: Tara A.

description: This review is specifically for Leona--we worked with her to plan a company happy hour and she was SO fantastic to work with. Super quick response times, helped us pick the perfect amount of food to order, and got us a cost effective menu.
author: Madeline K.

description:
Decent little German place in FIDI. Will say, the food and drink get a 4 star, service wasn't great though.

Came here during a Cubs/Giants NLCS game. Was working out of our sf office and its right around the corner. Was a bank holiday so it was quite dead in FIDI. Easy to get a table.

We ordered some apps and drinks. I got the braised steak with potatoes (forgot what it was called). It was delicious! Overall a decent experience.
author: Erin J.

description:
I came here with some friends after a late night event. There's plenty of seating at the bar, at open tables, or in private booths. I'm not sure what time their kitchen closes, but I was apparently too late to try any of their food. Oh well. We just a few beers (it was IPA Monday!) and enjoyed great conversation.

The staff members provide excellent customer service from giving recommendations for beers to cleaning up after drunk sailors puke all over the floor. My experience here for the first time was not extraordinary, but I would be down to come back again when it's a little more alive to try items off their food menu and more selections of beverages.
author: Stefanie C.

description: A good bar, no doubt, decent staff and vibe... BUT... as always in this town, a rip off! $34 for 3 whiskey sodas?! It's just robbery, again. Totally bemused how they can get away with it. Can't go back.
author: Simon P.

description:
Wunderbares Essen und ein amaziang Atmosphäre.

It's like a dining hall straight of out of Beowulf. It's very long with the bar in front and the most of the tables in the back. It has a modern ancient feeling, but does that even make any sense? 

I came here with a large group and I think we ate everything on menu including sharing a beer filled Das Boot. Basically a giant glass boot filled with German beer. Definitely try this when you're here, even if your Nana is joining you for dinner. 

When at Schroeder's you must try the Smothered Tots made with beef jus, horseradish, melted cheddar, and pickled peppers. This is like mutant cousin of carne asada fries, the good mutant cousin, not the one that gets locked in the basement and shunned from society. Drunk, high or sober these will taste amazing. 

Pork Cracklins - House made Pork Rinds with pickles, and spicy mustard. Yes, these are addicting and you will order a second round. The Sauerbraten is ridiculous; braised beef, red cabbage, bacon, grapes and potato dumplings. Just think German styled Short Ribs. Insanely tender and the potato dumplings are amazing!

BOARDS: Pretzel. I know this sounds ridiculous, but the pretzels here are like knotted balls of salty, spicy awesomeness and they come with a smoked butter and mustard. So good! The Sausage board was also very good, it's comes with four different types of sausage that you get to choose. Everything is made in-house and is delicious.  

I ate and drank plenty more while I was here, but honestly it's just making me hungry for some Schoeder's and I can't tame that craving while Vegas. 

Essen alle Lebensmittel!
author: Nate M.

description: I'm eating my words from the previous review as quickly as I ate the food (and drank the beer) at Schroeder's last night. This place has changed so much in a couple of years, it's just so much better now. The food is absolutely amazing, super flavorful and authentic, and a great price. Beer is delicious as well. The new owners really turned this place around and it's once again among one of my favorite places downtown. I hope it stays that way!
author: Anca R.

description:
Remodeled German communal restaurant.  Not only the decor and ambiance is more modern, but their food is presented with a contemporary touch and look!

It's a beer hall and I like the good vibes here!

Das Boot, the bratwurst and whatever entree, you name it, they have!  Their hearty meals compliments well with the beer.  

It's filled with laughs and the rowdiness that comes along with the crowds gathered here.  

It can be a celebratory and festive place!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Bare bones unadorned establishment serving an excellent selection of sausages and in depth selection of very good draft beers. We had the 7 sausage assortment and the tator tots (tator tots were greasy and served only warm, not hot). The 7 different sausages, however, were all excellent but again served only warm, not sizzling hot.

I'll be back for the sausage but a couple times a year are probably often enough for me. 

Snappy service, although at 9PM on Saturday night there we were very customers other than us.
author: Michael M.

description:
Beer: 5/5
Brat: 3/5
Fried pickles and mushrooms: 1/5
Music: 5/5
Crowd: 5/5

Fantastic after-work scene, but would recommend avoiding the food.
author: Alice M.

description:
My last review was a 2 star, granted it was from 3 years ago.  I checked out the lunch menu online and joined my two German pals for lunch there today.  I was happy to see in the passing of 3 years the luncheon menu had changed and expanded.  My tummy was very pleased with the Schnitzel that came with mash and red cabbage.  The charred lemon was the best touch, juicy tartness on the crisp (but not at all greasy) schnitzel.  The little pot of condiment was a weird touch to me, the wait said it was made with raisins, it had a hint of sweetness but I did not use it as it seemed not to compliment the dish.  ymmv.  One companion had the same dish and declared it yummy, she did ask for salt, and I confess, it added a boost of flavor.  Our third member had the frankfurter (being from Frankfurt herself) and she gave me a taste.  Yum, nice snap to the casing and the sausage was *very* tasty! Will have to come back and have a plate of my own.  So, from a 2 star review back up to a 4, a decided improvement.  

Service was prompt and pleasant.  We were also not rushed out as we lingered chatting.  They gave us the bum's rush by diming the dining room lights.  Which was totally fine.  Subtle way to telling us lunch was over and they wanted to clear the place.  If that was not the message, it's okay, we had a long lunch anyway!  

I was pleased and will be back for more as I want to try the Jager schnitzel!
author: Donna H.

description:
This place is not so bad after all. I love the decor of this place. I like the beer garden area with the picnic tables. It gets really busy here during happy hour after work. I like how people squeeze in and share their personal space with strangers. The seating area right by the door is a great place to hang too. 

I stopped coming here for awhile because they discontinued a beer my co-workers and I really liked. But now we found one that taste almost the same. It is the Paulaner Salvator. So now we'll be back when we're in the mood for German beer.
author: Edie G.

description: Schroeder's, you're no Reichenbach Hall, but then again, SF is not NY. Portions are a little on the smaller side, but man, they're tasty. Sausage platter with sauerkraut, mustard, and pickled veggies for $40? Yes, I'll be having those 6 sausages in my mouth. Smothered tots were a bit meh, as they had canned jalapenos and some packaged, shredded cheese on top, but beers were fantastic, as you can already guess. Ambiance and service are as good as they've always been. Expedient catering to you, and great German hall feel with benches and tables, along with bar area. On Saturday nights, they've got live music as well, so watch your games, down your liters of German beer, and have a couple of bratwursts.
author: Danny C.

description:
Remodel was done well, but some thought could have been put into the acoustics and dampening sound. It can get really noisy in the dining room with sound bouncing around on all the hard surfaces.

Food is ok. I preferred the old menu which had a more authentic flavor profile.

Why 2 stars? All you need to do is look at the path of leaking trash cans from the side door to the curb. It's a virtual cesspool of bacteria, grease and god knows what. I work nearby and have to walk past one of the filthiest sidewalks in the city. Even fast food across the street scrubs their walkways daily. Maybe Schroeder's can be just as good as the super-sized folks and clean up their mess. It's called be a responsible business that cares about the neighboring businesses and the tourists who bolster our economy.
author: Steve S.

description: Authentic German beer hall in the financial district with of course outstanding German beer selection including Pilsners, hefeweissbier (my favorite), dopplebock and even a German IPA.  Nice selection of German cuisine as well ranging from small bite bar fare like pretzel knots and smothered tots.  If an entree is in the picture, try the traditional Jäger Schnitzel veal cutlet with spätzle.  Food service a bit slow; even for a simple Schroeder's popcorn order, but who's here for the food? Love the ambience with long community tables and Munchen paraphernalia as one might expect to see in Bavaria.  Fun atmosphere and friendly bar tenders.
author: Roy A.

description:
Headed to Schroeder's upon rumor of currywurst being on the menu - and sadly the seasonal menu's days were numbered, so had to try some other things instead.

The flavors are quite good here. My favorite dish was the grilled pole beans with radish, sunflower seeds, preserved lemon & crispy pig ears! The smoked chicken wurst came with tasty sides of mashed potatoes, sauerkraut & mustard.

Favorite drink so far: grüne tal (laphroaig scotch single malt 10 yr, black bottle blended scotch, escorial liquor, lime & bittercube bolivian bitters).
author: Angie C.

description: We had a blast. The staff is very friendly, the beer delicious, the food nice, and the overall atmosphere very upbeat. Perfect for large groups.
author: Loic C.

description: My husband and I came here for some drinks. We didn't have any of the food so this review is only based on the drinks. I love a good Moscow mule and they were definitely made right! My husband has been in search of a citrus flavored beer. He found the perfect one at this place. He went with the T.W. Pitcher's Radler. It's a lager Shandy with grapefruit and a hint of blood orange. We were both happy with the drinks and the service! Excellent experience!
author: Valerie R.

description:
I've never loved the food at Schroeder's, but I've always thought it was pretty tasty.   Up until my lunch today, I'd have given them 4 stars but I really was not very impressed with my bratwurst and Spatzle.   Both left plenty to be desired. 
The bratwurst was not particularly well cooked and seriously under-seasoned, so much so that I found it hard to swallow.   Spatzle, as far as I'm aware, shouldn't be dried out nuggets of carbs.I'm sorry, Shroeder's, but I can only give you 3 stars.
author: David O.

description: Great place to catch a game on TV and to nozzle on a Sausage Board!  There's a variety of German sausages to feast upon with the sausage board so you won't be disappointed.   The Smothered Tots is also a must order. Absolutely tasty. Wash it all down with a couple glasses of the NV Riesling (Germany Sparkling) and you are done for the night!  Will be back for the friendly services and amazing sausages! =)
author: Melanie N.

description: Went for happy hour, can't beat their Tuesday deal of $2 tots at the bar! Got the jaeger schnitzel and spatzel for dinner, overall was pretty good not as good as the sausage platter if your sharing with a friend.
author: Mandy B.

description:
Tried this place last night as a birthday dinner outing for my mother (she lived in Germany for many years and has a real soft spot for German food still). I really want to give this place 4-stars, but I just can't bring myself to do it...

First let me say that the atmosphere/ambiance of this place was fantastic--easily my favorite thing about it. It has that Bavarian feel with the bench style tables, without being cramped or overpacked. The various beer steins all about were a nice touch. Our sever was very pleasant, well organized, and attentive (she had the German accent thing going on--I'm not sure if it was legit or a gimmick, but I didn't ask and it doesn't really matter). 

Here's why it's a "3" though... it's pricey, and the food just didn't thrill me. It was ok, but not fantastic. I ordered a Hefeweissbier and the bratwurst which came with mashed potatoes, sauerkraut, apple cabbage and a brown mustard. The kraut and cabbage were spot on (and I can say that with certainty since I was in Germany only two days earlier). Sadly the mustard and the brat were bland/weak by comparison. 

To be completely honest, I'll probably go again (I'm a sucker for mood and ambiance), but it's not even close to my favorite German restaurant in SF.
author: Jarrod B.

description:
I can't afford whisky every time I go out, even though it's on the expense account.  When I want to give the man pictured on my green credit card a break and change up my drink, no better place to go than an old fashioned beer hall.

And yes it's old.  Or it's portrayed to be old, crusty, and full of that old world charm.  You know what...it works on me.  It's the type of place where big groups from the office come and down liters of very very good beer, to the point where they forget who they are with and start cursing at the boss.

Yes, it's that type of fun, but order more than you need - service can be a bit slow due to the popularity.
author: Ron L.

description:
Reasonably priced, wonderful German Food. I love the decor. I have taken many photos in this restaurant with many people throughout the years. I first ate here with my father in the late 1960's. I have always loved their selection of schnitzel, wines, and cocktails. It is a fabulous place to dine at with friends, colleagues, and family. 


Wunderbar!!!
author: Bella W.

description: Amazing happy hour menu. Draft beers and appetizer are affordable and properly portioned for price. Great entrees and good service. Highly recommend pretzels with beer cheese, brat in bun, and Pilsner or Hefeweizen drafts.
author: Andrew R.

description: Really great atmosphere. Food was really good. A little under seasoned (even by german standards). I'm giving it a 4 star because the food is overpriced.
author: Mathias A.

description:
OUr waiter, Carlos, was very friendly and knowledgeable. He gave a taste of beer to help my husband decide. He helped us decide which cheeses to order on the cheese plate, and his suggestions were right on. We ordered the "traditional" brat, and it was a little bland,and the tiniest bit underdone in the center, but the  Kasekrainer was very flavorful. The potatoes and red cabbage were tasty. The kraut was ok, just not like what we're used to in the states. It is probably authentic German style.  Unfortunately,the entire entree was lukewarm. I know they would have been happy to re-do it, but we were to hungry and tired to wait, so we ate it.
Overall the quality of the food was good, just needed to be warmer.
author: K L.

description:
Cool German themed bar in the heart of FiDi.
Huge beers!
This check-in was for the advance Oktoberfest bloc party - $10 cups of beers and $5 bratwurst.   
Fine. I'll just have to nurse my drink.  Haha.
author: Drew B.

description: Decent German food...The Hoff sandwich was good but pricey.  Will come back if the menu has lunch specials at the right price.
author: Chet M.

description:
Saver yourself the trip.... To Germany, come here instead!  Since the remodel, it is much more Bistro than Bizmark, and thats a good thing.  The old atmosphere would likely make you imagine rodents in the kitchen & somone out back scraping the mould of a huge block of bland germanic cheese (but you wouldnt leave because it was an 'experience')!  Besides the food was likely the same in the real Germany, and you only came for beer anyway.

Now the atmosphere is more Mercedes Headquarters, Deutche Bank managemnet dining room... Well maybe a lot warmer than those.  Point is its been remodled beautifully.  The huge internal space now feels roomy - as opposed to barn-like.  The vibe is modern, and welcoming - as opposed to fascinating, like a Napoleon Dynamite set scene.  All that said, they did manage to keep, and incorporate into the new look/feel, the old wall paintings.  All in all the remodle is pretty fab for this space.

The menu has undergone a similarly satisfactory renovation.  The mixed pretzels starter may be heavy on starches (and likely more gluten passing into your system than german troops went back into the Saarland) but this is essentially a comfort food menu- so get over it.  The tastes of the breads and the mustard & butter condiments was heavenly.  (For a moment I even stopped hating Angela Merkel!) 

The tone of hearty & comforting was set and continued throughout a substantial lunch.  Service was great at the door and ok at the table.  All in all a very enjoyable place for lunch, especially if you can sleep under your desk in Embarcadero IV afterwards.  (I want to see how the Oompha bands & busty maiden dancing works in this new refashioned setting.  The guy on the door assured me it was still fun - and I believe him.).  I look forward to being back sometime soon: - but not on St Patricks day, when I think Germany gets invaded by Ireland and no one is sober enough to sign any peace treaty shit for days! 

Go, eat drink & be Gerry!  Its worth the 7 minute flight!
author: Stephen M.

description:
Great place to hang out after work with a group of peeps. Clean, spacious, lots of standing area as well as large wooden communal tables.. just like Germany!!?? (jk I haven't been)

Unfortunately they don't have happy hour pricing - it's $12 for cocktails and starts at $5 for beer, fair for SF and prime FIDI area pricing.

Their smothered tots ($12) is quite the deal as it's a heaping PLATE, good to share for 3 or 4 and probably has crack in it because that shit was DELICIOUS and the only factor that makes this place above average to me. I seriously don't know how they elevated the tots to be so good. Typically with tater tots, that usually means dry and tasteless, but these do, in fact, have potato flavor, are perfectly crisp on the outside, and somehow soaks in all the delicious umami flavor of the mushroom gravy without getting soggy, and the jalapenos are just the perfect kick. UGHHHHH. Good thing we were sharing cause I coulda demolished that shit.

OK I'm sorry I called this place average. I just remembered this place also has DAS BOOT (not many places in the city do!) and their pretzel knots look bomb AF even though I didn't have any..
I did sample some of their dinner offerings for a Yelp event when they reopened and their food is pretty solid, though, yes, a bit pricey, but it's on par with the area.
author: Emily C.

description: I wanted authentic german Kaese Spaetzel but instead got a TINY portion with a THICK layer or pretzel crumbs on top. I could go for a San Francisco style but the pretzel crumbs on top were too think and made the whole dish dry. The beer was good, but not too many choices of good Bavarian beer which is - let's be honest - the only beer that matters. For being in the big city, I was expecting a few good German lagers that you can't find in small towns. The atmosphere was awesome though, and my waiter was nice and prompt.
author: Nicci M.

description:
Came here for team happy hour on a Monday at around 3PM. There was lots of seating but was filling up once it was around 5PM. 

Ordered the Moscow mule which was alright. It didn't come in the copper mug though. 

Order both tots. The regular tots was way too salty for me. The other one with cheese and jalapeño was a lot better imo.
author: Sherry Y.

description: This used to be a stereotypical sticky floor German bier hall.  The new owners have done a decent job of updating the place without making it unrecognizable from what I remember. They serve both domestic and German beers in 1/2 and full liters.  And boots, in 1.25, 2.5, and 3 liter versions (which are huge and unwieldy enough that they charge a deposit against breakage.) I was a little disappointed that they didn't have my favorite, Weihenstephan Vitus (if they ever do serve it, don't get a 3l boot of Vitus unless you want to get closely aquatinted with the floor...) tho they did have Weihenstephan's Hefeweissbier which is also good. The food deviates a little from strictly traditional fare (German style banh mi?!) but it is mostly within reasonable expectations for German food.
author: Herb L.

description:
So now what am I supposed to do with my Bavarian lederhosen outfit? After all, there are only so many "Sing-Along Sound of Music" showings at the Castro, and Oktoberfest seems so far away.
