Now that Schroeder's has shaken off a lot of its old-school beer hall vibe for a sleek urban look, I feel like I now have to sit up when I down a boot. No more upchucking on the linoleum, I guess. Jamie W. and I decided to check out the renovated digs at my behest after a recent fundraising party he had nearby. We had some bar bites already, so we weren't terribly peckish. At the same time, we could have a nibble of something, and the back dining room was not all that busy on a late weeknight.

Gee, it's really nice in here now. The polished light wood tabletops and flooring. The subtly lit Herman Richter murals. The huge circular chandeliers. The floor-to-ceiling black mesh curtains. The vintage beer steins all neatly lined on brightly lit glass shelves (photo: http://bit.ly/1GwcggV). The new owners are Andy Chun and Jan Wiginton who unsurprisingly own the Press Club on Yerba Buena Lane because there are definite similarities in ambiance. The bar menu is still quite German but most certainly upgraded (photo: http://bit.ly/11124wJ). Since I failed to bring my Berlitz translator, we mostly guessed what the items were though we were aided by a very helpful waitress...or should I say waitperson now? Anyway, I knew Jamie would go for the $10 Pretzel Knot with Apple Cheddar Sauce (photo: http://bit.ly/13Q0TBt).

He's a pretzel nut, and it came out all nice, warm and chewy just like me. The sauce was almost unnecessary since I was already downing a thirst-quenching half-liter Crispin Apple Cider (photo: http://bit.ly/1u5vbtO). Yes, I did not give myself das boot this time. I got a little daring and ordered the $14 plate of Beef Tongue very thinly sliced with capers, radish and crème fraîche (photo: http://bit.ly/10wl8li). It was good stuff but rather premium priced for the paltry portion. It was just tongue after all. Everybody has one. But the find of the evening turned out to be a retro throwback, the $6 bowl of Kartoffel Tots which must be German for "Tater Tots" (photo: http://bit.ly/1ycmHjA). It came with two ramekins of dipping sauces, ketchup and an aioli. The perfect bites - piping hot, crispy on the outside and surprisingly light.

But wait, our late night snacking is not over. We were tempted by the dessert menu our waitperson (...there, I got it) casually left on our table. We immediately went for the $7 Pfannkuchen, which were shards of crepes dusted with powdered sugar, decoratively layered on a plate with a line of bushberries and covered with a dollop of white chocolate cream (photo: http://bit.ly/1Gwc3KJ). It was quite a pretty little plate of sweetness, very Bavarian in style and gobbled up in seconds. So this is the new Schroeder's, eh? We likee, we likee. We'll need to come back and try the Wiener Schnitzel, the Kraut Burger and...oh my God, they have Currywurst? I had that four times in Berlin. I love currywurst. Before the drunken patrons start singing songs of the Fatherland, we may have to come back very soon.

FOOD - 4 stars...bar bites with a nice German twist though the biggest hit was the most familiar, tater tots
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...sleek, chic...like an Elizabeth Arden makeover of an old hausfrau with a wart
SERVICE - 4 stars...quite friendly waitress...I mean waitperson
TOTAL - 4 stars...the Schroeder's facelift is much better than Renee Zellweger's
author: Ed U.

description:
Yay! I'm so glad that I finally got to eat here. I am a huge fan of German food and I wasn't disappointed.

I came here with 3 girl friends and we ordered a smorgasbord of apps and split the sausage platter. We had the loaded tots, the crab, the beets, spatzel, and pretzel knots. The crab was great, but a small portion. The beets I would skip -- pretty pointless to order roasted beets for $10+. The loaded tots are wonderful and so satisfying. The pretzel knots are also a skip -- they should have offered it with some sort of cheese sauce instead of just butter and mustard. The standout was the spatzel, it had bacon bits and cauliflower. 

The sausage platter had 4 different types of sausages. I don't remember which was which, but we enjoyed it. Wish they gave us more sourkrout, though. The pickled veggies that came with the plate was also awesome.

I hope to come back and try more of their entrees.
author: Alice W.

description:
3.5 stars

I can't compare apples to apples since I've never seen to Schroeder's before the remodel, but I like the modern beer hall look. With its spacious communal seating arrangements encouraging you to get to know thy neighbnor.

On the other hand, the openess this type of seating ensures that you hear their conversation. No biggie, we keep our convo to PG-13 but I went to the restroom (super clean!) and came back, only to find out that my neighbor took my napkin. Good ice breaker huh? ;-)

You'll pay a little bit more for your food since it's in the Fidi, but the "california" style German food was a bit of a stretch for me. Their version of currywurst has red cabbage, sprouted lentils and chutney. Um, delicious but too busy for me. The bratwurst is good and cooked through this time, which was an improvement from when we came here for breakfast during the World Cup. Lunch items come with tater tots. YES. 

Wonderful service. Def 3.5 stars.
author: Janice C.

description: This is our go to spot. Great staff and manager. Always feel @ home. Great beer selection and pub grub.
author: Steve G.

description: What can one say about Schroeder's? It's been there forever and it's consistently good. At a recent lunch I had bratwurst with all the trimmings and it was as good as I've had in Germany. Beer selection is huge, and I could sit at the end of a table (tables are family or bierstube style) and do work undisturbed.
author: Ed G.

description:
This is one of the few German restaurants in San Francisco and it's located in the Financial District. You would probably think a dining setting like Schroeder's would be overpriced -- given its beautiful art-lined walls and atmospheric lighting--but the price was, overall, very reasonable.

Let's start off with the restaurant's atmosphere and decor. The place is modern and cozy, in that the beautiful wood tables and top-notch mise-en-scene is paired with the familiar appeal of a stereotypical European restaurant, with its huge murals, heraldic shields and stuffed deer heads. Case in point, my favorite part of the interior: the big circular light fixtures with warm toned light-bulbs that emulate medieval chandeliers. I also love the long dining tables--another updated European concept--that provide a good hangout spot for a big group or party. 

 If you want to reserve a table for a big party, you can call in ahead of time, and they will send you a form to fill out details. Your credit card is needed to hold the reservation in case you don't show up. They have private party option available as well, but there is food and beverages minimum. P.S. They are fast with emails for any inquiries. 

Drink! I got Pur Coincidence Cocktail $12 (Pur pear liqueur, pur elderflower liqueur, scrappy's habanero bitters, and lime). Not bad, though I really need to mention that the bitters in this drink burned their way down my throat with every sip. Not that that's a bad thing. 

Food! Smothered Tots (5/5) $14, definitely recommend! I get amazed when chefs can make something common like potatoes into a great dish. It was crispy, flavorful and colorful! 

Roasted Bone Marrow (5/5) $15. This was my first time trying bone marrow, and I was not disappointed! Rich fat and juicy jelly-like marrow paste; pairing with the warm toast, great! 

Smoked Chicken Wurst (4/5). Delicious! Meaty with just the right amount of fat, not too oily. If you do want to try the wursts, you should get two instead of one. 1 for $18, 2 for $23. Might as well.

Kraut Burger (4/5) $15. The only thing I have to complain about the burger would probably be the house made buns. The bun was a little too dry and hard, but the meat, however, was very juicy and cooked to perfection. The sauces that came with the burger were also great! 

Schweinshaxe (Ham hocks) (1/5) $22. I was actually really excited to try this because I've had German ham hocks a while ago in Europe, but it turned out to be nothing I expected. The ham hock tasted just like the leftover lean pork in a broth stock. It had little to no flavor. The lentils might have made it worse. The combination is essentially baby food. Mushy.

Overall service was good. I think the waitress can do a little better with the ordering. Bottom line is Schroeder's worth visiting again.
author: Tammy C.

description: Perfect for big groups. The beer collection is awesome too. Food is regular bar food.
author: Ash M.

description:
Two months ago I came here for a private event.  I like German food just as much as the next person, and I knew a good time would be had.  What I didn't think about was the after-effect: waking up nightly in a cold sweat, thinking about spaetzle.  Damn you, Chef Manfred Wramble!

Oh this is a very real problem for me, friends.  The spaetzle haunts my dreams!  Sure, I tried everything they offered: pretzels, pork rinds, sausages, cheeses, German potato salad, delicious schnitzel, the list of delicacies goes on and on.  And everything was great.  I mean GREAT!  The drinks were strong and had great flavor, the music was festive and added to the rustic German beerhall atmosphere.  The entire night was fun and crazy like we were really in Germany.

But the spaetzle...  You German bastards.  Curse you for exposing me to this culinary delight when I live 100 miles away!  For those thinking I'm making this up, let me tell you about it and maybe you can understand.  Tiny dumplings, lightly dressed and tossed with corn, tomatoes, ricotta, and bits of heaven.  All just slightly warmed.  Are you salivating yet?  Because I am!  I'm pretty sure I ate my body weight in the stuff and it's all I've thought about since.  In fact, I have to cut this review short- I'm heading to SF now.

Spaetzle, here I come!!
author: Felicia W.

description:
When you think of the city on the bay, you don't tend to think about boisterous German bierhalls... but you should. 

Schroeder's takes the traditional Bavarian "gemutlichkeit" up a notch. The traditional plank benches and hanging chandeliers are upgraded to modern luxury. And the food follows suit -- traditional sausages, spaetzle and schnitzels that get a foodie upgrade.

But of course, then there's the bier. With nearly two dozen local, German and European brews (skip the 0.3L and go for the 'Halbe' (0.5L) or Mass (1L) steins) you can't get much closer to the Bavarian capital without being on the other side of the globe.

Best of all, this local treat is conveniently located right smack in the heart of the financial district, making it as easy to get to as drowning out a second liter of Hofbrau. Ein Prosit!
author: Evan Thoreau H.

description: I came here 3 years ago and loved it it was for my wife's birthday. Tonight was for the same reason . The service was over the top great. There was great music.  We were seated by a nice young lady from the front.  We were greeted by a awesome waitress she is blond. I didn't catch her name.  We started with appetizers the fried pickles and mushrooms. Omg they were so good.  Not soggy very crispy tasty. The dipping sauce was so good I could drink it. My wife had the Jagger snitzel it was uber delicious. It came with a gorgeously fried crispy cutlet with mashed potatoes and this salad of arugula and crazy good mushrooms.  Their sauerkraut is so good it is sweet unlike the jar stuff.  Their mustard is tasty on everything. I had the bratwurst with the mashed potatoes slaw sauerkraut mustard and pickles.  So I tasted the pickles first and they are sweet not too sweet very crunchy awesome texture and flavor.  I tried the bratwurst it was so good it had great flavor it was juicy and had that snap.  The mashed potatoes are creamy and the slaw was so good. The mustard with every thing was heaven on my fork.  We had a couple beers they were malty and Carmely so good great amber color.  My wife is happy she loves this place and so do I.  Thank you for making my wife's birthday a birthday to remember.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Came here to celebrate mine and a friend's birthday. I highly recommend reserving a table if you're looking to eat/sit together with more than two people. I always recommend the tots, the pretzels (with the beer cheese), a bratwurst plate and lastly, if you're game, a boot of beer!
author: Lucy C.

description:
I had never heard of not been to Schroeder's until coming here for a Yelp event about two weeks ago.

The building is beautiful with huge glass doors and windows in the front and plenty of long wooden picnic branch like tables to sit at throughout the restaurant.

The bar is beautiful as well with carved wood everywhere and the alcohol is displayed ornately. There are also a ton of cool paintings on the walls around the ceilings that I never got tired looking at either. Another plus? The bathrooms were clean. Hooray!

My favorite item on the menu that I tried was their Pretzel Balls that came with a cheddar beer dip which was good. Did I mention I'm a vegetarian? Yeah not much here for us on the menu. The only other things I was able to try was the Spatzle which was pretty good (though the whole corn kind of threw me off) and the Pickled Vegetables which were ok. It's nice that they have a few non-meat options so that we may dine with our meat eating friends.

I would definitely come back to Schroeder's again when in the area to try more of the menu and drinks. It's a unique concept that you don't see too many places in Northern CA. Going to Schroeder's made me feel like I was at Oktoberfest again down on the Embarcadero. And those were good times!
author: Jenni T.

description: Last time I was here was maybe a year ago. They changed and not for the good.  We wanted a nice German dinner and entered a beer garden atmosphere. What German restaurant serves burgers and sliders and no sauerbraten or German potato salad or red cabbage. It took 10 minutes to get a menu and when the loud music stared our radar was screaming at us to leave. We did and won't be back. Say goodbye to one of the favorite SF authentic German restaurants.
author: Tom B.

description: This is a long time SF establishment that has moved from their original location and reopened in the financial district. It has a limited menu, but is still excellent!  The Kase Spatzel was wonderful, and we also had Jagerschnitzel and Weinerschnitzel.  Excellently prepared and tasted perfect.  They have a wonderful beer hall atmosphere at the front end and single table dining area in the back end.  Fun place, and a must to visit when in San Francisco!
author: Claudette K.

description: Nice beer but bad schnitzel and spaetzdl. The pretzels were ok as well as the tots but how could that be bad
author: Natalia G.

description:
Schroeder's got recently remodeled, so the legend goes (legend aka Yelper Peter L). I came here for the World Cup viewing of Germany vs Portugal and found a fairly large place - first part is a beer hall with the typical long, wooden tables and benches. The back holds the restaurant with an open kitchen. 

While the interior is impressive and gives the restaurant a very modern look I'd call it German-style restaurant rather than a traditional German. It's definitely a nice pick on German-inspired dining (and drinking). Since the game started at 9am I didn't try the beer selection (and you call yourself German, Sebastian) but instead had the breakfast. Sadly, that was a bit disappointing - for $20 I got a rather small portion of scrambled egg with a Bratwurst. Both the egg and the Bratwurst looked a bit lost on the large plate. My friend's Bratwurst was even undercooked. $20 for that? C'mon.

I'll be back to check out the dinner but so far only 3 stars. Great interior and appearance, but the food didn't live up to the standards. But maybe twice's the charm.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Been here a handful of times and still havent had the food! 

Anyways...Das Boot of Crispin Cider = One hell of an amazing time! Be warned, the cost of beer is definitely more expensive then other places but for the novelty of the space and a chance to drink from a das boot sort of makes up for that! 

Gorgeous space, plenty of communal bar seating 

Overall Thoughts

Das Boot = Bottoms Up!
author: Eddie W.

description:
Wunderbar!

Schroeder's offers some of the best authentic German food I've had since meine Grossmutti's kochen.  Highlights include:

Vesperplatte:  a delightful mix of cheese, pate, und house-made pickles

Sigi's Market Salad:  rather straight-forward salad

Bratwurst:  accompanied by kraut, don't be afraid to slather on some horseradish and/or house brown mustard

Wiener Schnitzel: out-of-this world excellent (and this is coming from someone that doesn't like veal)

Spätzle:  small, tender dumplings from Heaven.  Corn, tomato, ricotta, poppy seeds top the tiny dumplings for extra flavors.  The veggie at our table ate this as a main dish

Black Forest torte:  very rich chocolatey, somewhat flat and fudgey.  (I expected a fluffy cake-- this still got the job done though!)  The cherry reduction topping was a perfect tart accent to the rich and gooey chocolate

Of course these dishes NEED to be washed down with a boot or stein of draught bier!  

Prost!
author: Andrea H.

description:
Looking for a place to watch the Warriors-Spurs game, not expecting to find such a convenient location! When you walk in, it has a nice, cool, rustic feel to the place. We just plopped ourselves down at one of the long tables in front of the projector screen.

Food was awesome, drinks were awesome-er. My friend was excited that they had the Paulaner, and I was excited to try The Financial. Man, that drink was strong. That little drink packed quite the punch!

Our table got the pretzel knots, tater tots, and wings to share. I didn't try the tater tots, but my guess is that they were pretty good, considered my two friends finished the whole thing. Pretzel knots were hot and delicious, just the way I like them. Wings had a nice, sort-of-sweet/sort-of-tangy flavor, along with a little spice. I think I could've finished that entire plate by myself.

Service was awesome. Our waitress was very attentive throughout the evening. Although Warriors ultimately lost, we still had a wonderful evening with our drinks and bar bites.
author: Eryn H.

description:
Love it! Great food and Great service. 
I will definitely go back many times. I highly recommend making reservations before going there. They are normally very busy.
author: Ednah C.

description: As a German that just moved to the Bay Area, I'm eating my way through different German restaurants to figure out which will be the one I'll get my beloved Schnitzel, German beer and other German soul food from. It was the first restaurant on my list and the search was basically over. I only gave 4 stars because I think they're a bit pricey on some foods but that's just me. It's a very spacious and clean place with big tv screens which showed soccer when we were there. It gave me the German flair right away and reminded me of the Hofbrau Haus in Munich. The staff is super friendly and attentive. We got there when it was quite busy but we were served surprisingly fast. The food was delicious and the desert, the "Apfelstrudel" was to die for. The food is mostly authentic to Germany and tasted almost like home. The variety of German beers was quite impressive as well. It was a really great experience and we will definitely be back. Soon.
author: Ella C.

description: Great place for after work happy hour. Huge ass beers - boot ( 2 liter ), good cocktails, good wine. Amazing fun vibe and energy around the open seating area. We went on a Friday evening, loved our drinks and the popcorn mix as well as the tots. I would go back in a heartbeat :)
author: Reema B.

description: The whole meal was wonderful. We had the prefix menu with the little gem salad, the Jaeger-schnitzel and upgraded the dessert to the apfel strudel. I had a small glass of the kolsch (German of course). Everything we had was better than average food, but the strudel was unbelievable. It was warm and crisp, served with a quenelle of lightly sweetened whipped cream and a small mound of crisp, spiced grapes. It was incredible, a perfect dish. It was worth going to this lovely restaurant just for that.
author: Chris C.

description:
Downright fun. Ever think it'd be awesome to have an endless table where you and 12 of your friends can merrily sit together and order liters or flights (either German or USA) of beer? Come here! And if you're lucky, it'll be a live music night like there was at their Octoberfest! I danced as much as I drank, and mingled with other jolly tables.

The food (smothered tots!) and drinks are definitely worth coming for at this German pub. And, if it's football season, you can watch the latest game on their TVs. Pro- Bro! I mean, Prost!
author: Regina D.

description: Bartender was rude, grinding on her friend, on her phone, complained about drinks I ordered. Would not go back. If you hate your job change careers
author: Jonathon G.

description:
It's a really nice place and very conveniently located in SF downtown. It's pretty busy in evening and weekends but you can get a seat after looking here and there.
The ambience is very chic and I loved the rustic furnitures. According to the menu the place got established in 1838 which is pretty old.
Coming to the booze and food, they do have variety of beers (can't comment not a beer person) but by the looks of people around it seems they were liking it a lot. I loved their appetizers though you won't find a very large variety but what is there is sufficient to satiate you. We ordered pretzel and kartoffel tots both were amazing. Just loved it.
It's a nice place to hangout after work.
author: Mimansha B.

description:
I came here one weekday afternoon/evening with the intensions of drinking a boot of Racer 5. I did so. I was drunk, they didn't care. We ate food, they were jolly, I was jolly. It was a fun time. Sadly I don't recall a whole lot, then again, I did drink a ton of beer.

I'll return.
author: Justin C.

description:
I've been here many times. I recently went to Germany for Oktoberfest. I asked the Bartender (Caucasian dude with glasses) to make me a traditional radler. He offered some canned ish. I gave him the recipe, to which he said "Well you can't call everything you had German. I was in vegas and not every cocktail is called Vegas". It was something to that effect. 

All my other friends said he was a douche when they ordered their drinks. 

Overall, drinks and food is good.  Bartender needs an attitude adjustment.
author: Nichole P.

description: Ridiculous pricing and everything else is average. $10.20 for a pint before tip?
author: Easwud C.

description: I went here for a beer after work and sat at the bar. Super friendly service and a lot of different choices. Also many sizes of glasses -- so if you drink a lot or are just looking for a fair sized glass, you can find that here. Staff is very knowledgeable about what they have to offer. This is a great casual place to head to after work.
author: Lori M.

description: The response was quick to my website reservation which was handled through Yelp. We arrived after a show at the Orpheum and the place had just opened. Each gentleman who served us, from the water to beverages to entrée to bussing was friendly and really aimed to please. You could just tell that they wanted us to have a good experience. We started with the divine pretzel knots that were explosively fresh and made heavenly with the company mind grainy mustard and spoke butter. I like the middle of the road suggestion of frankfurter and two others liked Nurnberger. Veggie girl enjoy her spaetzle and the top off strudel was well received too.  We were glad to be seated at the rear tables as we weren't looking for a beer whole experience. Really nice ambiance and decor
author: Marie B.

description: The food here is fantastic. The atmosphere was eclectic, but new. The wait staff was on top of it and the food came out quick. Try the pretzels!
author: Chris C.

description:
Cons: Food takes time. Server was drunk. Portions are small.

Pros: Great location, ambience great, delicious food.
author: Sandeep ..

description:
Yelp had one of their 10 Year Anniversary events here and we had a really fun time! Shroeder's was completely closed to the public that night. 

We enjoyed the slightly overdone Bavarian decor (display glasses with huge, antique steins), wood communal picnic-style tables & benches, and the lively band (accordion, clarinet, tuba, and a metal washboard): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/schroeders-san-francisco-4#ccAiOkULl6GQTFPJ-Op8OA

The food was good - not the best German in the city, but definitely the vibe here was the most fun of all the German spots we've gone to! Fitting for FiDi area - a little less authentic, but a little more party-like.

Here's the food we got to try:
Pretzels - 3 stars (a little stale, not terrible)
Potato Salad - 4 stars (good, like that it's not too much mayo and has crumbly bits for texture)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/schroeders-san-francisco-4#hk65swoBSuzq6ITMXkB1aw

Corn spaetzle - 4.5 stars (my bf: "best spaetzle I've ever had!" The corn really made the difference)
Chicken schnitzel - 3.5 stars (solid)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/schroeders-san-francisco-4#m9tJdWwV6dZxgoDgqWVd2A

Cheese, bread, & meat plate - 4 stars (meats, like pate were great! bread has nuts & grains)
Liver pate was the best! 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/schroeders-san-francisco-4#X3NH7XZMyVveR8qJg1vvcA

Mustard - 4.5 stars (spicy! good kick!)
Bratwurst - 3.5 stars (good, but the mustards made it really excellent)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/schroeders-san-francisco-4#W7BgGDVpfRdqE_CrpwK7Zw

Sliders - 2.5 stars (not too impressive)
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/schroeders-san-francisco-4#pgjcnrCVJSpsuUX6hfWjYw

Oatmeal chocolate cookies - 4 stars (grainy, small but thick, soft, and very unique!)
author: Ziyan C.

description: I went there Monday night, excited about having some good German food. Got there at 8:45 PM, door was locked (even though the sign on the door stated that they were open until 10 PM. As we were walking away, a young lady opened the door and told us we could come in to the bar, but the kitchen was closed already because "things were mellow". Obviously, they didn't care about having new diners. So I think I'll stay away on my future trips to San Francisco. Besides, I learned there were many other German restaurants in The City. We ended up having an excellent meal at one of the other restaurants on California Street.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I used to haunt this place back in the day and loved the DOURNESS of it all!!  Dark paneling, ancient waiters and good heavy German food with nary a kale leaf or avocado to be found.

I had read the reviews on the remodel and wow, impressive. We walked in (we had a reservation) and it looked like a full on party going on in a Beer Hall. Millennials by the scores, all seated at long Beer Hall style tables, loud, lots of good vibes..
Luckily for us older farts, the table was in the rear behind a a transparent hanging curtain which kind of acted as a separation.
The menu is huge. The prices are quite reasonable...a nice bet for a foursome would be the sausage sampler for $40. She had the Bratwurst and I had the Weinerschnitzel, both nicely prepared and presented and quite tasty.
We will be back!
author: Mark S.

description:
Drinking a beer at Schroder's in the summer or fall is a good time, no doubt. But the food at Schroeder's shines in the wintertime. 

By chance, came here for a friends b-day right before Christmas and was blown away by the menu. Don't get me wrong, the food has always been good, but their latest menu really highlights German food at its best. 

What we ate:
Roasted Beets with mandarin, goat cheese, pumpernickel, horseradish
Käse Spätzle with bacon, cauliflower and herbed bread crumbs
Wiener Schnitzel (a la hostein) made of veal, potato salad, cucumber, dill and an egg on top. 

Not only did I pig out on the apps, but the schnitzel was so big and hearty that it went home in a doggy bag and served as breakfast the next day. With another egg, of course. 

When chef Manfred came out to greet the table, we gushed about the food. He probably thought we were pandering to his creative tendencies, but it was no joke. The food was amaze.

A good German girl likes all German food; however, I've never been a German food fan until now. The winter menu has completely changed my mind! Das es guten!
author: Abby S.

description:
What a gorgeous venue! It actually is pretty big inside -- it goes really go far back.

I came here for a happy hour, so I only got to try a drink and not the food. The Kleine Blumchen (translation: small flower) is a beautiful drink but definitely tastes very strongly of tea (and is a bit bitter). Most of their cocktails are around $14, but it's worth it because of the quality and presentation.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Come here for the beer.
Don't come here for the food or the cocktails.

I was super excited to try the Sichuan Summer - ever since I went to Chicago's Broken Shaker, I have been fiending for more drinks that involve Sichuan peppercorn. I ordered it... took three sips, and left the rest of the $12 cocktail there - albeit there wasn't much left because it's a rather small cocktail. It tastes very sweet (no spice to it) - kind of like mildly alcoholic koolaid, so if that's your thing, go forth and prosper.

But what was criminal was the jager schnitzel. It came out and was beautifully plated. I dug in. Unfortunately, it was lukewarm (not piping hot) and extremely thin (all breading, no piggie). It might have been delicious about 10 minutes ago but had been clearly sitting around for a while. Perhaps this is service's fault. I'll give it credit though; the mushrooms and kugel surrounding the meat was delicious.

Also had pickled veggies and the potato pancakes (which WERE hot and were pretty darn good).
author: Sylvia L.

description: Came by here after a night out around the Fidi for St. Patricks Day. Schroeder's was very full and had a live band going on (and they weren't half bad!). Two of my co-workers and I were super hungry so we decided to get their St. Patricks day specials. I ended up ordering the Corned Beef sandwich which was super good. It was just right and had a nice amount of cheese and egg with it. The place had a very friendly staff and I wouldn't mind coming back here again in the future.
author: James R.

description:
Great happy hour place.. Friendly people.. 
They had a drink there that was like a Hot Tottie but way better it's sad they no longer make it :-( it was my favorite drink but now that I have tried their Pür Coincidence I love it.. 
Oh and their Apple Strudel is bomb.. The pastry is so crispy and flaky.. Yummmmm gotta try it!!
author: Lor L.

description:
Has anyone else noticed that everyone in San Francisco is 28 years old? 

I don't want to say it's depressing, but there are two things that really exhaust me in public spaces and it's when I'm older and/or shorter than everyone else in the same enclosed space. 

Thank goodness for Schroeder's. This place is old as balls, but in a good way so you never feel like you're the crypt keeper of the bar scene when coming here.

It's like, you could go to a hip, hot new young people bar and it's like the Demi Lovatos and Taylor Swifts and whomever else is young and totally outside the realm of my understanding why they're popular. Or you could go to Schroeder's... which is like the Martin Sheen of bars. It's not a standout kind of place but from what you can remember it's not offensive and a part of it will remind you of a really old version of your dad, young version of your grandpa, or any of the first few seasons of The West Wing (I still miss you every day, Leo McGarry!). 

I came here on a weeknight with some ladies for some forearm sized pale German beers and some filthy girl talk and had a pretty damn good time, considering the general level of exhaust we were all feeling. 

The girl behind the bar was a fox, the beer was crisp, and the older gentleman sitting next to us was visibly uncomfortable by our conversation but still intrigued enough to continue to listen in intently and not leave when he finished his beer. It was nice because I felt like a whipper snapper in comparison to the general weeknight crowd and refreshing to see someone look at our conversation in the confused and disgusted way that I look anyone who's under 26.

Inside there's a nice big bar and classic German beer hall communal seating with kitschy paintings of busty lederhosen-clad women and the sweet smell of encased meats as far as the eyes can see and the nose can sniff. It great for groups, it's not hyper trendy, but it is a great place to grab a seat (Yay for not standing-room only!) and a beer and have a classically under-rated good time.
author: Candice G.

description: Cute beer garden in the financial district of San Francisco. Pretty crowded during the week but good beer selection. Also got some tater tots yum.
author: Jenna G.

description:
Great place for Friday lunch when you can drink heavily!
Ruben is outstanding ! The flat sausage was kind of blend but not overly greasy.
author: CAScuba Y.

description: A couple of us went here for a late dinner and beers, I gotta say it was fantastic, and the service was excellent, they gave us tastes of different beers, just in case we didn't like it. We had sauerkrauet and sausages, I think they were called bratwurst, and they also had a meatloaf kinda thing, which was breaded with mustard, and potatoes. We probably drank too much to really taste the food properly, but it was a great atmosphere and we'll definitely be back.
author: Mack L.

description: Loved it. Food was Delish. Vibe was really fun. We stayed until closing!  Pretzel knots are a must.  We will come back here for sure especially if we have a sports game we are wanting to catch in a nice setting.
author: Nicole C.

description:
Definitely the best German food in the bay area. However, even for SF, it's a bit on the pricier side. Portions are average. 

I don't drink, so I can't comment on the alcohol selection, but my friends certainly seemed more than satisfied with it.
author: Mickael P.

description:
This is a great place to grab a drink after work. The beer is excellent here! They serve pretty good German food but it's exclusively German food so if you're looking for a happy hour spot with appetizers that include fries, jalapeno poppers, and wings, then you're probably in the wrong place. 

The wait staff was fast and attentive. This bar is lively and noisy during happy hour and dinner! The decor is pretty nice and the atmosphere is nicer than your average bar or pub but not too fancy. I will definitely go back again!
author: Tasha T.

description: It's been years since I've been back to Schroeders and I shouldn't have waited so long. Love the remodel! The food also seems to have improved with presentation too.
author: Jacquee P.

description:
Came here for a company party. 
It's a cute German bar.
Very open venue with a lot of beer and liquor to choose from.
Good service bartender was courteous and fun. Other waiting staff were polite and happy to help. 
Overall had a good impression and will be returning.
author: Nicky V.

description:
*********This place SUCKS**********

 - but not just the prices and b.s. - now's it with the guys that work here in black suits. - Remember the Fear the Beard - well this one is not funny. The Bus Girl, E something with the beard is a jerk. 

I was having a drink at the bar with some friends and the busboy with the black suit and beard is all pissed off pushing through people to get to the front podium. He pushes this girl in the back holding a full beer and it goes everywhere (I was lucky to have avoided it). 

She turns and looks at him and he just acts like a bigger A-HOLE and offers no apology. Then some guy is parked out front and he goes and yells at him because he's a sad sack. - then this goof ball yells at the guy trying to start a fight. Better yet - this guy keeps flagging this review saying it's personal. I cannot imagine this review being any other way. The girl with the blue hair wasn't a jerk. the bartender wasn't a jerk. Only this loser that was mean to everyone around him. 

The drinks are Expensive and the Food is like eating fermented GARBAGE. 

I don't know about you but paying $20 bucks for a Hot Dog and a Beer is too much. 

STAY AWAY
author: Rew C.

description: The pretzels there are the shyyt! Also had the potato pancakes which are ok, frying them in oil would have given them that extra 'omph' I am used to from eating them in Germany for 12 years. They served them with some odd  'mayo like' sauce. I didn't think to ask if they had apple sauce for them at the time. The German vs American beer pairing was interesting. Really nice atmosphere to this place. 3 stars because even though it was good, it just didn't make me geil.
author: Boris F.

description: Nice place to have lunch! Selections are pretty hearty - choose from burgers to brats to schnitzel.  Great business lunch deal with 3 items. Burgers came with choice of toppings and tator tots (not housemade, but crispy).  Good sized portion of schnitzel with mashed potatoes and cabbage.  Plus - plenty of big-screen TVs for sports viewing!
author: H Q.

description:
$9 for a well Gin and Tonic during happy hour time? Get out of town.

Since the renovation, Schroeder's douchbag level his risen to an all-time high, as have their drink prices. I will not be back.
author: Crystal C.

description: Ordered off UberEats, the bratwurst was not at all a good German meal...Small portion, sausage casing was very thick, and not seasoned well. The mashed potatoes were also dry and tasteless.
author: John E.

description:
We walked in without a reservation and the hostess told us it would be a 10 minute wait.  She gave us ZERO confidence, that she would come find us.  We took a seat at the bar, and in fact she NEVER came back to offer us a table, so we eat at the bar.  
  
The beer is great.  Bar tending staff has zero personality.  I'm looking at you deep voiced black dude.  

Food  taste old and dry.  Not worth a return visit.
author: EC N.

description:
Team lunch was scheduled for Schroeder's & have to say I was pleasantly surprised

Being veggie, there usually isn't a lot for us when it comes to German cuisine but we found plenty of choices

The table ordered a bunch of appies to share so got lots of nibbles of:

Spätzle corn, tomato, ricotta, poppy seeds - this was so creamy & garlicky & good - wishes I'd had a whole bowl of this just for myself

Beets on a bed of honey-yogurt w/ pumpernickel crisps.....the beets were tender & very flavorful

Potato Pancakes - orders were made with & without the bacon so I could indulge as well & wow were they good!  Crisp almost like a cornflake coating & the potato-onion mix had a nice little kick to it.  Baby heirloom tomatoes all piled on top & these were definitely faves of the table ( me included! )

Entrees ranged from the Bratwurst to the Schnitzel meal, the Schnitzel Sandwich, Sauerbraten, & the Chicken Salad.  I ordered the Chicken Salad but minus the checken salad - it was supposed to be on this lettuce, quinoa & peach base w/ a yogurt dressing

Have to say I think I chose poorly for my entree b/c it wasn't all that great.  The lettuce was wilty & there was practically no quinoa - just a random grain scattered here & there.......guess I was hoping for more of a nice bed of the quinoa & especially as I had no chicken salad in my meal.....next time, stick w/ what's on the menu & don't try to make up your own dish

Sides of their pickled veggies - extremely vinegary & pungent in a good way; tater tots - how can you go wrong w / those & fried Spatzle b/c you can never have enough spatzle

We all waddled outta there w/ full & happy bellies
author: Adrienne G.

description: Great beer, great German food. Can't go wrong here. Whenever I am in SF I try to get here.  Great scene at 5pm  place gets busy.
author: Lynn K.

description: Cute little restaurant in the Financial District. I've never had german food before or authentic sauerkraut but the burger i had was really good.Also the tater tots. WOW i am a huge fan of potato of almost any kind and the tater tots were jaw dropping good
author: Nancy W.

description: Dank beers great atmosphere, kind staff! Benches, hardwood bars and a beer hall motif definitely worth stopping by. Kind of expensive!
author: Aaron R.

description: We got here early and our server was attentive without being cloying. She was very sensitive to my food allergies which was great. Water glasses were kept full without being obtrusive. The ambience was nice but it wasn't crowded so it's hard to say what it's like later in the evening. The cocktail list is creative but not extensive. The food was very good and not super heavy like German food can so often be. Overall, a nice experience.
author: Robin N.

description:
Came by for dinner last minute by myself and was able to get a seat in the back which is partitioned off from the bar area (thank god).

The food was just delicious, and the wine pairings suggested by my server, samantha were perfection! Samantha was
author: Beth O.

description:
I frequent this place usually about once a week after work with coworkers. I hadn't been before they renovated, but I like the present theme and atmosphere. It's super casual with long shared wooden tables, a private party area, and a lot of good beer options. 
I like the wide range of beer sizes. Sometimes I just want .3 of a liter, and for my birthday I shared a boot with friends!
The staff here is always...interesting. I really don't think they care about hiring friendly people lol. They do their job well enough, but even after coming here so often and being good patrons the waitress that serves us all the time never gives any acknowledgement. We all laugh about it, but last time we were there we saw her rolling her eyes with another server after seeing our tip! Maybe show some personality... 
We'll still be coming back every week though lol.

Their tots are also really good.
author: Lindsey P.

description: I still like Schroeder's but the amount of liberties they take with the spaetzle is making it harder and harder. I totally understand their desire to stay seasonal but - pumpkin has no business in a noodle dish - and where are the cheese and onions?
author: Oleg H.

description:
I love the new remodeled look!  It still has the traditional German bierfest feel, and even more so now with the communal seating up front.  Long wooden tables deck the front of the bar, while the back hosts individual tables for more formal dining with sleek round chandelier lighting (I only mentioned the lighting because I really liked it!).  They also remodeled the bathroom!  Thank goodness because it was disgusting before!  

Yes, they still have the boot.  And if that's too much for you, you can always opt for the liter, the half liter, or .3L.  They revamped their menu to a more refined bar menu too (well, of course they have brats, but they also have a nice meat and cheese plate too now.)

I'm excited to see how St. Patty's Day will be like next year.  Hope the crowd won't rough it up too much! 

Prost!
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Lots of hype after the re-opening, and I'd been dying to get in there.  Got there at 6:30 on Friday and the line was out the door.  They had a bouncer holding a line outside.  But I had a dinner reservation, so he let us in like VIP.  (Literally had our names on a piece of paper outside)

Cavernous inside.  Original murals and taxidermy, but otherwise modern and slick.  Beer hall tables in the front - where it was madness, and restaurant area in the back.

The food...

If you'd ever been to Daniel Patterson's Plum in oakland - you know it was short lived and went thru changes.  Charlier Parker and Kim Alter were the hyped executive chefs there....but the best chef during their run was Manfred Wrembrel. (Formerly of Incanto and a stint on top chef masters as a sous for chris constantino)  Well, turns our Manfred is now here.

I don't know much about authentic german....but damn the food here is good.  Pretzel bread and pickles were off the hook.  (THE PRETZEL BREAD!!  BOMB!!)  

Started with divine potato pancakes with smoked salmon, and shaved horseradish (i think) that was off the hook.  The cured/pickled sardine dish was light and crisp and refreshing....i love me some sardines.  But the SPAETZLE....THE F$&%ING SPAETZLE....that stuff is crack.  LOVE IT!!

By the time the wienershiniztle and pork belly came out....I was already in food coma. The liter of beer didn't help.

But I highly recommend this spot for dinner and will be back fo sho~!  People are mostly there to drown in boots of beer, but dont sleep on the food.
author: Arthur Y.

description:
Only thing better than the food is the drinks. I love vinegar forward cocktails, and I am right at home here for them! Try the blueberry and you will agree. Though if sour's not your thing, worry not. There is no way that you could leave this extensive bar unhappy. The list of scotch alone will make you glow with joy.

Now, the meat of it - Schroeder's your corner restaurant - were you to be in Bavaria. It has the look, it has the feel and it absolutely has the food. We tried it all and felt that we were back, from schnitzel to spatzel to bratwurst we were in hog heaven.

Potato Pancakes are just as they should be; light, a hint of pushback/chew and flavor. Pretzels are hot and fresh - just how you like everything - and as good as the finest bretzel in Deutschland. Simply point to the Traditional section and prepare for succulent satiation.

Go for the beer, go for the liquor, go for the atmosphere, go for the exemplary waitstaff, you will love All.
author: Katie W.

description:
TLDR: food is overpriced and low quality; beer not much better. 

We started with the Kartoffel Tots. They were fine, although it would take extra effort to ruin tater tots. 

We had the Spätzle for our entree. I get that the chef is doing an interpretation of German food; for this dish (at least) it's a horrible translation. Very salty and dry. Small as hell noodles. They should be embarrassed to charge $19 (!) for this. 

The German Chocolate Cake (which is an American dessert, btw) was dry and did not have much coconut in the frosting. It was more like a flourless chocolate cake. A horrible execution on what is normally one of my all time favorites. 

The beer was ok, although it did not have a head on it. My server tried to explain to me that a hefeweizen would never have a head. Really? Then why are you serving me the beer in a Weizen glass, which is designed to accommodate plenty of foam? The beer tasted ok, so I suspect residue in the glass. 

If you most come here, stick to the beer and skip the food. Better yet, don't come here. There are much better choices for German food (fusion or traditional) in SF.
author: Eric M.

description:
if it wasn't for YELP I would have not known of this place. Nice area and near the HYATT. The space is huge with table you can sit and have conversation's with your neighbor also look and take pic's of their food too hehe. I loved the service , staff was great on this busy 10yr YELP WELCOME PARTY. The food was wonderful the scene was loud and deco very nice and cozy feel.

Beer Great ! and Spatzel OMG! just give me a try of that YUMMM
author: Michelle M.

description:
Schroeder's is looking awesome after the reboot. I've hoisted steins in Munich and I've floated on rivers of beer during Oktoberfest. There's something deeply satisfying about the interplay of roasted pork, tangy cabbage, ice-cold beer, and polka jams. Schroeder's SF honors that tradition and delivers.

The beer program is also looking good. US craft beer is enjoying a golden age these days, so it's prudent to cherry pick the best domestic microbrews. That said, it is nice to see underappreciated German brews and wines emphasized. On a hot summer day, grab a real German Heffeweizen with a lemon wedge at Schroeder's. You'll see what I mean.
author: Chris S.

description: We were trying to grab dinner in the FiDi on a Friday night and couldn't get into Barbacco without a reservation.  Luckily we stumbled onto Schroeder's right down the street.  The three of us got seated immediately in this surprisingly large restaurant.  There was a pretty good selection of beer on draught, and considering how loud and lively the space was, this was the perfect place to drink a couple of pints while eating a few sausages.  The food we got - sausages and spaetzle - was pretty good(nothing memorable), but the environment and beer selection made Schroeder's an unexpectedly fun dinner.
author: Simon L.

description:
This place was terrible. We came with a large party with a reservation on a Saturday night.
First, the hosts had lost our reservation. Luckily, the place was almost empty so this ended up not being much of a problem.
As we sit down, about 6 of the guys in our group order boots of beer. We're told that they only have 2(!) boots in the entire restaurant because the others have broken. Why haven't they been replaced? Get some on Amazon Prime until you can get the nice replacements! This is a German restaurant known for having boots of beer! In addition, the 2 existing boots were in use by another party, so we got zero.
Our server was extremely rude the entire time and spoke to us like we were somehow supposed to know the ins-and-outs of Schroeder's restaurant.
We ordered a bunch of drinks and platters of food and carried on. An hour later, half of us got extremely sick; I'll spare you the details.

Poor customer service, no boot inventory, and food poisoning. I'll never, ever return to Schroeder's.
author: Shannon A.

description:
Great place to unwind after work!   Huge space, so great for large parties.  I haven't been here prior to the renovation, but the decor is nice.

Casual ambiance, but filled with financial district workers.

As for the food, I've only had the appetizers, so I can't speak on the dinner part.  As for the sliders = good, pretzal knotes = fair.... not as soft as as would expect fresh pretzals to be.

Pricey? = yes

Would I come back?  = yes

Enjoy!
author: Len S.

description: Great sausages, and great beer selection. The wines by the glass are also lovely (yes, I order Riesling in a beer joint). The tater tots are the best, and service is usually prompt and cheerful. The only ding on Schroeder's is that it can be deafening when in full swing. Seriously, too loud to talk to your hand. I love to go when it's not crazy busy to avoid the clamor.
author: Lisa R.

description:
If there is such a thing as California-German fusion this is it. I lived in Germany for years and return often. This place does not serve German food. 

The beer was good and the band sounded great. Nice atmosphere. 

Our server essentially shut down when we asked if the Schweinehaxe was on the bone. This is a pork knuckle served On the bone with a crispy skin.  She said no and immediately wrote us off. The service went downhill. The potato. pancakes were greasy. The  sauerbraten didn't resemble any served in Germany. That said, the flavor was good. 

This is not authentic German food, just someone's interpretation of it. If you've been to Germany and want to feel as if you've returned, go elsewhere.
author: Jack G.

description:
I've been a Schroeder's for years and was hoping that with the remodel, they didn't change all of the things I loved about the place.  I went recently with a few friends and thankfully the changes were great and the beer and the food stayed the same.  The decor is much more modern and open but in a very good way.  Our waitress was awesome.  We ordered a few different beers, the pretzel knots (highly recommended) and the bratwurst.

Great update to an old standard.
author: Blake B.

description:
The short: Visiting the establishment for a special 10 year anniversary event so I'm sure I did not get the full experience.

The long: After a long ride out to the Bay area to have the opportunity to kick back, relax, and socialize in this large venue was a nice treat. What little food I had while here was tasty and the bar staff was super attentive and on top of keeping the drinks flowing. I'll happily be stopping in on my next visit to SF to get the full experience food and all.

What works: Great attentive staff and some wonderful drinks

What to improve: Can't say I noticed too much
author: Patrick M.

description: Lovely atmosphere, authentic German food and beer. Really nice for watching soccer games. : ) It would be nice if service would extend beyond the community-style tables to the seats along the wall.
author: Andres G.

description: I really liked the hostess and the staff here. Everyone was very nice and accommodating. I didn't really eat the entrees, but the sausage board and tots were both very good. Everyone had a good time. Next time I come here, I'll get the Kraut burger, it looks amazing
author: Sam Y.

description: Nice ambiente, good service. Food was just ok. They did something with their pretzels, they are not as good as they used to be. Sauerkraut was undercooked, almost raw. Bun for the Bratwurst roll was way too soft, more of a Mexican bollilo than a German roll
author: Ralph K.

description:
Quick Review: One of my favorite happy hour spots in the FIDI, great beers and loaded tots. I've grown to appreciate the art of beer, especially hef..in the boot size. 

Food & Drink
All different types of beer on tap with multiple sizes. Prices are not super cheap but not expensive. Great potato options! I suggest the loaded tots and potato pancakes. My coworkers and I also ordered a sausage platter, some were good but others were not my preference. The platter was also a little pricey too. 

Ambiance
I've never been to Germany but a few people in our group said it was a pretty good attempt of a replica. They had older men (late 50s) come and perform on a Friday night in authentic gear. It was pretty cool. 

Service
Option to go to the bar or have a server come to your table. Overall they are pretty fast and going to the bar wasn't a hassle.
author: Brittany S.

description: Came for lunch. Nice place for a beer fest.  Food is so so.  I had the luck warm wiener schnitzel with dry mash potatoes and bland purple kraut  (I think).  Wife had the Jager schnitzel which had some mushroom gravy on top.  Food is too expensive given the quality.  The Heffeweiss bier was good.  Dunno if I'll return.
author: Dennis L.

description: Drinks were so pure and delicious. The appetizers came out quick, loved the service. Would come here again.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Yes I will sound like a broken MP3 bragging about how good this place was and what a crap had it became. so... if you are still reading this, here are my 5 cents: 

this place was #1 on my list to go have a German beer with few shots of frozen Jägermeister. cause that is kind of not many bars offer in the area 

I visited it with my brother on 06/30, at lunch time, right when Germany was playing someone during world cup thing. i'm not a big fan and cared less about their sport coverage, but they had TVs all around and even 2 big screens. 
Bartender who was serving us (young bearded guy) would not even make eye contact, nor keep a conversation ... ooookay .

Majority beers on tap were American ... ooookay 
Marzen by GB out of which seem to be the only reasonable choice for a 1 liter (not a big fan of IPA guzzling) 

We also got bratwursts, two - what a waste 

so, as usually by tradition wanted to get some Jägermeister  BUT! not only they did not have it from the freeze, THEY DID NOT HAVE IT AT ALL !!! German bar with no Jägermeister ???  

but than i saw the new owner (or at least that bartender told me that is the one)  ... 

Asian guy! and he was running with orders and drinks on the floor, where 3 chicks on the front desk were simply doing nothing 

so... my opinion ... i miss good old Schoreder's. 
It became just another bar. I might swing by there once more, but there are soo many more places that have a character and this one just lost it in translation.
author: Alex S.

description:
I'm giving 2 stars only for the food, the service is undeniably horrible. Our waitress never brought us menu's to start, I had to flag down the bus boy to get one. We then walked to the bar to order our drinks from the lack of service we were receiving and THEN the waitress showed up. She was very rude and short with us and not providing a good experience. When we received the bill, she slammed it on the table as if WE did something wrong? The snobby brunette ruined this place for me.

I came to the old Schroeder's, where people were friendly, there was dancing, it was authentic and such great atmosphere. Where did they go? Now its just a stuffy, yuppy bar like the rest of SF is becoming. It is such a shame.
author: Jackie S.

description: Spacious with lots of seating, great selection of beers, AMAZING tater tots, what more can you ask for? The only down side is that they close at 10pm on a Friday.
author: Thao T.

description:
It's all about the boot here. Sort of a gimmick, but sort of a piece of history as well, considering this may be THE oldest German brewery in SF, starting existence in circa 1898.

Main dish I had was two links of bratwurst. Were decent, not outstanding. Same goes for the smoked sardines (with soft boiled eggs) and pork rinds -- everything was a good accompaniment to our [large] beverages.

But yep, dare you get it, fill that boot up with a liter of good German beer (I chose Weihenstephaner Hefeweissbier) and take your time mightily trying to finish it! No chugging aloud. Only reason I did not *QUITE* finish is because of a movie reservation at the Embarcadero Cinema nearby to see Richard Linklater's excellent film, "Boyhood."
author: Garett T.

description: Nice place with an amazing Wiener Schnitzel and bacon-potato soup. The place is loud and can get crowded. Reminded me of Munich. To top it off they have Hofbräu on tap.
author: Jorge R.

description:
Great German food, German beer (das boot!), and German everything.

I've been to Germany for about 4-5 days and it really does due justice (in downtown SF of all packed places) to the huge 'hofrabahaus' dining halls that fit 1,000 people+.

The bratwurst are all different and tasty. The various sliders are great. They even have tater tots, win!

The old fashion drinks, das boot beers, and service are amazing. Highly recommended for a fun German themed outting for drinks/food/hangout out with friends. Plus tons of TV to watch sports.
author: Chuck N.

description:
The old Schroeder's used to be my "satellite" office for years and represented a significant time in my life. I went there tonight for the first time since the remodel and I was pleasantly surprised. It is very tastefully done! I love the inside vibe and look forward to coming back with the guys.

The beer selection was good, the tots were great, and the bratwurst was something I'd order again but not spectacular. The red cabbage and sauerkraut had way to much salt but luckily the mashed potatoes and pickles were excellent. Respectfully, the cooking staff should eat at Suppenküche to see how great authentic German food can be. So, good starters but slightly disappointed with the main dish and I wouldn't risk $20+ to try anything else on that level.

Friendly staff and again, wonderful decor. A slightly modern twist on a traditional beer house worth a visit. Prost!
author: Dave R.

description:
Came here for dinner on Saturday night, which is definitely a different vibe from the post-work weekday crowd. The dining room was fairly quiet save for the German band playing. 

My dad, who used to eat lunch with my grandfather at Schroeder's at least once a week in the 70s, was disappointed to see the changes in the menu but still enjoyed the sauerbraten. He reminded me several times while I was perusing the menu that in the good old days, women weren't permitted in the restaurant for lunch because they took too long to decide. Sounds about right...

The waitress kindly provided me several gluten-free options, and I ended up with the burger (no bun) and potato salad, which was delicious. I was thrilled to see Omission gluten free beer on the menu in addition to the standard German bar beer repertoire. 

Super delicious food, service warmed up as the night wore on, and cute cozy dining area. Loved it.
author: Stefany B.

description:
Price adjustment.

Steal: Plate of fresh salmon with sides and a local beer for $10 in Estonia.

Swindled: Turkey pastrami sandwich with avocado, cheese, honey mustard, sprouts on toasted wheat for $14 in the FiDi.

It was delicious. Renovated space is beautiful. Service was nice. There was a pickle and chips on the side. But not $14 delicious, beautiful and nice. 

Make that almost $20 with tax and tip. For an average sized sandwich.

Going to take some time readjusting to what is becoming the San Francisco status quo. Realize it's more expensive. But sometimes you feel taken advantage of.

Plenty of other yelps seem to have had the same sticker shock.
author: Jason B.

description:
I'm not a huge fan of German food but I love drinking here!

I originally checked this place out on a Yelp Elite event for the 10 year party, but have been back 3 more times.

I love their cocktails. A little pricy but they are strong and use premium spirits. Their is one I can only describe as Scotchy, scotch, scotch scotch! It has that expensive smokey single malt scotch in it and is a pretty awesome drink. They also have some great beers on tap, and you see those boot things. The HUGE beer boot glasses. I'm not sure how anyone can finish one of those. They are crazy!
author: Chris S.

description: Great place for groups! Comfortable and casual vibes.  Wide selection of German beers.  My friend got the smothered tots and loved them.  I would recommend the tasting flight! Good place to watch a game with the huge flatscreen.
author: Jamie L.

description:
Great beers, good food but not as good as the beer. 

I've been to Schroeder's both before and after the renovations.  While after renovations the food menus have improved, I wouldn't say I would come back for the food.    The Beer though, that's a different story, still consistently good. 

Yes before the renovations the place was very dark.  Food choices also was not great, but typical pub fair that you would expect at a German beer bar.  The place has now been transformed with beer all tables and bright candle style lighting.  Does make one feel like they are in a Beer hall in German, kinda... 

I say kinda, because we're still at the heart of the financial district.  And you can tell they really try to cater for that audience.  So while the thoughts of making it look like a traditional German beer hall is there, it does feel very much falsly put together and not quite right.  

This also comes down to the food.  While the food is good. It wasn't specular and amazing. A companion of mine loved German food, but he didn't find much of what we ate that day authentically German.   

The Spatzle was very American, very much more like a mac and cheese.  The Potato pancake was more like a hash brown.  The Schnitzel was very crispy and good.   Overall the food was good, but you can tell it was done so with a flare to cater towards the American Professionals working in the area. 

The beers are still great.  It's still a great place to get a boot of good beer.   I'll be back for the drinks.
author: Maggie F.

description: I don't leave many ratings but i gotta share: What a great find this place was for me and my group on a Sat night. Great atmosphere, spacious, and super friendly staff. Only had pretzels for food so can't judge on that but the drink selections were plentiful and the Liter option was nice too for it's price. Oh and the "competitions" they had were cool and a lot of fun to watch. Will definitely be planning to head back soon.
author: Jimmy K.

description:
There is something to be said about restaurants that are able to continue tradition and expand into a wider demographics. After two years of being away as duke of Schroeder's, I was excited to try Schroeder's 2.0 and the result was actually less than stellar. 

The atmosphere has changed, it has become far more clinical and lost a lot of the character of a small mom and pop ran restaurant. I can't speak for the food menu, but the beer selection is slightly better than it used to be but at almost twice the price. Before the renovation, liter beers were $12, now they're $18? For what reason? 

This place used to be a classic destination because of the character, entertainment and free Friday appetizers. Now that all of this has been stripped there is no reason to come here. Sadly Schroeder's has become another over priced and soulless FIDI bar.
author: Carlos V.

description:
Such a fun place to go for happy hour especially when it's not too crowded (which is basically never)! This bar has such a german-feeling to it and the beer in the boot is just the cherry on top. If this is your pregame, get the boot with a couple of friends - it's a really fun experience! I've tried some of their small snacks as well like the pretzels and tater tots and they're a great accompaniment to the beer.

If this place looks to crowded at first, give it a couple of minutes, the tables tend to clear up fast as people come and go at different times!
author: Malika R.

description:
As the original Schroeder's "first to review" (ahem),  I felt it might be best to wait a little bit to let the dust settle before updating my review.  After many visits to the new incarnation,  I feel it's time.  

I loved the Old Schroeder's.   A lot.   Old Schroeders was the alterna girl you knew Sophomore year who was sneaky hot.   Behind that mess of unkempt hair were beautiful brown eyes and cuteness that the masses didn't quite appreciate.   A spitfire in a New Order T-shirt.  She was friendly.   She was cool.   And the secret not many people knew:  she was hot.

Then the first day of school Junior year you came back and she rolls in with a new look.   Blonde hair cropped shoulder length,  guess jeans and a bitchin new purse.   All the sudden the jocks start to pay attention.   Before long she's the girl all the guys long after.  She's still the same nice girl you used to know, and by no means has she written you off,  but she has some new friends now -  and some of them are pretty douchey. 

So what do you do?   Do you go too-cool-for-school and write her off a as a sellout?  Tell everyone how she used to be so "real" back in the Doc Marten days,  but now is stuck up?   Or do you accept that despite the fact that the secret is out,  she's still your friend and probably hotter than ever. 

Schroeder's is that girl to me.   I loved her before, but I'll admit  that she's looking better than ever.  Fun communal tables.   Massively improved food.  Huge projection TV screen for sports.  Friendly waitstaff.  But despite all that,  she hasn't lost what made me fall for her in the first place -  the murals, the boots,  the beat up millwork that has seen decades of patrons drink and dine in its warm glow.   She's a warm hug after a hard day of work. Just as she always always has been.

She may not be just mine anymore (before it was half empty -  now I have to and get there early for a seat),  but I love her still the same.  I may just have to share her now with the masses.  Five stars.
author: Cully W.

description: Nein, nein, nein. Schroeder's claims to be a German bar, yet they charge $10 for a beer and $15 for bratwurst. That ain't German. That's SF bullshit.
author: Justin K.

description:
Looks the part, but fails to deliver in terms of drinks and food. With so many delicious options in the area, I probably won't be coming back.

Food: I ordered the potato pancakes and while they were tasty, I was honestly surprised by how little food there was. My friends ordered the more expensive halibut and also got a smaller-than-expected portion.

Drinks: While there were some good beers offered, it's a surprisingly small beer list for a German-style biergarten.

Service: Mediocre. We waited a while for our food even though the place wasn't too busy, and were not offered water.
author: L H.

description:
I went here with my 10 of my coworkers tonight and was completely TURNED OFF. We tried coming once, it was packed and it was recommended that we get a reservation. So for today's event, we did.

We were celebrating a few events: a promotion, grad school entrance, and a bday. We ordered drinks our first round and ordered some food to start. I would say we weren't there long until we received the check. The service from our waitress was atrocious. If the area we were sitting at wasn't an area for "drinks", it clearly wasn't explained to us. If we were told that we have to order xyz, we happily could have; ordering wasn't an issue we just wanted to settle a bit before we could think about it. We tried to order a few things and were denied. Add insult to injury, they dropped the bill off as we were told we couldn't order items. 

Not sure what happened. Food was decent, but because the experience was what it was: it SUCKED. Kind of like a pretty girl who has a bad attitude. This place isn't "fancy" enough to act as horrible as they did - it's obviously a watering hole for after work beers in the FiDi. You're a pub that serves beer and sausages for crying out loud. Put your pinky down.

Would never, EVER, recommend this place. The one good thing is that they showed their ass early so we couldn't give them any more business than we sadly had already given.
author: Tinick P.

description: Had a great lunch experience with colleagues. Staff were very prompt and helpful, and food arrived quickly and was delicious, as usual.
author: Robert G.

description:
Good food + good atmosphere + good beer + nice waitress = fun lunch

Went for a fun business lunch and had the kroketten tots (tate tots), Jaeger Schnitzel with red cabbage. Very tasty. It costs a little more than a regular lunch but that's expected because it's not your regular lunch faire. I like that they have stein lockers for regulars who want to store their beer steins there...seeing them adds to the fun atmosphere. The waitress was really nice and patient as we tried to decide which of the 20+ beers to choose from.
author: Jim T.

description: Restaurant was freezing cold; the hostess said that it is "always like this." Both my guest and I wore down coats through the meal. Potatoes were extremely over salted: essentially inedible so left on the plate. The pickled shrimp sandwich was extremely skimpy. The wurst was fabulous, and I like the decor. The service was good. Didn't try any beer: needed to stick to hot beverages due to aforementioned cold.
author: Annette C.

description: The beer at schroders is great.  The food is ok.   Schnitzel pretty meh, but goulash was good.  They have a lot of space, and can accomidate large parties.
author: Michael E.

description: I only had a glass of champagne here ($14 =(   ) But the environment was really fun! My 2 friends and I were able to get a spot at the end of one of their long, wooden tables which was great because the place was packed!! I would love to go back another time for the food. Fun find, definitely feels like a German beer hall in DTSF!
author: Stephanie D.

description:
Was there 2 weeks ago, it's was very busy and nice.
The German Pretzel and the Wiener Schnitzel and the salad was great!
Easy 5 stars!
author: Ben R.

description:
We turned up as group of 30 ish for happy hour I.Thursday's.  Our office manager said as long as we we have a stamp we can order beer . So rocked to bar with stamp they had no idea said they would find out  then I got harassed twice in two minutes about the bill even the manager harassed said she knew nothing about it and proceeds give our office manager a hard time really . So dropped my card on it and then still got the evil crap they said they would transfer it on to the bigger bill     Duh   

Shame place looks great customer service sucks
author: MIchael S.

description: My friends and I went there on a Saturday night for dinner and I have to say it was an amazing experience! Service was superb, from friendly hosts to our server Sam. The food is a modern interpretation of classic German cuisine. The Jäger schnitzel, the Sauerbraten and the artichokes are absolutely incredible, and the game hen is a real feast! The portions are generous, and the chef definitely knows what he is doing. I totally recommend this place!
author: Timothy C.

description:
I went to Shroeder's a couple of years ago and didn't love it, but I went again recently for happy hour and they remodeled the whole place - it's SOOOO cute! 

Really fun place to grab some drinks after work. They have communal tables which I usually find to be awkward, but it works out just fine when you're getting your drink on. Nice wine list, good beers, and their tater tots are perfect little balls of potato heaven, so make sure you get them.

Been here twice in the last month, definitely one of my new favorites! :)
author: Suki B.

description: The revamp is a job well done. Cozy traditional German bar atmosphere with a modern twist. They have a nicely curated collection of traditional beer steins. Very decent rotating German and US beer selection. Simple yet tasty German food menu. Service is very good. A great place for a power lunch or happy hour.
author: Stefan R.

description: I used to go to the old Schroeder's and I can say what a beautiful improvement. I love the dark room romantic decor. The vintage authentic German beer steins are displayed in a lighted case.  The restrooms were updated and also the wine, beer and booze menu. I had crabcakes as an appetizer, that is not a typical German dish. They were out of the pretzels with the smoked butter. I had the chicken wurst for my entree and yes those were tater tots with my sausage.  I'll will probably go back.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
Truth be told I was more than a bit nervous to meet an old friend here for lunch, it had all the makings of one big fat awkward mess.  But you know what, from the minute we sat down for lunch, it was altogether beautiful and civilized, and nothing like it used to be...  just like the newly remodeled Schroeders.

The food was delicious, but a brat will run you $15 and the weiner schnitzel $24.  The wait staff seemed a bit eager to clear us out, it was a busy lunch crowd.
author: Meg W.

description: Schroeders is a fantastic place to grab a German beer for happy hour or just in general. I was there twice this past week, once for Happy Hour on Thursday. Ladies, run don't walk, the man candy is to die for. Then on Sat for dinner, we were promptly seated by a lovely woman named Kyla, even though we were having issues with our party size. (Seriously friend yes means yes!) We had a great meal and the service was top notch. I would definitely go go back.
author: Alexzandra H.

description:
This place is always a treat! 

The food is fantastic, the ambiance great and we had a wonderful time. The staff was crazy friendly. I highly recommend the plate of meat. I mean, YUM!

I also love that they carry gluten-free beers. It's nice to be able to go to a beer hall with friends and have an option to drink!

If you ever need drinks in FiDi or want a great night out with some rockin' german food, you don't need to look any further than Schroeder's.
author: Renee P.

description:
Definitely a fan! 

Couldn't have asked for a classier sports bar! Ashley (I think that's her name), the host, is also amazing!! 

I came during a really crowded time (Warriors NBA Finals Game #4) with a group of 5-6 people. There were private parties that booked the back end so perhaps that's why  service seemed to be a bit slow (hence the 4 stars). Other than that, come thirsty and hungry! Everything on the menu is wonderful!

I will be back!
author: Claudia P.

description:
I was long overdue to try the revamped, modernized Schroeder's and found it to be a mixed bag.  The atmosphere is now amazing; they kept all that was good and spruced it up nicely.  Same with the menu which now finally has some veggies and freshness, just enough CA flair to the traditional German favorites.  The issue we had was with the ridiculously chaotic service.  We sat at the bar on a busy Friday for lunch and it was a complete cluster***.
Food runners were literally walking around the massive restaurant asking people, "did you order this"?   We had *two* different, incorrect meals put in front of us before ours arrived (after a very long wait).  No surprise, it was cold when it finally came.  We weren't about to send it back - could have been an hour before it returned (and likely still cold).  The items would have been really quite delicious if hot.
The bartenders were confused beyond belief themselves.  It was as if it was everyone's first day.  They need more staff and/or more training.  It was certainly busy, but probably not any different than any other Friday lunch.  Did the regular staff all walk out, to be replaced by novices?  It really didn't make sense -???
author: Ellen H.

description: Amazing bratwurst! This restaurant is very authentic German. The interior is very cool and authentic. Service is good and nice atmosphere. Totally will come back!!
author: Cole F.

description:
The newly renovated space is beautiful and I am excited to see a smaller, more refined menu than previously. However, the food is small and not good and not traditional. The beer is expensive, but tasty. The service is super friendly and helpful. 

And, it is my understanding that the Ocktoberfest block party was a hit, however we went on actually Ocktoberfest (day after) and it was s snore. We expected way more and were told that there would be festivities, but alas...no there really weren't.
author: Jenn D.

description:
4 stars for private party service!

My company rented one of the back "rooms" for a work happy hour and let me say the service was suburb.  The servers came out with trays of delicious German beers for us to chose from.  Wine pours were plentiful.  
Sparkling wine too? You don't say!

Everytime our drink was below the alert alert I need another beer line, they were in ready with a tall glass of drink me now please.

The Warriors game was on in the bar area and I jokingly asked the waitress to tell me the score throughout our party . . . and she did.  SO AMAZING! 

FOOD - the pretzels were da bomb. 
Sausages/Brats: a little dry for my Polish taste . . 

BRING BACK THE BRUSSEL SPROUTS!

I would highly recommend renting out one of the back rooms that are separated by sheer curtains which makes it fun to still people watch with a little privacy . . . 

Thanks for a great time! :)
author: Jenny B.

description:
We were in San Francisco two weeks ago and ate lunch at Schroeder's.  It was fabulous!
