A really beautiful and interesting restaurant. The food is delicious.  I have been to Oktoberfest
the last 5 fives years, this food is authentic.  Next time I am in San Francisco, I will definitely eat here.
Great beer as well.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Went once before and once after renovation.
I think I liked the food before renovation...
The place is now fancier but more expensive.
I had bratwurst for lunch which came as a fancy hotdog and tater tots for $15.
REALLY!? Apple strudel was ok.
author: Sunny S.

description:
I came here with a colleague to watch a game and grab a drink.  It's tough to find a good place to eat, drink and catch a game in the Embarcadero but this is a good option.

The bartender Nick made a couple of good Manhattans.  Nice selection of rye etc here.

I ordered the Jager Schnitzel. A generous portion of breaded pork, it was graced by an array mushrooms to numerous to name but oyster and hen of the woods present.

If you are looking for a decent place to catch a drink, regard some ersatz German murals, quaff a beer from a big stein or have some wine, this is a good call.
author: Dave H.

description:
Schroeder is a huge place! It's a bar and a restaurant with a huge dining room. They have some kind of wheat theme going on here. The inside looks very new like they just remodeled. 

== Food ==

Pretzel knot was very very good. This definitely a must get. It's very soft on the inside while a bit crunchy on the outside. 

Potato pancake was very delicious! It's very oily... actually it tastes like what it is... a fried oily potato. Kind of like a hash brown, but more oily.

Bratwurst, Currywurst, and mashed potatoes. The bratwurst is very good. It has a nice meaty flavor with some kind of spice to it. Currywurst is good, but the curry spices kind of threw me off. It's spicy and kind of pales in comparison with the bratwurst. The mashed potatoes are really good. They are very creamy and smooth.

Spatzle is some kind of potato and cheese dish. It looks like mac and cheese but tastes like olive oil potatoes. It was an okay dish.

== Service ==

The waitress was nice and engaging. The food came rather quickly for all the dishes that were ordered.

== Overall ==

Expensive but a good place for lunch. Most of the dishes are good. Some of them stand out and shine brightly compared to the rest. The more worthwhile dishes are worth the money.
author: Steven B.

description:
The best things that made Schroeder's charming, unique, and different are gone.

The decor is the only thing that has improved.  The bathroom is better.

Things that got worse:

1. Beer selection: where is the Czechvar? Why are there American beers on the menu that I can get at three dozen other places in SF?

2. $14 for a Bratwurst? With no sides?

3. Where is the sausage plate?

4. Where is the goulash?

5. Pickles used to be free. Now they cost $6.

7. Where are the meatballs?

8. Where is the German schlager or European polka music?

I think I'll be going to Harrington's across the street.

At least they still have heritage.
author: David D.

description:
A former fine establishment that has been changed and watered down to a hipster's attempt at a German restaurant that will just not work.

This place really used to be a fine establishment, with soccer and beer and a solid stroganoff.  Now, the only German thing it serves are bangers.

Although the beer is still decent, and the place is nice enough, it really just is not all that German.  It feels forced, and confused between the German and the hipster.  

Not quite my cup of tea.  Miss the old solid stroganoff that used to be here.  Too bad, as that recipe had been here for decades...
author: Mark M.

description:
German in name only. Unless you are getting beers and watching a game don't bother! 

If I could give them zero stars I would. I haven't even left and I'm this disappointed! 

They forgot to serve us bread to start. Which is understandable, but still the details matter. 

The schnitzel is a disgrace. No flavor, any thinner and it would be a sheet of paper, and the sauce only has a hint of flavor. Think of Homer Simpson yelling at the rice cake and you are pretty close. They charge $24 for this. I felt robbed the moment it showed up. 

I wondered why it was near empty for a Saturday night. Now I have an idea.

The new look of the place is good, the atmosphere is good, and the staff is attentive and professional. Yet to call the food Germany is to dishonor Germany. 

Our whole table of four ended up voicing our complaints to the manager. He seemed like he had a speech prepared, like he had heard this all before, and did his best to try to describe to us what they were doing with the restaurant. To be hipster friendly with a California lean style to German food is pretty much what we were told. As well as if we didn't like what they were doing here are the names of two other German restaurants to go to so we can find what we are looking for. 

Well when I go to a German restaurant I expect German food! Not what was presented to us. It is clear that the chef doesn't know what he is doing. I shouldn't get up from the table feeling hungry for the price of the meal I paid for, which was what happened.

I'm more disappointed than I am angry. I expected German food, and instead received extremely overpriced hipster styled food. You have to first be cool and be of quality to do that. I was told the menu is seasonal. Hopefully when the menu changes again it  will get changed to something that resembles German food.

At the end the Manger took off half of our bill and wished we would try them again. I might come back for beers and beers only, yet I am not going to order any more food from them until they can provide evidence that they know and understand what real German food is. 

Everyone that went was really looking forward to getting German food. This experience was such a disappointment that it nearly ruined our night.
author: Harrison J.

description:
Horrible service! We went for a friends birthday and had a group of about 8 people. The waitress was nice at first but kept messing up our order. She forgot several things that we had ordered and then never came back to our table to see if everything was okay, etc. We tried to get her attention to order more drinks or get the bill but we felt that she was ignoring us. 
 
The food was okay. The potato pancakes were gross but the spitzel was good. I will probably never go back here.
author: Christa B.

description:
Oh, well. At least I dont have to wonder what the new Schroeder's would be like anymore.  Perhaps the "dark cave at the end of the time tunnel to 1975 " niche wasn't paying off anymore.   I do have trouble believing that the 
"over-staffed, 13 Dollar burger-serving, culinary school bratwurst-presenting, plain american food dressed up with german accents" niche is going to be more lucrative.
If you're looking for german food, go someplace else.  If you're looking for a good dollar value, consider another choice.  The old Schroeder's filled a (very small, admittedly) hole in my life that could only be filled with an obscure central European beer and a plate of heavy german food served by attitude wrapped up in a dirndl.
I'm not sure what they're selling now, but I'm not in the market for it.
author: rich s.

description: I was here for a Warriors game. The ambiance is nice but the prices are really high for a biergarten type of place. Beer selection decent and pretzels were good. But I order a German chocolate cake that didn't come out for probably 20 min so the server apologized and asked if I wanted to take it off. I cut my losses and did but he didn't even comp a single thing or offer any alternative. Kind of ridiculous for something you'd think would be a quick slice and scoop.
author: Carly M.

description:
Once upon a time, I would have given Schroeder's a five star review. Now, it deserves a 0.5 star rating. The Neu Schroeder's is fancy in that S.F. / N.Y.C. restaurant kind of way, and that's about it. No more Köstritzer, no more Warsteiner, no more Radeberger.... 

The gal behind the bar has attitude, and the beer menu has been fancified with higher prices, more CA beers, and the usual nuevo-california foodie foolishness describing the beers: "grapefruit, pine, floral, herbed olives, golden raisin"; etc. I very much appreciate good beer, but... it's BEER for God's sake! And they've eliminated any unique tap handles, it's just a row of stainless steel pulls now. They kept the old paintings and wood paneling, but I don't even know why they bothered with that.

I honestly have no idea how some reviewers here can give the place 5 stars now. It is virtually the same as any other fancy glass and fancy 'rustic' wood restaurant in the city, with menus and prices to match. I enjoyed the place for many years, but now, sadly; Schroeder's, you are dead to me.

- I tried to update this review, don't know what happened - trying again:

So - UPDATE - they have eliminated the Goulash soup, which together with a half liter of beer was a heavenly and filling evening meal. WTF? Also, there's no sausage platter!! A German beer hall with no sausage platter?!? Seriously? For shame, Schroeder's, for shame.
author: Steven B.

description:
Worst German food I have had. This is not German food and the portions are tiny. When you get a schnitzel you don't even get a side dish. 

On the bright side the beer is good.
author: Andreas G.

description:
We went to Schroders on one of the Oktoberfest Saturdays expecting an amazing evening.... And while the live music and dance was great, the food and service were not particularly extraordinary. 

The food was good, but far from 'authentic' and quite overpriced. If the food had been more like $15-$20 a plate rather than $25+ I would have been more impressed. Additionally, the pretzels were bland and the mustard didn't make them any better, we actually preferred them without. The other appetizer we had was 'smothered tator tots' (not my choice but....)  the flavor on these guys was good, but they just seemed like frozen tots.

For dinner we had, Weiner Svhnitzel (bland), Jager Schnitzel (which had great flavor + was pretty good), + the Sauerbraten (also very good and flavorful)

For dessert we got both apple strudel and the pretzel bread pudding. The strudel was nothing more than what seemed like a frozen apple turnover, however, the pretzel pudding was delicious!

I think our greatest issue with the restaurant was the lack of consistency + the lack of authenticity. This place has been a SF staple for years, my uncle used to go here 30 years ago and loved it. Perhaps they are under new ownership, or perhaps they're trying to appeal to a different audience? Either way, I wouldn't break the bank on the food here.
author: Nelli S.

description:
Even though this bar was legit in terms of space/TV/beer selection, the service I had from one of the female servers was horrendous.  She was snapping on me when I was asking simple questions, even before I drank anything, completely un-called for!  The bar was not even busy at all, despite it being a world cup game due to the holiday.  
The other guys working seemed cool so hopefully this was an isolated occurrence!
author: Ubz D.

description:
We arrived at lunchtime w/o reservations, so we waited 30 minutes for a bench. 

The food was unremarkable- Wiener schnitzel dry and bland. The potato salad was also bland- not enough mustard. Kats favorite part of te meal was the tater tots. My bratwurst was lean and crumbly. No juice and very little taste. 

Our sever was working tables all throughout the restaurant, so we didn't see much of her.


The beer was good, albeit expensive. Speisekammer, see you for my birthday!
author: Joe E.

description: This is a cool bar that can accommodate medium to large groups without a reservation. The place looked great and inviting and the service was good. Typical bar food to order but with a twist- pretzels and burgers for the most part but they were all delicious. We ate everything and ordered a ton of drinks. Overall, a success!
author: Monica C.

description:
Review is only for their signature cocktails..... haven't tried the food just yet.

Craft cocktails here are among our favorites. We had the Be Mein and Grune Tal.  Both were delicious.  Both were prepared well with the appropriate strength.  Can't speak much about the Be Mein since I was told it was yums but Grune Tal was smokey (used Laphroaig), with a hint of citrus to meld well with the smokey notes.  Good stuffs.  I don't see it on the online menu so it must be seasonal? If you're tapped out with old fashioneds, this is the next go to.  

Plenty of bench like seating, hooks for clothing (at least I think they were or they were candle sconces), Das Boot (2 liter sizes), kinda make shift beer-stein museum.  Think german beer tavern but a bit more fancy.

Will definitely return for more craft cocktails, and maybe, just maybe, try the actual food (or arrive early enough so that the kitchen is actually open).
author: Vivial S.

description: Not very impressed with the food, tired several different items. Gave this place a shot a few times and I never walk out with a wow that was a great time. To me the beer doesn't taste crisp and has a syrupy taste to all of them. Tired a boot and a few of the german pints.
author: Sugi s.

description:
This is the first time I am here since they remodeled. Just sad. The place lost its character. Instead of this being a German/Czech beer hall it turned into a modern style brewpub/fusion place. 

Their draught beer selection dramatically shrank. Music atmosphere is lousy. The biggest kicker is that the two different hefeweizens i ordered which each is listed for $8 for 0.5L i got charged $9. The first time I thought it was a mistake but the 2nd time I knew that I am getting ripped off.
author: Yup I.

description:
What a difference new ownership makes. While I'll allow that any bar with a Das Boot is killer, here's the facets of the OLD Schroeder's I am very glad to see changed:

The floor: they have one now! And it's polished wood, not linoleum with potholes in it that went clear down to the basement.

The "food" at the old place was rancid meatballs and frozen vegetables. There's a real reason it was free. The new menu is insane; the best of the kitchens of Bavaria and CA. I'll admit I'm partial to German food, but their take on the cuisine is perfect: not too much vinegar and heavy sauces, the right leavening of California flavors, and more than enough fresh ingredients and creative preparations. Only food of its kind in the City.

The alligators in the bathroom. Yes, I'm pretty sure there were alligators in the old toilets. Never stuck my head in to verify, but I definitely made eye contact with a malicious aquatic reptile following a reading session at the old Schroeder's. Terrifying. New bathrooms, clean facilities, and like the rest of the place: updated and modern. Whew!

The "service". Gotta ask, where exactly do these Yelp reviewers come from that preferred the old staff?! What exactly is viewed as "good" service?? I don't know who considers it a fun-filled night to get yelled at by grumpy life-term bartenders, then to be delivered a bill that contains charges (cash only, naturally) that are double the amount of beers consumed. No, I'm not exaggerating, this happened three to four times to me and at least as many to more than a few people I know. If getting into a shouting match with that grouchy, sullen old manager in order to avoid getting charged up the keister for phantom drinks is your idea of fun, well, then, the NEW Schroeder's isn't your style. 

And finally, the beer hall itself. The good parts, I mean. I work in Munich for a chunk of each year, and THIS is what a beer hall looks like. They kept all the great old murals, the old wainscoting, the old taxidermy, basically they kept the historical lifeblood of the place....and updated and polished everything else. And thank God for that. Long, blonde wood tables, chandeliers that would be at home in any Braustube, benches, sexy lighting. The hall got the best kind of facelift: removing all blemish and leaving what made it special in place.

This place is the real deal: It's crowded, it's noisy, it's fun, it's a damn beer hall. It's nice that, after 120 years, the City FINALLY got the beer hall it deserves.
author: Sean C.

description:
This place was cool before, now it's even better! It retained the feel of a German beer hall, but now it's an updated version of one. The whole front wall was knocked down and in it's place they put a nice storefront. It really opens up the place and gives it a better vibe. 
Food and drink menu was redone also, I had the Kraut burger I think it was called and it was very tasty. Beer selection is always great of course, but that goes without saying.
author: George M.

description:
When you make big changes, not everybody is going to be happy.

Revisited the "new" Schroder's for the first time this past week. Unfortunately, I'm in the unhappy camp. 

Considering their location in the Financial District, maybe this was a good change for them. They've "modernized" the decor, and the menus as well (including the beer). You can, however, still order from the bar menu at a regular table (just ask). I ordered a brat from the bar menu, and it was decent.

I liked the old Schroder's, and I'll miss it. Won't be revisiting the "new" one in the future. But best of luck to them.
author: Celeste H.

description:
This place has been getting a remodeled recently and this has been a source of excitement for myself and my coworkers who frequented the "old" establishment. The last day or so we've seen people inside enjoying drinks so a group of us decided to see if we could get a drink and check out the new interior.  We were very disappointed by the dismissive response we got from the Asian looking gentleman standing at the new host stand.

Sorry sir, if you're having a private party you might want to follow the lead of all the other SF establishments and simply post a sign on your door. There's really no reason to make your once regulars feel like they are putting you out when they come in excitedly to see the new place and buy a drink.

I get it, new ownership, new staff...yadda yadda. But, you should be welcoming to patrons even if you've failed to post a sign that you were closed for a private parties until your official opening.
author: Jorge S.

description:
Take the three stars with a grain of salt. We had a fun Saturday night dinner here. The ambiance is really inviting - lots of long communal tables and a back section with actual 2 and 4 top tables if you're looking for something a little more subdued. Plenty of TVs for sports viewing.  Service was consistently good throughout our meal and overall I just loved the wide open feel of the restaurant. Oh! There was live music too, loved that! 

The food is what left me less than impressed. I do recommend the tots - they were tasty and came with yummy dipping sauces.  Our friends enjoyed the sausage platter too. My jaeger schnitzel was pretty over-seasoned and the spaetzle was really dry, boo! 

Fun spot to go with a group, but I think there is far superior German food in the city (Hi, Leopold's!)
author: Brianna M.

description: Cool spot in the FiDi. Decent beer selection and great tasting, if not hearty, pub food (loved the hash browns and pretzel bites). The interior is cool- a mix of old school German beer hall and understated communal table restaurant. The only downside is that you have to pretty much stalk for a seat unless you commit to eating dinner, at which point, the hostess is willing to seat you in the back.
author: Mar C.

description:
I'm so thrilled Schroeder's has reopened. The revamp is a complete success from atmosphere to menu to brew. They have only been open a few weeks and I've already ventured there for dinner twice.  It's the best of German cuisine meets Northern California.
If you're just there for happy hour, don't miss having a cocktail, the tenders are brilliant. If you get cozy for a meal, do NOT overlook Spatzle or Beets or Pork Belly and thats just the appetizers.
Single ladies, heads up, this may be the best place to be Friday after work. ;-)
author: Kelly W.

description:
Schroeder's 2.0 is a welcome addition to the financial district!  

Some highlights for me: 
- The remodel: like how they kept the old murals but revamped the entire interior. 
- The bar: very social w/ communal tables, yummy beers, and a unique Old Fashioned that I believe is brandy based.  
- The food: Spätzle (a must) & the Wiener Schnitzel. 
- The staff: friendly & inviting.  

Understand that there's some push back from fans of the grittier old Schroeder's but to quote a Billy Joel song, "The good ole' days weren't always good and tomorrow ain't as bad as it seems."
author: Tim F.

description:
I came here for dinner after work and love the decor and staff here. I would recommend coming with larger groups because the portions are gigantic and you'd get more variety - for two people, it's hard to get the full experience and not stuff yourself full to bursting. The spatzel is my favorite, and their salads are always really light and tasty. 

I just want to give people the heads up that the meat platter was a bit too adventurous for me (I couldn't handle pig face, sorry), but for someone who's into less traditional cuts, this is perfect. It's just a ton of food, so come prepared!
author: Rachel A.

description:
I have had many a good times here.
Food is good, nice beer, good projector to watch sports.
What's not to like!
author: P D.

description:
I love this place after the reboot. This has quickly become my venue of choice for after-market drinks and snacks. Boasting a mix of German\Craft Beers, Wine, and cocktails, there is something for everyone. I also found everyone extraordinarily friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive.
While they certainly spruced up the joint, they kept some of the original artwork that gave the old Schroeder's its charm. Personally, I am glad that I can now eat and drink there and without the shadow of worry about the state of my vaccinations, which was not the case under the old management. I am looking forward to the evolving menu and will continue to visit this place for along time to come.
author: Luis G.

description:
Nope.

I was a big fan of the 'old' Schroder's.  The abundant boots of beer, the polka music, the stiff-arm competitions of who can hold a liter of beer the longest.  All gone in the new modern revision.  The beer still tastes good and I'm sure the food is decent, but the best parts of this restaurant left with the old owners.  SF has plenty of modern, overpriced restaurants.  My opinion is we need more with real character.
author: M R.

description:
Wow!  What an amazing remodeling job the new Schroeder's owners have done.  By keeping some of the best from the old, while dramatically improving this San Francisco institution, was an almost impossible task that they have masterfully accomplished.  The fact that the new ownership decided to not only keep the name, but also the spirit of Schroeder's should be praised, not chastised.  Being a San Francisco native I've see a lot of change, some for the better, some not so much, but kudos to the entire Schroeder's team! 

As for the staff, they were warm and accommodating even while being extremely busy and having to adjust to all that comes with opening a new restaurant.  I've never understood how people can review a place during the first few weeks and expect perfection.  If you have ever been to a new restaurant or worked in the industry, you should know this.  

As for the beer and cocktail menu, it's extensive, well rounded and not overpriced, especially for San Francisco!  When I feel like a $1 PBR I go to my favorite Tenderloin dive.  If I want something special, I will come to Schroeder's. 

As for the food, it was some of the best and unique German food I've ever had.  Balancing tradition while trying to accommodate "new" tastes is tough.  I enjoyed the old menu but it was extremely outdated and tired.  The new menu is fantastic and a testament to their California born chef of German immigrant parents.  I've been several times now and haven't been disappointed.  My favorites were the Spätzle (an amazing new take on a classic dish), Vesperplatte, Potato Pancakes, Wiener Schnitzel, Bratwurst and one of the most unique burgers in town, the Kraut Burger!  

I'm happy to say that Schroeder's is alive and well and for someone who has been a patron for 20+ years, I will be coming back for many more!
author: Cary D.

description:
I'd never been to this place, even before it reopened again. My friend suggested this place for the location, seeing as we planned to meet on a monday night. We couldn't get seated until our party was present, so there was a lot of waiting at the crowded bar area. 

Beers are delicious! Soooo many great tasting beers that we had to get a few boots. WHY NOT? 

Food is pretty ok, really pricey though. The portions for appetizers and charcuterie are small for sharing that you'd need to get multiple orders. 

Service is really good despite the busy-ness of the place. They even served us our own cake (with a cake fee of $4/person), which we thought they wouldn't. 

Atmosphere is great for groups. They have long tables that seats plenty. Overall, we had such a great time but the price we paid for our entire meals (mediocre tasting, nothing too memorable) and drinks was just sooo much.
author: Faye F.

description:
If you like German/Austrian/Polish style fair this place crushes it  I had the weissewurst...my grandfather would have been impressed (he was Swiss).  The sauerkraut was as good as sauerkraut gets.  I did not have the schnitzel, but it looked very good.  As did the sauerbraten.  They also have spaetzle.  

There was no singing or standing on the tables but definitely captures a bavarian bier hall vib...with an american twist (TV's on the walls).  All kidding aside the the TV's make it a great place to watch any sporting event (we were there for the Warriors destruction of Houston).  I would come here again just for the food.

Great selection of German beer on tap served in a stein or boot.  

Stick to the German food, you can have a hipster serve you those tater tots, grilled cheese on whitebread and wings at a thousand other places.
author: Mark M.

description: I was in town last weekend and got the pleasure of stopping into Schroeders! I loved their specialty drink that had champagne and gin in it--light and very tasty! My absolute FAVORITE was their pretzel knots--the mustard to dip them in was AMAZING!! I loved their potato pancakes but the smothered tots are out of this world! Everything we ordered exceeded my expectations and then some! It was all so delicious and I wish I  had restaurant like Schroeders by me back home.
author: Jess G.

description: One would expect that dining in a place like this surrounded by beautifully designed furniture and warm-toned light fixtures would cost an arm and a leg as well as being in the Financial district, however prices are surprisingly reasonable. The staff seems pretty knowledgeable about the drinks and very approachable too. They even let and friends are I into the pub 15 mins before closing. The beers were among some of the best I've ever had and the food looked amazing. Too bad for us that the kitchen was already closed. I will absolutely return next time when I'm San Francisco again.
author: Shawn L.

description: Great place to watch the World Cup! Awesome atmosphere!
author: Heloise D.

description:
Really awesome beer hall, you need to check it out. Especially if you're a Harry Potter fan... you'll go nuts. It looks like the Hogwarts dining hall.

Their staff are really helpful and friendly. Quick to serve and clean. Awesome! The restrooms are as clean as I would think heaven is. 

Drinks are strong and plentiful. They may be on the expensive side but you get what you pay for. A really nice ambiance/environment, its financial district location, and quality food/drinks/service!
author: Ricky N.

description:
Schroeder's is awesome! This is my new go-to restaurant + bar.

The food is terrific - don't miss starting out with the beets, spatzle, and brussel sprouts... and not necessarily in that order. The bratwurst and wiener schnitnel are delicious also, just save room for the black forest chocolate for dessert! The dishes sound familiar but are every bit new and exciting... much like the rest of the space.

Nothing beats a Derby Radler from the bar menu, though from the looks of the beer garden... a boot of beer gives it a good run for it's money!  I'm pretty sure it's the perfect compliment to a World Cup match and a prerequisite of all German patrons.

Big fan of the new renovation, it kept the character of the old Schroeder's and updated the rest to be the full-service beer garden it always wanted to be. The staff are super helpful and knowledgeable of the menu, trust their recommendations. My favorite is their new wardrobe - it's equal parts refined + classic, in homage to the original crisp white shirt + black-tie wait staff back in the day, but are newly casual complimented by the pinstripe aprons or suspenders over plaid to add just the right amount of modern California.

Super stylish all around. Time to reacquaint yourself with an SF classic!
author: Darren R.

description:
This is another in the new wave of German restaurants in San Francisco that prove how innovative and tasty German food can be. We ordered way too much food, mostly because it all sounded good, smelled, good and looked good. We weren't disappointed by anything. Duck Brest pastrami is amazing. Traditional sauerbraten was a revelation. And even the burger was special.

It's loud and fun and lively around the bar when you walk in, but gets steadily quieter as you go back in the room. Get a table in the back if you want to talk, or sit at the long communal tables in the middle for fun and football watching.
author: Rick H.

description:
Love it!  

I had dinner and drinks at the *New* Schroeder's the other night with a buddy after work and I was absolutely blown away. The drinks were excellent and the food was fantastic. I was also a big fan of the hand-selected beer list.  

The waitstaff was friendly, knowledgable and educated and the scene was great. The place was crowded, but in a good way, as we were still able to conduct a conversation and catch up. 

This is my new go-to in the Financial District!
author: Morgan B.

description:
We intended to watch the world cup finals there....
two friends inquired on tables, but it was said "no reservations" and "first come first serve", so after waiting one hour to get in, just to find that the best tables with a good view to the screen are all booked up, so much for the above statement.... 
well, the world cup is no over, so i cannot speak for the rest as we ended up watching somewhere else....
author: Matthias H.

description: Went there for lunch witj colleague.  She got schnitzel and liver sandwich and l got bruwts plate.  Shd couldn't find liver in her sandwich but rather than that she liked her meal.  I ghonk that $16 for one bruwts is a little bit too pricey during luch time but it was well made dish.  The place is very loud.  It was hard to carry on a conversation.
author: Maryanna K.

description:
When I first heard that Schroeder's was being "remodeled," my fear was that the place would lose all of its great, old German character. I was pleasantly surprised that the space actually re-images the look of a typical, Bavarian beerhall: long tables, big hoop chandeliers, etc.--all with a very clean/modern approach. The long tables are cleverly transformed into smaller seating spaces by the use of planters that turns a table for 12 into a table for two within seconds. They've done a nice job of maintaining the old German-style paintings, which were a great source of charm. And I'll admit the old Schroeder's was getting a little grungy; the new place is clean and very stylish. So as far as the remodel: good job!

Now, onto the topic of food. I was very pleased to see that many of the old favorites were still on the menu. I ordered the Bratwurst and sauerkraut with great anticipation! However, the Bratwurst was on a hotdog roll and the sauerkraut (on top of the Wurst) was cold--ala a brat like you'd get at AT&T Park. I'll admit that it was good, the brat was perfectly cooked! But like the re-model, the German cuisine is "re-imagined," bearing little resemblance to the original. The potato salad was also very nice, but nothing of the sort ever left a kitchen in Munich.  No salt or pepper on the table.  The condiment on the plate was ketchup (with a BRAT?!)

Finally, unlike my fond memories of the old Schroeder's, not a soul speaks German anymore; which is too bad.  But the service is fast(er) and friendl(ier), so that's a good upgrade.  

So there are pluses and minuses. I'd go back, but I'd love to see just a few of the old menu standards done in the authentic style.
author: Bill M.

description:
Great beers from Germany we had two dunkels, both very good with malty flavor. 

The service is excellent.

The food is all expertly cooked too - but didn't find Murnchen sausages on the menu, hence 4 stars.

The bratwurst was good, and the duck breast was delicious and filling. The almond cake was nice.
author: Sergey F.

description: Overall disappointed by food and service, while the beers were very good. We ordered 3 beer selections and the smothered tots, which we really liked. I thought the tots were a good serving and had good flavors, though slightly overpriced. After the good tot experience, we decided to go with the chicken schnitzel sliders (3 for $12). We were instantly disappointed. Chicken was thin and overcooked, with a miniscule helping of coleslaw inside. They were tiny, but ok, we are in the FiDi, I get it. Had they been tasty I would have forgiven the size. Dry, overcooked and a total rip off! A terrible follow up to the tots that were so enjoyed! Can you really go wrong with tots though, we asked ourselves. Yes, yes you can. At this point, we sought to settle up with our server nowhere in sight. We asked for the check 2x from a busser. A new server took over our table, finally bringing the check and asking us to look it over to make sure it was ours. Note to floor management: If you need to have a server take over tables, everything should be properly communicated and service should never go to the wayside. Note to chef: revisit your recipe or do a better job of quality control with your line cooks.
author: Luca T.

description: We went for dinner with a group of six. It was my second time at the restaurant and probably my worst dining experience in years in San Francisco. The spätzle was visibly burnt. We sent it back only for them to bring out a replacement that was so salty we could barely finish it. The tots were bland and unoriginal. The service was unfriendly and absent. The only redeeming factor was the beer.
author: Chris D.

description: Don't go here if you're looking for authentic German food.  Newer ownership.  Their schnitzel was pounded so thin I just tasted breadcrumbs and it had some weird mushrooms on top.  Very expensive for what you actually get!  I miss the old Schroeder's!!
author: Dannie S.

description: I won't be back. Two stars because the music was fun and venue attractive. I ordered the saurbraten.  Nice tender piece of meat, but it was so over salted that that was the only thing I could taste. I believe I was given a dumpling. The texture was odd and it was utterly tasteless. The beer was good. Be sure to read the tiny font print at the end of menu. If you ASK for bread you will get it. Although our waitress had a big friendly smile on her face, she wasn't friendly and pushed a little to hard about ordering appetizers. For German music, it's a go. For good German food, find another place. By the way, my friend didn't even eat her order. Don't expect good conversation, noise level way too high.
author: Susan C.

description: Good service and atmosphere. We had the saurborten which was a little dry, but the cabbage was awesome and dumplings, though not authentic, were delicous. Great wine selection and a fun atmosphere
author: Austin E.

description: I think this place is beautiful. Ample seating, very professional waitstaff. I went planning to carb-load: potato pancakes (ok, minimalist, but served with a really good salad), pretzels (disappointing) and spaetzel (fine, nothing to get excited about). My colleague got a frankfurter, which looked gross to me, but which she enjoyed. Mustard was a highlight. I'm grateful for German food in a good location, though it's not the best you'll ever have.
author: Frankie I.

description:
Fun spot. Good service. The communal seating is nice cuz you can peer over at your neighbor and see what looks the best ;) 

We all enjoyed our meal, the pickeled veggies were yummy, the pretzels were good and our meals too. The desert was nice and our server was friendly and efficient.
author: Erika E.

description:
Dined here for lunch and it was pretty good. Definitely different from the old Schroder's. The ambiance was nice, the lighting is 10x better than it was before and the service was far better as well. We were a fairly large group (8 ppl) and we ordered a bunch of different things; some of us shared. 

* Salmon flatbread - salmon was way too salty and so many of us had a bite and tossed aside. 
* Spatzel - pretty damn delish. Everyone really enjoyed and one person even said that she'd come back just for the Spatzel as her main dish!
* Potato Pancakes - they were also very good. They were unique and flavorful.
* Bratwurst - also very yummy. I especially enjoyed the spicy mustard.
* Caraway Fries - I ate almost half the bowl myself. I enjoyed them and their dipping sauces (ketch-up and aioli).
* Kraut Burger - I didn't try this, but it really looked good - maybe next time I'll give it a go!

So the food was pretty good and the service was great (but a bit over the top with the fork replacements, etc.) It kind of felt like the server never left the table because she was constantly putting new forks out, taking our used forks, dropping off plates, picking up plates, etc. It's not a bad thing, just a bit over the top.
author: Noneya B.

description:
We had some good draught beer, the pork belly, potato pancakes  and spaetzle to start. The potato pancakes were too fried,greasy and an odd topping.    The spaetzle was our favorite.  The pork belly delicious.  It took about 40 minutes from time we sat down until this first food arrived.

For main course, the weiner schnitzel was plain and a bit dry.  The bratwurst was okay.

It's really a three and one half stars.....it's pretty pricey for what you get.

I enjoyed the crepe dessert with berries and cream.

We loved the interior. It's pretty cool.  I would definetely come here for a beer and appetizers and watch a game,
author: Foodlover B.

description:
We visited the revamped Schroeder's about a month after its re-opening and was impressed!  The space is contemporary, and yet has maintained the essence of the a German been hall.  Great ambiance with good light and an updated vibe.  I especially like the placement of beer steins in lighted cupboards throughout the restaurant.

We had a great waiter who shared the menu with us and had good suggestions.  My favorite item on the menu that visit was the Vesperplatte, which included homemade mustards and pickles.  Yum.  I also enjoyed the artichokes with the garbanzo beans.  It was delicious.

We will definitely be back.
author: Ann F.

description:
The renovation of Schroeder's is a welcome addition to downtown.  

The bar is always packed and lively.  Great beers, great cocktails.  Bar menu is good and during big sports events, they bring in more screens to accommodate spectators.  Great vibe for happy hour and evenings.  

The restaurant is a great place for dinner, too.  The chef has done a great job taking traditional German food and making it more modern and unique.  It's a bit quieter in the back restaurant, so good for dining with any party size.  It's fine for 2-4 but also a great place to go for groups.  Definitely worth checking out for your next group dinner. 

The food is fantastic, the service is top notch.  The staff is attentive and want to make sure you enjoy your experience.  Grab some friends, start at the bar for a few drinks but be sure to eat dinner, too!
author: Lija H.

description:
Schroeder's is a Financial District institution, but it had grown tired.  The renovations were much needed and added life to a incredibly well located downtown bar.

This is a great place to grab a happy hour drink or a unique bite to eat.  Highly recommended!
author: Nick P.

description: Ate here for late lunch snack. Food was good and beer was better. I think this place is a good beer drinking place. The long tables and matching benches reminds me of the Munich beer halls. No beer mug lockers for the regulars. Not sure if I will bring our German friends here. This is one of the bigger German restaurants around here and not sure if they want to eat German.
author: Clifford W.

description: My husband and I had so much fun at the spot when we visited for the Yelp party. We danced with each other to the German music played by an authentic band. Good memories
author: Kellianne R.

description: Held our customer appreciation party here - awesome service, yummy food (delicious desserts), and great drinks served right.
author: Matt H.

description:
LOVE the new Schroeders. So much of the old appeal, but more up to date. The beer was *awesome*, cocktails were amazing, and food...woah. A few weeks later, and I can still taste the corn spaetzle, and two of the desserts. 

Super friendly staff, and tons of fun. Good food, great environment and not stuffy at all. Great for happy hours, dinners, or just drinks/dessert.
author: Mindy W.

description: Venue is outstanding, beer selection is good, service is pretty good, and food is alright.  The food presentation was great, but the pretzels and pickled veggies were underwhelming - I wanted more body to the pretzels and less salt, and the cucumbers in the pickles veggies were funky in a not good way.  Mains were both decent, though not outstanding.  Frankly, I think the other german places in SF are better for food, though the venue here is fantastic.
author: Justin D.

description:
This place is a gem.   Went there on a Saturday night, and it was busy but not crowded which is perfect.  Has the beer hall style community bench seating that seems to be showing up a bit more lately which I'm not a fan of, but the decor is very nice.  Upscale without being crazy fancy.   Several large screen TV's for sporting events. 

But the food, oh the food.  Only been here the once but everything was spot on from the beet salad to the schnitzel, the sauerbrauten, and all that accompanies those dishes.  And the strudel was crazy flaky and good.  I'm more of a meat and potatoes man than desert, but seriously, try the strudel.  

Looking forward to finding myself in the neighborhood again so I can try a few more things on their menu.
author: Samhain M.

description: Been here few times, great place for beer and live music and dance. If you are a fan of Oktoberfest, this is it! Good for groups or celebrations. The waiter/ess are absolute professional, even the musicians are friendly. Would not recommend for ppl. look for quiet dining, the place get pretty loud.
author: Noah W.

description: Beer is great here although it a little pricey. The Reuben was one of the worst Reuben's I have had...greasy and salty. The pretzels are great though I can eat a ton of those. Great renovations...all and all, it's a fun place to grab after work drinks but for anything really German, go to Leopolds or Suppenkuche.
author: Alan H.

description:
Overpriced as all hell, and the portion size is tiny.  Their Kraut Burger was quite small, and for $15 I expect more than a bland burger and some tater tots.  $23 for a pair of sausages with some fixings is a bit much as well.  Throw in some beer and you'll be spending a heck of a lot.

The atmosphere is certainly nice, and the whole place looks good... but I definitely wouldn't go for the food.
author: Noah R.

description: Love this place! Awesome German beer hall with really great food. Really fun for watching a game or going out with a group. The interior of the restaurant is really cool!
author: E F.

description: It's a nice place for after work Happy Hour drinks and all.  I just personally don't prefer the noise volume.  If you're not having a private party, you all have to jam pack together with strangers on one long table.  Good luck having a conversation here with a large group, you'd better hope the people you're with can talk loud!  I DO love their slider burgers and tater tots - these are two of the reasons I actually come back to visit.
author: Iysslene M.

description: Amazing!!! Order the Ellie Irish Carpool Bomb!! Best drink ever! 10 steps above the typical Irish car bomb :)
author: Abigail B.

description: Great German beer hall with an excellent variety of beer in addition to having great sausages as well. Great vibe, feel, beers and food so can't go wrong with this place. I'm giving it three stars for one reason - I spent approx. $300 (food and drinks) here on my tab alone with a group of friends. One of my tabs came out to $45 and I left a $5 tip before keeping my copy of the receipt. The bar charged me $95 on my credit card when I checked a few days later. I always keep my receipts for a few days for this exact reason and called the bar to have them explain what happened. The manager promised she'd look into this and get back to me and she did the next day. She confirmed that the server had mistakenly put in $50 as the tip instead of the $5 and she was going to get written up for this. The manager apologized etc and said she will be reversing the entire tip amount. I told her that if I was in her position, I would have offered to reverse out the entire $95 tab but that's just me. She acknowledged and dodged it by saying I should let her know whenever I'm planning on coming in next and she would get me a round of drinks on the house. I told her that's I would never tell her when I'm coming next just to get free drinks and then asked her to give me the owners contact info as I'd like them to be aware as well of the incident. She gave the info to me and then called me back to say that she would be refunding the entire tab. Overall, great great place but definitely stained my experience with this whole incident followed by my interaction with the manager.
author: Kabir S.

description: This place has horrible service. For a place that markets itself as a beer hall, you would assume that they would, at least, be proficient at serving beer. I went up to the bar to order because the server failed to serve me in the thirty minutes that I waited. There were three bartenders working [(I use the term "bartender" loosely) hell, I use the term "working" loosely].  One bartender was pouring beer and seemed to actually be working. The second couldn't seem to decide if he was a barback or a bartender today, and failed in doing either. The third seemed to be the only one working. Another twenty minutes later I was finally served my beer. I've now been here for an hour and have decided that I'll finish my beer and never come back. STAY AWAY!
author: Tyler S.

description: Great beer, duh.  Horrible food.  Really horrible.  They've attempted to make California Fusion German food.  Really???  They should have just stuck with the traditional German recipes and presentation or switched complete over to California cuisine.  My opinion.
author: Alan M.

description: I always enjoy myself here. Fun environment. Excellent beers. The service is a bit slow sometimes (two people serving drinks behind the bar on Friday?) but if you're patient they'll get to you. Overall, it's a great place to go.
author: Seth G.

description:
This was our first trip to the remodeled Schroder's. It's a different thing now but I definitely like it. From a hardcore German dive it turned into a sleek restaurant with food I'd call German inspired.

The pretzels knots were great as was the carrot salad. Beware , though, there are three pretzel knots, a lot of food. My wife liked the beets salad a little less. My bratwurst really turned out to be some kind of huge hot dog. This must have an interim stage of German brats evolving into hot dogs, circa 1890.

Apple strudel was nice.

Service was great, just the original seating was a bit bumpy. Lots of cleaning up table, replacing dishes etc. 

Nice place, just not authentic German food. For that Suppenkueche is a better place.
author: Heiko L.

description: First time coming here for a happy hour with co-workers. It was a nice place...fun atmosphere...and good drinks. I had 2 whiskey sours. The only thing was that waitress was a little short with us and if we didn't have the order she would move on. Not sure of that's the norm but not the best impression. Didn't have any food...but will be back to try it. I guess it's worth another shot.
author: Jacob H.

description: BOOOOO!!!! This was one of the great SF bar/restaurants, but the renovations on both the interior and the menu have take all the soul out of this place. I can't express the disappointment I have with what they have done here. Now just another trendy interior and menu. Food was trendy (wow tator tots, can't get those at every other place in the city phhhf) but the ambiance was just terrible.
author: Matty S.

description: Don't waste your time or your money.  This once great authentic German restaurant is now anything but.  We ordered a traditional German potato appetizer and they brought us out a bowl of FROZEN OREIDA TATER TOTS.  We are German and have been to Germany.  Never have I once been served this.  We are never coming back here again.  The new owners have ruined this once great restaurant.  We will continue to give our business to Teske's Germania in San Jose.
author: Diane T.

description:
Many people will come across Schroeder's for the first time and may find a serviceable spot for food and drinks, but those of us who remember the Old Schroeder's will find a poor imitation in its place. We all knew it would change in little ways: updated interior, nicer bathrooms, more light (cringe). Did they have to change the food? Did the lunch menu HAVE to strike all semblance of traditional German food in favor of a German-influenced California small plate menu?

Had the Kraut Burger, ridiculous bun and all. Nothing tasted of the Schroeder's I used to enjoy with my dad. Another in our party ordered the bratwurst and enjoyed it, though we agreed it was sparse without any of the usual sides. The beer menu has been lobotomized, too, and the unique tap handles on the bar were removed (befitting the new, sanitized style). 

The small (maybe imperfect) things that made Schroeder's unique are gone and I don't think I can bring myself to keep visiting this Zombie Schroeder's.
author: P D.

description: The restaurant has a bar area in front and a large dining area in the back. We came here for dinner and there was no problem getting a seat on the weekend. The appetizers were very good. We got the spatzle, pig head and crab. However, my main entree wiener schnitzel was below average. Dry and over-fried and lacking in taste. This was disappointing as I've had much better at other German restaurants. The meal was expensive too. The beers and selection were good.
author: Ali F.

description:
It was the first time I went to Schroeder's and I did enjoy it. What I liked is the long tables that people share. Second I liked the relaxed and friendly atmosphere. Third that it is very large with very nice furniture and paintings. Its almost like in Germany.

They have a good selection of beers, the food I thought could be better. Better choices and better quality and also more authentic German. But overall its a great place with a long tradition. I would go again when I have visitors.
author: Guido W.

description:
Visited before and post remodeling/change in management a few times. The interior is now very cool, they really transformed the place. The menu is now much shorter though still has that European kick. 
The service: always good, no issues here. 
The food: I would advise to stay away from sausage plates. The curry one is totally horrendous! Stick with schnitzels - they are good, though a couple of times were under seasoned and there is no salt/pepper on the table. Pretzels are a MUST to try. Really tasty with or without dipping sauces.
I give the place 3-start rating really for the prices. It's seriously overpriced in my opinion comparing to other lunch places in the area.
author: Skate K.

description:
The new schroeders is annoying. A suited gate keeper stops you at the door to ask for the name of your party. He is surprised to hear you just stopped by for a beer. Well then, wait on the sidewalk for 3-5 min. Eventually another (smaller) suit appears from within to guide you to a spot at the bar where 10 other people are crowding in. You mention that friends will be joining you, and the little suit says your friends have to wait on the sidewalk until other people leave. 

Fine. So you turn to order a beer, only to find that the beer list is in a little red book being held hostage by the bartender.  By the time you get a beer in hand, the little suit stops by to ask you to move to another spot  further away from the bar. No thanks. Then your friends show up (yay!) and the little suit comes back and asks if you want to check your bags. No, we're fine. How annoying, you say to your friend. Why can't they just leave us alone? The little suit overhears and comes back to inform you about the fire Marshall and maximum occupancy etc etc. 

Yes, those requirements apply to every restaurant in the country. But somehow Schroeders has managed to make the fire Marshall intrude into your happy hour experience,
author: marc c.

description:
Don't go here. Go to suppenkuche!!!

One of the worst dining experiences of my life. I can't remember ever being so disappointed. Looked forward to the reopen ing  for months. 

The food- they just don't get it. It's not German food. It's wrong. It's small portions that are absurdly exorbitant. My friend is pregnant and the chef refused to cook her burger anything other than rare. She got 3 burgers each rarer than the one before. 

They were out of over half the beers. 

The waitress was horrible. She had a terrible attitude. 

This is an F- experience. GO TO SUPPENKUCHE !!!! It is 1000% better.
author: Buren R.

description: Very cool German bar/restaurant. Loved the ambiance. Would be a great place to gather a large group of friends or coworker. Big long tables.Tons of German beer. Food menu is minimal, mostly just small plates. But great place overall.
author: Ruthie G.

description: Here's a first.  I had a 1:30 reservation on Thursday before Christmas. Ashley from Schroeders calls me to confirm reservation, then calls back an hour later and says they had a restaurant buy out so latest they could seat us was 12pm.  Very dissapointed and no real apology.  No professional.
author: Fritz H.

description:
I have NEVER felt so unwelcome!  Take your business elsewhere.  New management is VERY RUDE.  The way my group from work was treated last night is inexcusable!

We were not a rowdy bunch.  I was sober and we did not deserve the treatment we received.  Im not even kidding, our waitress threatened to kick us out three times for ridiculous reasons:

1. After ordering a round of appetizers and drinks, we would have to order more food or we would have to leave.  
2. We had 4 people come over to chat for 5 minutes. Our waitress quickly reprimanded us that if our party was larger than the reservation, we would have to leave (mind you, the rest of the dining room was completely empty!)

3. After our senior manager graciously paid our bill and excused herself, our waitress made it very clear that we would have to leave as soon as our food and drinks were finished.

The bar was full but the dining room was still empty when we left at 7:00PM, so why all the craziness in asking us to leave so many times!!

If I want a good happy hour, I'll stick with Royal Exchange across the street.  If I want German food, I'll stick with Suppenkuche.
author: C S.

description:
Great social atmosphere. Great service. Great drinks. Great food. See where I'm going with this? It's great. Obviously people have different experiences and they do have a huge staff and yada yada yada, but each time I've been, nothing but solid customer service, delicious food, and overall just a fantastic lasting impression.

Let me break it down for you.
1)Solid customer service: very attentive even in the bar area and ready with great suggestions, but most of all flexible and accommodating. Example, my buddy and I asked to move around the bench area about three times because we wanted to get better views of the game as the tables cleared and Nicole our waitress was totally cool with it. Also, anything us drunk dummies needed she was there without even a request. We were sand bagging a little as we tried to finish our boots, OUR TWO LITER BOOTS mind you, and she comes around with two glass of water, "seems like you guys are slowing down. This'll help." She called us out! And I like it...especially because I did need that water. 

2)delicious food: I have experienced both the bar and the restaurant areas, and both have superb menus. For dinner I've had the pork and it is to die for in that when we we perusing the menu, my buddy Jack and I, and we liked a lot that was on deck but we both ended up with the pork. It just sounded so good. No regrets whatsoever. It was very flavorful and not too tough, great sides that really refresh the pallet rather than just sitting there, as in the asparagus and quinoa actually contribute to the meal's taste. Also I hate quinoa if that tells you how good this meal is. Meanwhile in the bar section, to compliment our boots Lawrence and I finish off our terrible weeks with smothered fries and by the sound of it one would expect heavy and loaded. However, had great taste without being too cumbersome which one can run into a lot. Still had the grease that makes bar food delicious without being grease with a side of fries. And drinks? Cocktails are delicious, our waiter Yuri had great  suggestions. I wish I remembered the names of the drinks but that goes to show how good they are right? And of course get yourself a boot. It's just glorious, enough said.

3)lasting impression: decor is great, I love the lighting. The inside is like buckshot and zeitgeist but less divey, and I love dive bars but the Schroeders experience is all encapsulating as in it's a full experience-food, service, and ambiance compliments one another. The staff is engaging and ready to strike up a conversation whether or not you are their priority. We had such a good time that we were able to chat it up with a whole slew of random people we just met.We actually ended up leaving shroeders with these people we met there and found ourselves drinking with them in the Castro dancing our drunken booties away. And most of all, the people I've talked to who work there seem to genuinely enjoy their jobs. When they speak about what they do and how they carry themselves, very down to earth and just wear this glow that makes you jealous like their in the cool crowd. I've spoken with Cassie, Mel, Diego, Cleveland, Dallas and Kori, and they make me want to come back and send people to Schroeder's. 

Sooooooo to summarize, if you couldn't tell, I love Schroeder's. I highly recommend it. One could say it's pricey but this is what I'd say to that person, "you definitely get what you pay for aaaaaaaand welcome to San Francisco honey." you're not just paying for food or drinks or service or whatever, you're paying for an experience.
author: Rajiva U.

description: First time going back since the change. We used to order the sausage platter and it was epic, great variety of sausages and even had a few small pork chops! This time we get it and it's 3 sausages cut up into threes and one slice of head cheese. And it cost us $34.00!!! Are you kidding me I was so pissed off. I asked my waiter what happened and he told me it under new ownership. I thought it was just a remodel but that explains alot. We also ordered the kraut burger and I joked with my friends it was going to be small like a white castle. Sure enough it was about the size of a slider and it cost $15.00 place is a joke. I will never go back I need to find another German spot I give it 2 thumbs down and it hurts me to say this as I used to love this place.
author: Jerome L.

description:
Well, if somebody decides to create a Yelp account just to write this ONE review, it was either a overwhelmingly good experience or just horrible - in my case the latter is true!

So yesterday, as some of you may know, Germany played their second game of the World Cup against Ghana. This is a top game on a Saturday noon (kick-off at 12) and Schroeder's did everything wrong which they possibly could! 

First of all: kick off at 12 and at 11:50 there is a huge (!!!) line in front of the restaurant and still enough space inside. Should that make you think about whether you handle the door correctly? Yes, it should. Should the fact that people are nervously starting to pile up at the entrance and asking you why they have to stand in line for 40 minutes make you think? Yes, it should. The point I want to make is pretty simple. If somebody decides to go public viewing of soccer, they do not need their seperate table, a waitress that bring's them to that table and an arrogant cuff-linked manager at the door (don't get me wrong, I wear cuff-links on a daily basis, but that was the perfect synonym of how incredibly arrogant and unfriendly he was). You know what they need? Beer, atmosphere, the feeling of community & unity and most certainly not missing the freaking national anthem. And now comes the most ridicolous part for everybody that has not been there: THEY HAVE COMMUNITY TABLES!!!!! To sum that up: you seriously make your (anxiously waiting for the game) customers wait in line for over 30 minutes, to place them seperatly at the same community tables?!? I am sorry, I had to stop typing on my small iPhone screen for a second because I had to laugh so hard! Basically, you artificially increased the average wait time in order to achieve: nothing! How about that? Open your freaking doors, let the people sit wherever they want, and let them be happy. And please don't come me with excuses like "well, the waitresses need that in order to bill correctly". If you really think that way, check out your competition (Leopolds), they just got the place packed for the first Germany game and everything worked out just fine!

This leads me to my second point! I do not know where you got your management education, but I would get myself a lawyer if I were you and sue the last cent out of regarding institute because they clearly failed in performing their duty. Or where you drunk on your (admittingly delicious) beer when you set up the staffing schedule? In numbers: roughly 50-70 persons in front of the bar, the rest of the (huge) restaurant packed, the knowledge about the game (I mean you broadcast it), and you place two(!!!!!!!) barkeepers???!!!!! That must be a joke. Drinks took ages, since one of them was exclusively preparing drinks for the seated service, and the guy that serviced the crowd at the bar should either think about a career change or management should only staff him when he received proper training. I mean not knowing the beer price, taking (I timed it because I was laughing my butt off by this whole mess) 38 seconds to place ONE order in your micros register (a normal bartender takes a maximum of 5 seconds), and not being able to deliver a Hefeweizen with the proper layer of foam on top?! Seriously... And don't Arthur with a German (me) about how you pronounce Hefeweizen! You will clearly lose.

All in all, I have been to a lot of places in SF and the world to have food/drinks/watch soccer, and I thought I had seen incompetency at every level, but congratulations to the lads at Schroeder's yesterday, they put applied mismanagement to a whole new level! What s gigantic fail and a mess! At least the crowd at the bar had a lot of fun laughing at that, and the consensus was exactly the same: how can you possibly mess things up on so many different levels? I do not have the answer. Ah yes, what I almost forgot: 9 dollars for .5 beer?! Come on, that is even for SF a whole new level....

Sunmary: if I feel like entertaining myself with watching management fail, I will definetly come back!
author: Luca E.

description: Bad 'German' food and unfriendly service. They don't seat you, so as a group of 6 we had to linger over tables to swoop in to get seats together. The service was unfriendly bordering on rude, the food took a long time to come out, and when it did, simple dishes like spätzle were so burned we had to send it back. The second dish of spätzle was so salty it just tasted like popcorn. Worst German food I've ever had. My husband's family is German (aunt owns and operates restaurants and breweries in Germany) and this food is terrible. Go to Suppenkuche in Hayes Valley if you want more authentic and delicious food and better service.
author: Leah S.

description: Really top-notch eats, and a great alcohol selection to boot! Had some bratwurst, spaetzle, and dessert, and it was all fantastic.
author: Rajesh S.

description: I wanted to like the new Schroeder's. I really did. And after a peak inside I was hopeful that they really kept the spirit of the old place. After actually stopping in for a drink, I realize all they did was leave up some of the old paintings. Everything else smacks of identity crisis. Ultra modern (and ultra flimsy -- two were broken! -- and uncomfortable) bar stools and and hip entrance stand combined with a California menu with a German twist (as opposed to the old German menu) left me cold. And the $14 tab for ONE draft beer was icing on the cake. Too bad. This was a charming, German beer hall. So...if you're looking for a modern, financial district spot to take a client or colleague, this is a spot to consider. If you want a German beer hall, look elsewhere.
author: Joel T.

description: Very disappointing!! The food was over priced and had no flavor.  The atmosphere was very nice and they did have a nice beer selection. But you can get great beer lots of places.   Will not wast my time or money to return. We really miss the previous owner we  patronize the restaurant  for over 23 years even drove two hours from home. Will be missed!
author: Brenda M.

description: I had not come here since the remodel and thought I was coming to the Schroders that i have been coming to for almost a decade.  That is NOT the case.  They have kept the name, but almost nothing else of the old place.  What was a quint old world place with a great menu is now a strange hybrid of trendy cooking school kitchen and loud techno music.  It really isnt a bar any more but rather an establishment trying to be an upscale restaurant with a bar inside. The menu has shrunk to a modest handful of very expensive disappointing items.  The staff are over dressed and have an off-putting attitude.  I am not sure what they are doing as despite an army of people standing around, actually obtaining a beer is hard to do.  With many other options serving better food at a much more reasonable price.  I cant fathom a reason to come to the new Schroders.
author: Derek n.

description:
Yes, they did a decent job renovating the place, however the important "substance" of the place is gone: just look at the "drink menu". 
Why would "German" pub not have all the classics of the German beers? 
Where did all the good Czech beer go? 
Why does it take 10 minutes to get a beer in front of me?
But hell, now they have Anchor Steam and Trumer Pils and some banana-like joke ... Well, I can have those "parodies on beer" in any other restaurant around.

It feels like the place turned into a "German theme park" rather then an authentic German pub. Yes, you walk in and it looks like a German pub, but very soon you will find out that it is very fake impression ....
author: A B.

description:
Not that the old Schroeder's was bad, but there was a reason it had to be made over...and like a phoenix rising from the ashes, we now have greatness.

How to describe the new Schroeder's? 
Social. Friendly. Hip. Fun. Warm environment. Excellent service. Delicious treats. 

The new decor is spot on. Classy. Clean, modern. The metal light fixtures are great and the natural light coming through the windows now is outstanding.

Sat at one of the communal tables and was a blast. That is what a beer hall should be - the chance to talk to others and be social. Such a good vibe, it was easy to engage with people around us and add to our fun. Don't go here if you want solitude. This is as social as it gets and the seating makes it very relaxed. 

The service, on a very busy night where people were being turned away at the door, was absolutely perfect. The waiter came by at just the right moment each time to get our next beer order and have it as we were finishing the last. With how busy it was, we could not believe how he did not miss a step.

Congratulations to the new Schroeder's. This is a place that my colleagues and friends are already targeting as a new favorite spot to go. Well done and thanks for keeping the right amount of the old, but making it a modern place that I want to return to.

It might be because I am a bit older than I was in 2000 when I first went there, but the updated Schroeder's is a place where I am looking forward to spending time,
author: Sean M.

description:
Oh Schroeder's... Schroeder's... the good times I shared here with my colleagues before the remodeling... happy hour priced beers, decent food, tongue-in-cheeks bartenders...

Came in here Friday (5th day of re-opening) and what a change it was.
*1 star for the seating arrangement--nice long wooden tables, floors, etc. 
Dim lighting was okay
*1 star for coat/bag hangers along the wall
*1 star for having some pretty tasty German beers

Why is it just A-OK?
Well, let me put it this way--
2 beers + 1 plate of fries (which were average at best) = $40!!!

$40 covered many, few quick rounds for my colleagues and some tasty beer food too at Schroeder's v1.0! Needless to say, after I paid the tab (yes, I am a woman who pays and treats), my remaining colleagues snuck in (they were at "full capacity"). One look at the menu prices and we meandered off across the street to Harrington's where we felt like home again.

Perhaps we're being cheap but heck, not everyone in this city took place in some IPO!

I still wanted to give it 2.5 stars but my bf joined later and we squeezed back into Schroeder's because I wanted to show him the place. He's quite a beer nerd and was very happy with the beer I got him. Happy tummy! Happy honey!

Yes, I paid again. But I ain't no sugar momma!
author: Aggie Z.

description: I hadn't been to Schroeder's in many years. A buddy and I were in the area so we stop by for a beer and brat. Wow, we didn't know about the renovation and almost walked by it. First thing that came to mind was 'sad' when I saw what they did to a classic beer hall. It looks like Gordon Ramsey threw up all over it. 2 brats, 2 beers with tip, $61. We will not be returning...
author: M. D.

description:
Had not been to this place in awhile. Last time was when it was sort of run down and we would go there to drink boots of beer. Heard the place got new owners and a facelift. 
     Went for drinks and then decided to stay for dinner as well. I was pleased with the whole experience. The interior is much improved. Hardwood floors and more modern feeling decor. But they still have tons of beer and large vessels to drink from should you feel the need. The bar looks the same but now lots of tvs. 
     I noticed they have a monster tv screen they can lower down. I am thinking this place may be the spot for world cup games. Plenty of family style tables to sit which is consistent with my memory of the old place but now everything is clean.
     The dining area is in the back. Menu is solid german food options with some fun starter options. Its definitely not bar food so dont think you are getting like wings here. I went with the traditional pork schnitzel which was great. A good way to balance out after a couple hours of drinking beer.
     So I cant really think of reason not to give place 5 stars. I see some other people had tough tiimes. I know place is very popular after work and (i think) to places credit they do limit number of people inside so sometimes there is a line during happy hour. That's better than a sh%t show inside where you wait an hour for a drink. My eating experience was good so maybe I am just benefiting from checking this place out after they had a few months to find their groove. Anyway place is still a fun place to drink beer and meet people. They still have all those funky pictures on the wall but now the place is clean and not rundown.
author: Doctor Z.

description: Great place, the new renovations added a lot. Great selection of German beer.  The atmosphere is darker now. The communal tables are awesome. Get the beer boot!!
author: David E.

description:
Old Schroeder's is dead. Long live the new revamped Schroeders! 

The remodel is beautiful. Long communal tables, walls of steins and gorgeous lighting fixtures. Gone are the sticky tables, unspeakable bathroom and bad service. 

If you are old and decrepit or live in the past don't bother coming here. Okay so maybe I miss the free meatballs and the potato skins. And maybe my schnitzel sandwich and Black Forest dessert was a tad pricey but they were very tasty. I'm not a mustard person but had to ask about it. The waitress said the kitchen made it. No industrial stuff here. And the liver mousse in the schnitzel sandwich...nice touch. The portions aren't generous but should we really be eating that much?  It left room for dessert! Yummy dense rich chocolate for dessert with brandied cherries and Carmel corn! Inspired pairings! Again, not a big portion for the price but wonderful. 

Service was great. The hostess remembered my name when I left and then four hours later when I returned for an after work drink!!! Not standoffish as reported in other reviews. 

Bottom line, leave the past behind. On with the new!
author: Gidget M.

description:
They really should hire busboys who understand some English. I asked for a box. Instead, the busboy took my plate and never came back.

The food is okay. It would have been better if the food was better priced. The bill came out to $93 for two people, including tip and tax, for 2 drinks, 2 appetizers, and 2 entrees.
author: Joseph K.

description: Met a friend to watch the U.S. Women's Soccer Team kick arse against Australia last week and the manager wouldn't turn the game volume on for us -- something about a hockey game happening, yada. There were 12 people in the entire bar, tops, and 10 of us were trying to watch our ladies play. Kicker was, we were forced to listen to sad sap music rather than the hockey game... so we left at halftime. Beer = cool. Lack of support for women's soccer = not cool.
author: Amber S.

description: Schroeder's has a different take on German Food. I had a Wiener schnitzel with the house potato salad. They also have wide selection of good beer. I like Schroeders SF, I still prefer traditional German Food. I did enjoy eating here. The bartender was very informative about the tap beers
author: Joe H.

description: Looks like you can't get food between 2-3pm. The bartender was extremely rude about it.
author: Chris W.

description:
I went into Schroeder's after work with friends who had been to both the old and new restaurant. We had a long work week and needed a close, friendly spot. The vibe is great! Beer hall plus hip restaurant at the back. 

The staff at the door were friendly and welcoming, we tried several appetizers which were great, and the servers were knowledgeable and efficient. My friend loves micro brews, and when she quizzed the bartender on "crafty German beers" and she recommended a couple great options.

We accomplished our mission - fun after a long week of work at a hip and buzzing local spot.
author: Katherine C.

description: Company, great, beer, their out of it.  Food, meh.  Decor, nice.  Service, not there yet.  Give this place a wide berth while it works out its kinks.  They tried to make up for the many mistakes, but straight up c- experience.
author: Andrew B.

description: Not good German food, but the beer choices are decent. I eat here only when someone in our group insists. I was raised on German food and this is about 4 stars out of 10 on its best day. Unfortunately I think the best days for this place are in its past. Finding good German food is becoming very difficult. Sigh.
author: Ragenvald G.

description: We ate here Saturday night. Pretzel knots were great!  Meals were good. (Flank Steak and Saurbraten). Great beer selection. Waitress was on top of things. Overall, not great but pretty good. Expected a little more for the money we spent $170 for two (no dessert). We did have drinks/beer which added up quickly.
author: Wendy C.

description: Overpriced is the first thing that comes to mind.  $24 for a thin, flat, dry weiner schnitzel with green beans and NO spatzle (?seriously?) is kind of a rip off.  Why no spatzle?  Like, oh, nearly every single German restaurant in the country?  The spatzle, while by far the best food tried, was a $12 side dish.  So if you want spatzle with your schnitzel it is a $36 combo.  Yes, extremely overpriced, especially given the sub par, dry schnitzel.  And the beer prices - $24 for a liter of beer (two pints).  I don't care if the beer is made from the tears of monks forced to watch the Khardasians - the equivalent of $12 for a pint of beer should not exist.   I do like the makeover and the vibe of the room and our server was excellent otherwise this was a one star and a never to repeat.
author: Stan B.

description:
I work around the corner and was a frequent visitor to the "old" Schroeder's. I liked it because it was close, because it was German, and because it was charming. 

When I walked into the new Schroeder's, it was as if the place had received the perfect face lift. The murals -- the best part about the old place -- are still there. In fact, they're more noticeable, since the kitsch is gone.  It's also much lighter and much airier -- two big improvements. 

As much as I like the remodel, it's less relevant to compare old to new than to simply figure out whether I like the new. The verdict is that I love it. 

It's still close to work, it's still German, and it's still charming. But now the food is much, much better, the place is more inviting, and the beer is still damn good. 

Right up my alley.
author: Matthew P.
