description: Very disappointed that they did not let us break a piñata in a wide open private area of the bar which we had booked.  I used to go to Schroeders during the lean years.  Definitely remember 2009 when they didn't even turn on the heat in the winter time and forgot half our order when we booked a private room to watch Champions League.  Don't forget where you came from.  Deustche bags!
author: Tom R.

description: I have been to Schroeder's twice before and I felt more and more disappointed each time I came. I have no complaints about the food but rather the service and management of the establishment was utterly dismal. To give a small background on myself I am a former restaurant manager at two different restaurants and I know from my experience that it is important that each patron and guest be treated with respect and dignity. Upon arriving at the restaurant in my most recent experience we had come with a fairly large group of about 15 people to celebrate a friend's birthday. We placed our name on a wait list and was given an estimated time of 20 minutes. After waiting for 30 the hostess failed to inform us that someone else had been taken to our table and that it would be another 30 before we were sat, she then suggested that we try and grab a seat at the community bench table tops that they have available. No apology was given for the confusion or the mistake she made and we waited until space opened on the community table. After about an hour into the service our sever came seldom and would not go around the table asking everyone's order and the manager, named Theresa, approached the girlfriend of the birthday boy and suggest that we leave because the guest of honor was "too drunk" and she didn't want to "clean up after him or your party..." My friend who's birthday we were celebrating was tipsy but not being belligerent, nor obnoxious, neither spilling or making any mess. For the manager to say such a thing to a guest is rude and disrespectful, especially for paying customers. She spoke condescendingly and was not apologetic for any of the circumstances leading up to that point. Even after all was said and done she suggested we pay out an leave. I will not be returning to Schroeder's and would not recommend anyone to come to their establishment. I would suggest to Schroeder's that Theresa be trained in hospitality and taught how to properly manage a restaurant. More importantly that she learn to simply be respectful. Schroeder's is definitely not worth the high priced menu and poor customer service.
author: Isaac M.

description:
I loved what the new Schroeder's has done with the space.  It is sleek, modern and elegant, and much improved from the interior before.  The service was fantastic.  Friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive from front of the house to wait staff.  That's great, especially since the old Schroeder's sometimes you had to work to find someone to help.

The food was good, but I feel that the restaurant is having an identity crisis.  The potato pancakes were not at all what I expected, but was delicious nonetheless.  We also thought the wienerschnitzel was excellent (crispy and thin, flavorful).  The schnitzel was also good, but I felt it was trying to be too much - German and farm-to-table and Californian all in one dish.  The bratwurst was fine, but not my favorite.  I feel like the chef has immense talent but is being constrained by trying to keep a connection with the Bavarian dishes of yore, and also trying to be California-foodie.  I did miss the sausage platter that used to be available.  Perhaps it would be better to have some old "classics" on the menu, and then just offer totally new dishes that have no relation to the older ones.  At any rate, I think there is a lot of potential here and I am looking forward to seeing how the place evolves.
author: Michelle C.

description: I decided to try Schroeder's tonight.  I can tell you that the food and service were amazing, but I couldn't even begin to hear the person opposite the table from me as the bar area was so loud.  If an establishment is far more concerned for the bar crowd over that of the dinner crowd, then they need to let the dinners know that ahead of time.  My remedy for them would be to simply build a 3/4 wall between the two verses that of the chain screen, which does no good whatsoever.
author: Tess C.

description: Oh how times have changed. Schroeder's used to have a super menu and atmosphere. Now you have to look harder to see the beauty. It has gone from a great place to a college atmosphere beer hall with the appropriate food quality as one would expect that a college crowd would appreciate. Wish I didn't make the trek
author: Walter C.

description:
New look, new food, new management and the space looks better than ever. 

The food is fantastic. I am a big fan of German food and I appreciate that they have a true German chef who is taking a lot of pride in the food he's putting out. The spaetzle, beef tongue, potato pancake and the sausages were all delicious. Also, as weird as this may sound, the simple house salad was lights out. 

And for those German beer fans, this place will not disappoint. Plus, a full bar with a unique and tasty cocktail offering. Had a cocktail with kolsch & bourbon that I will surely be going back for.
author: Teresa B.

description: Interesting menu but food was luke warm.  The Bratwurst was cold in the center and the potatoes warm on the surface as from a bad microwave.  I returned my plate and asked for it to be redone.  10 minutes later, I got a hot to-touch plate and cold food once again.  I returned my dish and decided to eat elsewhere. Waitstaff on the other hand was friendly but the kitchen FAILED with food.  Won't be returning and don't recommend to anyone looking to eat well.
author: Darius A.

description:
I will start off saying that I'm not the kind of person to write a bad review and I have been mulling over writing this for a week now. Had I never been to the original Schroeder's or never had real German food I probably would not be writing this one. I would have simply came, eaten and then left to never came back as the food was not good enough to warrant the price and it was not German food. 

Long story short, if you are looking for the old Schroeder's or good German food in general, don't come here as this is no longer that kind of place. If you want my long winded version why, then keep reading........

I was so excited to go to Schroeder's after they reopened. I was craving some good German beer and a nice plate of Hungarian Goulash with German potatoes and sauerkraut. 

The place looked great. They kept the paintings which was great. I loved the bench seating as that is just so eastern European. I could not wait to eat!

Imagine my surprise when the waitress handed me the menu with it's 8 entrees. Where is the Goulash?  Where is the sausage platter? What the hell is this? My friend and I had been raving about Schroeder's and we brought along 3 other friends that had never been (2 where new to the US from France as interns). I immediately began apologizing as it was very apparent this was not German food. Nothing on the menu looked German other than the Bratwurst. 

I have an open mind and was willing to give it a shot because you never know as it could be an amazing experience. 3 of my friends ordered the Bratwurst, one the Salmon Flatbread and I ordered the Chicken Schnitzel Sandwich and we got the Spätzle. With such a meager menu you would expect the food to arrive in quick order. An hour later it showed up. One of our guests had to leave as she could not wait as she had a meeting. So we got her food to go for her.

The Spätzle arrived first.. For me the best part of my entire meal was the noodle in the Spätzle. I will admit that little noodle was amazing but more on that later. The Schnitzel I had was just a sandwich. My friend Anca wrote a review the same day and you can read her opinion further down about the Schnitzel. You get nothing else with it unless you want fries for an additional $4. The Bratwurst came with no sauerkraut how can you possibly do that its a German restaurant for gods sake? However, it does come with a roll with a slit down the middle. I.E. A fancy hot dog bun. Really? The topper was my friends Salmon Flatbread. When it arrived I asked if that was the Salmon to which he replied yes. I then asked him where was the Salmon and he picked up some crumbles on the salad. Basically it was a salad with a few Salmon crumbles sitting on a piece of flatbread. $16.

My sandwich was OK. It had this mustard on it that was overpowering the rest of the dish. However, it was a decent sandwich but nothing to write home about and definitely not my Goulash (which WAS something to write home about). Overall the food was OK but we all said we would never be back. The food was just not good enough to warrant such a high cost for lunch.

My friend Anca got a nice reply from Schroeder's about her comment on the Schnitzel. They said they had a great Veal Schnitzel and were going to add it to the lunch menu based on her comments. So good going, please add a great Goulash as well. They also made a comment that their Chief, Chief Wrembel, is from CA born to German immigrants and uses his mothers recipes and spices them up with the techniques he learned in CA. They used the Spätzle recipe as an example of this. They said the noodle in the Spätzle was from his mothers recipe and the rest was his added spin on the dish. If you remember I mentioned for me the best thing of the lunch was the noodle in the Spätzle. I would recommend that he stop playing with his mothers recipes. If the noodle is any indication of how good she cooks then I would like to see more of her recipes without her sons twists.

I wish Schroeder's all the best. It is very sad to see the place change in such a way as it was a great place to come too for some authentic German food. Alas no more. I wonder, do you still have the Das Boot or did that go the way of the Goulash?
author: Paul G.

description:
I really miss the old Schroeder's.  The new "atmosphere" is like walking into a cafeteria.  No table clothes, loud, noisy, tables up against other tables.  No privacy and the noise level is so high, bouncing off the bare walls, that you can hardly have a conversation with the person across the table.  The menu has changed too for the worse.  The veal was paper thin and dry, no taste except for the breading.  The potato pancakes no longer come with apple sauce or sour cream, but with some salad that adds nothing to the pancakes.  I won't be returning.  Pity!

Finally, there was a big guy in suit and tie walking about.  He may have been the manager or owner, but what a sour face he had on!  Looked like a roaming ogre!   Nothing like a happy employee and one of the worst things to do in a restaurant if he was the manager or owner....no sense of hospitality.  He spoke with no one, just roamed around with that sour face on.  UGH.
author: Red H.

description: Great place for a beer after work with friends. The bartending and management staff are super knowledgable about beer and whiskey, I appreciate how helpful they are when choosing what to drink!
author: Michael G.

description: Post-remodel (and ownership change?), the food is better. Went for a big team lunch with coworkers, and it was great. The old-school German ambience is still there, only more polished and contemporary Berlin. They have so many great beer and liquor options to choose from. The food was really good - better than Wexler's. And the space much less noisy than Wexler's. Spatzle: delicious. Chicken Schizntizel sandwich: delicious. Our waitress was totally on point - after our meal we ordered Fernet Branca digestifs all around, and our waitress brought us a free sample of a superior German equivalent (Kilpesh??). Anyway, a fun restaurant and great food and plenty of great beers.
author: David W.

description: The food is expensive and not particulary tasty. The beer selection is OK but expensive too. I beleive they just re-opened and they need to get ROI on a lot of invest...The only good part is : the place looks really nice !
author: Mathieu F.

description: Wow this place has changed! I'm bringing people here for lunch from now on! Great food! Get the soup and a black ale. Yum! Not just for boot 'o beer anymore!
author: Mary H.

description: We came here with a group of friends for a HH but we ended up having dinner here. Its a great place at a good location. The atmosphere is good and the beer is awesome. Not quite sure about the german food. I have tried many german food in a lot of restaurants. This is just average.
author: Tracy D.

description: Mostly I was unhappy with the customer service. Food was ok, good sauerkraut, but really you come here for beer. So beer, they didn't have the beer I ordered, the waiter suggested another one that I hadn't tried. It wasn't good. I tried to change it out, but the manager didn't seem to care, and told me I was stuck with the one I ordered since it was a boot.  Then my friend ordered a boot, they ran out of the keg, have him half a boot and said, that's close to a liter so we'll charge you for a liter instead of 2, that's still $22 for a guess. Personally, I think that's bullshit. Normally when bars run out of a keg they give the half pour to you for free then ask you what you'd like for your actual order. Those 2 things soured my taste of this bar. Probably won't go back. Go to Leopoldo's on Polk instead.
author: Alan M.

description:
interesting beer and excellent food
modern pub environment
great after work meeting ground
author: Steven M.

description: A little noisy but once you got the back, you can feel the quiet side of the restaurant, great selection of beer when you are in the mood post work. I ordered the wiener snitzel and it was great, besides that pistachio kuchen closes the night of my dinner.
author: Bryan T.

description: Schroeders has good beer and good food. I like it. If you like German food and bier, kommt hier
author: Dave G.

description: I had another lunch there and the Schnitzel was a big improvement. Perfectly cooked and seasoned.  I also had a tasty lager that made for a nice meal.  It's still pretty hipstery, but my opinion of the food is definitely higher.  I shall return.
author: Kenneth N.

description: Updating this review after a few more visits and some great fun with the World Cup.  Service has found its footing as is expected with new places, and the beer list is amazing.  I've tried 5 -6 different brews and all tasty.  Food highlights so far have been: potato pancakes, vesperplatte, beef tongue and the bratwurst.  Fine dining food without the attitude.
author: Paul L.

description:
I've always been a big fan of Schroeder's for years since learning that Henry Schroeder was my great grand-uncle.  While it has been out of the family for almost 100 years, it was always great to be able to visit for lunch and see the decorations and taste the food that has been largely untouched since the early 1900s.  Coincidently this restaurant has been the favorite lunch spot of my graduate school mentor for 30 years which always tickled both of us.

Given the background, I had a lot of trepidation about what the new owners were going to do with the place when it closed for renovation.  Having visited a few weeks ago, I believe they've done a fabulous job positioning the restaurant for the next 100 years.  While I agree with some reviews about the food portions and cost, the food menu is something that always takes a while to perfect and nail down.  I'm confident the schnitzel plate and goulash will make a triumphant comeback at some point.  In the meantime, it is the coolest German beerhall in the city to sit and throw down beers at.  The renovation has the right balance of updating the decor and adding some much-needed swank while still hanging onto the "Schroeder's" feel.

Great job to the management!
author: Kristian H.

description: So many places in the Financial District are hugely expensive and unapproachable for the regular person. Schroeder's is both nice with good food and reasonably priced. Therefore it's a place that earns my accolades for that and for the quality of the service too. The bar is loud and energetic as would be expected at a German Beer pub, but the back area where tables are reserved is calmer and more appropriate to dinner. You can meet at the front, be loud with your beers and all the others doing the same, but then be welcomed to the dining area and actually have a conversation and enjoy your dinner. The sausage plate and some cheese is a great sharing item and more than enough for 2. Lots of great beers as would be expected, so it's a nicer beer garden that is indoors! Definitely fun and delicious.
author: Dr F.

description: Hubs loves this place (if it's kitschy, he's happy). I didn't like it prior to the new owners and the remodel, but was willing to give it another shot. First problem::Holy crap is it L O U D. Seriously, we are sitting across the table and yelling and I'm no soft-spoken chica. Second problem: the food--we had smoked chicken and Wiener Schnitzel. Chicken was ok, not remarkable but I can live with that. Wiener Schnitzel was just awful--dry, thin, thin, thin and tasteless. Sides did have some redemption value, though. I hoped that the Apfel Struedl would somehow redeem Schroeder's rep, but alas... Utterly tasteless, uninteresting and bland. Service was slow and trying--good luck getting attention in this crazed atmosphere. Done with you, Schroeder's...way, way too many good options in the neighborhood...decent beer selection however--we shudda drunk our meals...
author: Jane V.

description: Schroeders is a solid choice for dinner and drinks or for a larger party. Service tends to be good though I've heard other people have had mixed experiences. Food is well thought out and I like the newer menu quite well. The beer choices are good though not the best in the area.
author: Jim S.

description:
At the risk of offending fans of the "old" Schroeder's, I have vague memories of doing the chicken dance in a really gross bar downtown named Schroeder's, so I was not excited when I was told this was where my husband and I were going for drinks. I was VERY pleasantly surprised to see the new look (and how clean it was!).

I'm not a German food fan. I had no idea what I was eating. But it was good!!

I'm also not a beer connesieur. I had no idea what I was ordering. But it was great!!

I got the sense that the staff was really invested in the bar - they were going above and beyond to make us feel comfortable.  Welcomed us from beginning to end.

Undoubtedly, this will be a new after work hangout.
author: Wendy Z.

description: LOVE the new Schroeders.  Have eaten here three times since it re opened and its a huge upgrade from the old bar.  They kept all the great character of the original while upgrading the food and space.  I especially love the stein collections. The bartenders and staff are all great.  Make reservations for dinner to avoid the line and crowd at the front!
author: Sarah B.

description: Came here to get some German food and beer, duh!  The restaurant is mainly communal tables, which I'm not too much of a fan of, but it works for them.  Did not have a reservation for lunch but they were able to seat us right away.  The service was great, sausage was great, beer was great but a little pricey - das boot can cost around $50!
author: Karl D.

description:
They have done a terrific thing with one of my favorite institutions downtown.  The food used to suck, but it was otherwise a great place to drink beer and hang out.  They kept the coolness - old murals and feel of a great beer hall - but tightened up.  Augmented the beer selection and made the food far more than edible, than the old nasty fare.  I love it.  Perfect week day lunch spot and with the World Cup, it is awesome!

Nice work!
author: Judson H.

description: Enjoyed a nice dinner here, pastrami of duck. Good German beers, and didn't have to wait to be seated even during a very busy time. Beet salad also excellent.
author: Dave M.

description: The ambiance is really great. I didn't enjoy the Veal Schnitzel but the Saurbraten is the way to go and the pretzel knots were amazing!
author: Michelle K.

description: Last night my wife and I shared a dinner and found that the service from all employees was outstanding.  From the front desk to the waitress to the busboy ---  they were all soo friendly and not "over the top".
author: Tom S.

description: Admittedly this review is being written in the context of seeing the place after the recent reboot. Our old and stodgy place is no more. I understand the need for change, but it was a lot to take in. A few visuals are the same, like the large murals but most of the rest is different. The entry way is more inviting, throwing out the old gents club layout of yore. The menu is now made up of small fancy portions rather than big, old-school ones. The food seems a bit diluted from its roots. The bar man did recommended a great beer. Staff was friendly and accommodating. Schroeder's now probably fits in much better into the neighborhood than before and will bring in more folks. But the time warp charm is at best different, and possibly gone. With time I may appreciate the space more.
author: Roger B.

description: The new Schroeder's is great! A unique twist on German cuisine. Delicious food and a nice selection of German wines. I recommend the potato pancakes and the sauerbraten.
author: Janna T.

description: If I could I would rate this a flat zero I would. I went there on May 1st for a company banquet. It's taken me until now to say this but this place is occupied by complete racist servers. I over heard a server make a racist comment when I accidentally placed two orders for a soda. I heard him state and I quote "Indians are stupid. Indians smell bad." I'm extremely upset about this and if I was the manager I would like to know that this happening. But honestly the manager must be completely ignoring his or her job for allowing this to happen. This is absolutely unacceptable especially in the city. Honestly blows my mind racist work in this city. Food was great but my god service was terrible.
author: Ghandi R.

description:
Love love LOVE the new design. BCV really did a stellar job. This is a great happy hour spot to roll to after a long week. The crowd/atmosphere is great and you can count on great beers & food. 

Quite the step up-very impressed!!! :)
author: Molly C.

description: Great beer, very limited menu. Bill for $51 including tip and tax for a burger and 2 half litre beers.  Not for the feint of heart price wise.
author: Stephen L.

description:
I love the new Schroeders!  My friend's and I used to go to the old Schroeder's after work to have a few beers and sometimes down a few boots. While it was definitely fun, I have to say the new set up is 100x better with a cool new interior.  The spaetzle is awesome and so is this beer cocktail they have on their menu. 

The happy hour scene is great and it is fun to meet new people at their beer tables. Definitely watching some World Cup there starting Thursday morning!!
author: K B.

description: Has a lot of potential. Very nice german place and good beer. Unfortunately staff isn't that nice. Especially the manager was very rude!
author: Adrian F.

description: Great job on remodel but Please,DON"T call this German food!!! Bratwurst in a bun with sauerkraut on top = American artisan hot dog + tater tots? What? = NOT German. This is how Mexican's must feel about the Burrito. Cheesespaetzle + corn + ricotta = what? Is someone trying to invent the word German-Fusion? This might not work for every cuisine. And why would you mess with a perfect original recipe? Schnitzel with no spaetzle or fries but on a bed of onions and green beans? Please show me where in Germany you have encountered such thing and = $25? Couldn't recognize anything on the menu authentic to my beloved home country cooking. I don't think the pictures here apply anymore at all to the new menu. Sad lunch for me and my work team. Don't get me wrong I can dig a artisan hot dog, especially with the quality of sausages around town, so I ordered the Bratwurst, sat and worked on getting over my disappointment - but - alas even more sad the Bratwurst came and was mediocre, sadly bland sitting between the bun with a couple strings of sad bland what they call Sauerkraut. Rosamunde does this better a thousand times over!!!!
author: Judith B.

description: My husband and I had not been to Schroeder's in over 15 years and were pleasantly surprised at the upgrades.  The atmosphere was fun as always.  We have both traveled extensively throughout Germany and must say that the house made bratwurst is the best we have ever had.  Of course, you can't go wrong with the other items on the menu.  Highlights include the wiener schnitzel and the sauerbraten.
author: M M.

description: If you're looking for an authentic German experience DO NOT go here. This is the worst German food we have ever tasted. Not a single item we had in our very large group was good. These guys can't even make a decent sausage! Beyond that, it's completely over priced. Service was very average.
author: Helmut E.

description: The new remodel is awesome! Service is great and they were super accommodating to our large work group of 20ppl!
author: Aaron H.

description: The newly revamped Schroeder's now requires a bouncer and a wait to get in???? Get over yourselves.
author: C G.

description: The new owners have done a brilliant job revamping this awesome West Coast institution. From salvaging the original murals & highlighting then with gorgeous lighting to encasing the terrific collection of global steins, they have really don't this place justice. The food is reason enough to visit! Admittedly, I've never had a warm carrot salad & I couldn't have imagined it tasting as good as it did! So fun!
author: Lori S.

description: The new Schroeder's is AMAZING!  Beautiful interiors, GREAT beer selection, and delicious custom cocktails (try the Derby Radler!).  My advice is go for drinks and stay for dinner.  The food is really incredible and will have you dreaming about it for weeks...Spatzle, Pork Rinds, Potato Pancakes, Smothered Fries.  All unique and totally craveable!!
author: Aileen R.

description: Awesome environment great for happy hour.  Really great since the renovation.  Their beer selection is amazing.  Try the sausage you won't regret it.
author: Sam R.

description: The atmosphere is like Press Club except for beer. If that's your thing then you will love it. Personally, I would head to the exceptional Leopold's.
author: Jamie b.

description: We went to celebrate Oktoberfest, had 3 reservations w/ total 18 people. We had talked on the phone beforehand to see if it's possible to put the tables together. We had been there last year and had a great time. But we knew the place had a change of owner and we wanted to check with them.  They agreed. We came there and waited half an hour for our tables. Then we were seated insulated on 3 different tables, although when we came in, there were two 6 person tables free next to each other. When we complained, the host was rude and moody and basically told us to take it or leave. She did not greet us friendly and she did not care at all about our reservation or our complaints. I have rarely seen such a mismatch in personality and job description. The food was average-bad and while the server was the only friendly face we saw in Schroeder's, also the service was slow. As great as our xp was last year, as much did it suck this year. We're going to take our Oktoberfest elsewhere.
author: Daib S.

description: This was just what the financial district needed. A great place for HH with coworkers or dinner with friends after work. I've been there a few times and loved my meals. Try the derby radler cocktail. It's delicious!
author: Erin C.

description: Love the place!  Also, made to feel very welcome by the hostess when we first came in.   Will definitely be back.  Judy S
author: Judy S.

description: Not quite sure about the food. Being a native German born and raised in Bavaria, I think I have a good sense about German food. However, the quality and taste of the German food offered at this restaurant were far below my expectations, which are already lowered by the fact that we are ultimately not in Germany. The Jaegerschnitzel (why is it breaded?) was pretty tasteless and the spaetzle again tasteless and greasy. (Why are they fried in a pan?). By looking at the Currywurst, I had serious doubts that the owner has ever seen a real German currywurst. I cannot comment on the taste of it, since it was not a currywurst any comparison is baseless (apples to oranges comparison). On a positive note, the place is big and spacious. I am sure it is a good place to drink beer. I will continue my quest for authentic German food.
author: Manitu M.

description: The new Schroeder's has horrendous customer service. With the remodeled look they have developed a new attitude for being pretentious and not valuing customer experience, from calling for a reservation to presenting a check. I hope this is a result of poor new management and not someone's deep fall from grace.
author: Samantha K.

description: Had lunch here the other day.  Would have been a 4 star review on the food but there was an incident when the chef in the kitchen lost his marbles on the rest of the kitchen staff, expletives flying every-which-way.  Sorry, I'm not going to lunch at a place with a tyrant in the kitchen belittling his staff.  I turned around to get a look at the guy, and exactly what you'd expect.  Little dude with a chip on his shoulder.  Don't care how good he may be in the kitchen, this guy needs another job.
author: Nate W.

description: The renovation of this stodgy old place is really well done.  It's nice.  The beer is good too (despite pawning off that fake Austrian Trumer - from Berkeley - as a "German pils"). The food I had was HORRIBLE.  I mean, inedible. Stick to the beer and if you are really craving garbage head for the McDonalds across the street - at least it's cheap garbage.
author: Douglas E.

description: Hadn't been back out here since the remodel, it's definitely a major change and looks more upscale. Came in for lunch and it was pretty slow. Service was great, no complaints there. The food, however, was lacking. The bratwurst plate was tasty, but definitely undercooked. I should've sent it back but we were under time constraints. I miss the old Schroeder's honestly. Hard to slam liter beers in such a nice setting. Not sure if I'll be back again, maybe during Oktoberfest if I'm in the area.
author: Mark H.

description: Really cool first experience at Schroeder's! The menu is interesting and has something for everyone, the bar menu-- cocktails, beer and wine different and delightful. The waiters know their stuff and could not be nicer. The (new) decor is cool, and still respects the heritage of the brand. Really well done and a great new addition to the SF Bar/Restaurant scene. PS- my maiden name is Engelke-- 50% german!
author: Cynthia P.

description: Went there recently and take a looksie since they recently changed ownership and updated the place which has been around 100 years or something.  It was happy hour about 6 and the bar area was PACKED like sardines.  Everyone was drinking beer of all sizes and brands and we barely found 3 seats tucked in the middle of one of the communal tables.  We wanted to order some food when the server asked us if we'd be more comfortable in the dining room.  We went there and felt relieved to be away from the throng of after-work crowd.  We were optimistic about the food and one of my friends is German.  What we got was almost inedible food.  The pickled vegetables were so sour it could jot be eaten.  The pretzel was soft and break-like.  Actually tasted more of Hawaiian bread than pretzel.  The duck sliders were a mush of meat and wet bun.  The potato cakes were greasy.  The bratwurst was grimy with small bits of chewy meat with terrible sauerkraut in the sauce so astringent the white hotdog bun in it could not help absorb it.  The wiener schnitzel was the driest piece of veal I could not believe it was served.  Close your eyes and try to identity the cut and you could say breaded 'cardboard'!    We ordered wine but maybe next time I'll fight the crowd and drink a beer instead!  Server was very nice so **.... But Yikes!
author: Gregory C.

description: We came here for my boss's going away party and the staff was so accommodating with our large group. They were able to reserve one of the large communal tables for us. Our waitress was on top of all our scattered drink orders and when it came down to the check with people leaving before others, she had no problem taking items off and making separate checks. Everyone loved the pork rinds and smothered fries! Our waitress was also very knowledgeable when it came to the beer selection and able to make suggestions based on what some of us preferred as not every one was familiar with the beers served. Overall, great experience and definitely will be coming back!!
author: Tracey M.

description: The new Schroeders is amazing!  I love the decor - a mix of modern and traditional (especially the display case of all the bier steins!).  For drinks, I expected the long list of German beers, but was pleasantly surprised that they serve craft cocktails too.  Then there's the food.  What can I say?!  The spaetzel (spelling?) was to die for!  I could eat that as my meal!  The schnitzel was also incredible.  My friend had the burger and loved it.  I want to go back and try more stuff!  I have a feeling I'll be a regular here...
author: Jen H.

description: Thank you! The financial district desperately needed this place. Upscale, clean, with a dash of sophistication, while still maintaining it's approachable "let's have a beer after work vibe." Love the Herman Richter murals, glad someone finally highlighted these works. Highly recommend.
author: Peter U.

description: Had a casual business lunch here.  Shared the curry bratwurst sausage and my colleague had the chicken salad and I had SUPER spatzle.  They had corn in it and it was creamy.  Not diet food, but super yummy.  It was listed as an appetizer but could be a good side dish to share.  I would definitely have this again.  The sausage was bland.  I ordered it on the recommendation of the server.  It was just OK.  Service was good, fast, efficient.  Good water refills, quick with the bill.  The table was very long, picnic style benchs, and could accommodate a big group - but they put a grass/garden arrangement on the table which separated us from the other people at the table and gave us privacy.  The renovated venue is nice, open, good light, and clean.  Definitely looks like a German beer house/garden.  They take reservations on Open Table.  I would return here for lunch if I were in the area.
author: Sandra M.

description: I visited the "new" Schroeder's for bites and drinks at the bar recently and I was blown away by how it's been transformed into a friendly, beautiful, just-sophisticated-enough gastropub.  The wood-heavy decor is somehow warm and sleek at the same time.  On the night I was there (a Wednesday), it was definitely crowded but the bar is spacious and airy enough that it didn't feel claustrophobic, and the noise level was a happy buzz where you can still carry on a conversation.  The staff working the bar were incredibly friendly and pour some great beers and inventive cocktails (including cocktails that feature beer as an ingredient, which was a new and happy experience for me).  The food we tried included the pork cracklings ("real" cracklings, delicious and decadent) and the charcuterie plate that featured homemade pickles, yummy cheeses and one of the best and silkiest chicken liver mousse I've had in a while. . Unlike some others who seem to be posting reviews here, I have no nostalgia for Schroeder's in its former incarnation (my memories of the former establishment are unfortunate smells and perhaps the nastiest bathrooms in the FiDi).  But new Schroeder's I will be returning to again -- can't wait to get back there to try their full menu.
author: Leah S.

description: What's not to love about beer and German food? Basically nothing it turns out. Having eaten at other German places in SF (and Germany for that matter), the food here is kind of unique in the sense that it is a little bit lighter and more non-traditional than your typical German fare. Another reviewer said something about "German-fusion" and I had a similar feeling, although I liked it personally. It reminded me of German food meets California. Purists might not like it, but I thought it was tasty and well done. The selection of beers was great and I left stuffed full of breaded pork. No complaints!
author: Ryan B.

description: The potato pancakes are amazing as well as their Bratwurst..Their beer and wine selection are great!!!Having just re-opened they are doing a great job...I'm sure there are still a few kinks to work out and they will find their groove..I would definitely recommend...Go check them out!!!
author: Claudia T.

description: This place is AWESOME! The ambiance is amazing, the food is delicious and the drinks are to die for. Highly recommend.
author: Kendyl R.

description: strange combo of beer pub and expensive menu items.  great food however!
author: Tami Z.

description: Awesome food and even better beer. Very clean. Very friendly. Great atmosphere. Did I mention great beer? The newly renovated location is clean feeling, though I do prefer the place before the remodel just for the feeling of being somewhere old and with some history. The place feels a little more modern, but they went through great lengths to keep the sense of antiquity. Be warned that you will not find California cuisine here. It's pretty German. Courtney was great and attentive.
author: Wilfred B.

description: I love the newly remodeled space, the food/new menu is delicious. I can't wait to go back and try everything else. I has the baby artichokes and chickpeas and my husband had the schnitzel. Both were excellent. Looking forward to my next visit.
author: Alison D.

description: I was in this past Friday with friends in town and had a fabulous experience ! I have never had German food and was very excited to try it.  We started with the pretzel knots ( yummy) , the Hefeknopfle ( every ones favorite) and the local Trout ( my favorite). Do try the Rodenbach Grand Cru, such a good sour beer.   The staff was super friendly , all and all a great experience
author: Isabel G.

description: If you like beer and want to drink some in a giant glass boot, this is the place to go!
author: Victor T.

description: I miss the old Schroeders but the new one is good too. Plentiful German beer, good times after work, a little fancier than it used to be but what's wrong with that. Solid German dinner.
author: William M.

description: Excellent californian-German fusion food. Excellent service. The remodelation is gorgeous. It's classy and reasonably priced. I would take a client there. I just took some people from Alsace -France there who loved it too.
author: Gabrielle D.

description: two steps above royal exchange and one step above harringtons, both across the street. often too crowded given its location in the financial district, but the updated look is pleasant & roomy and the menu has been improved. i appreciate the 1/3rd pint option.
author: Sonya Z.

description: The decor so very nice after the recent remodel, and the food was good we quality if a bit pricey for a beer hall.  Is is a nice place to hang out for after work drinks.  Service was efficient and welcoming.
author: Todd P.

description:
So much fun! We were quickly greeted at the entrance and quietly directed through the happy vibes of the beer garden to our table with a view of the historical interior that has been modernized with a light touch.  I loved the see through mesh like curtains that divided the dining area from the beer garden  and private parties to the rear of the room.
Without missing a step we were offered a selection of beers. A few sips of my light wheat beer and the crispy potato pancakes appeared with freshly grilled cherry tomatoes and perfectly cooked bacon slice on them. My European born friend enjoyed the pork rinds with a  horseradish dip . I am too much of a west coast native for pork rind.
The side dish  of spatzle was interesting  with corn, tomato and poppy seeds. I loved the al dente green beans with a shallot puree that garnished the weiner schnitzel. The weiner schnitzel was very thinly sliced with an excellent crisp coating. The sauerbraten fell apart with my fork and the potato dumpling was a combination of substantial and delicate, just perfect for the meat's sauce. Of course the innovation was there with grapes instead of prunes in the sauerbraten sauce.
No dessert, too full!
author: Aileen M.

description: The energy was so positive and fun right from the beginning.  The food was cooked to exact specification.  The head chef, manager, and general manager were fantastic and the wait staff was off the chain.  It is easy to say this is a great place to bring those you wish to impress. Guaranteed great night out.  Thanks again Schroeders!!!  Nathan and April Anderson
author: April A.

description: I don't know. I just don't know if there's a niche for whatever this place has become. Both the menu and the service may turn out to be problematic. 1) The menu: Noveau-German? German inspired? The menu, in my opinion, does not have enough of the pure classics that people want from a German place to keep it exciting. Our server told us it was lighter, German-inspired San Francisco fare.  The appetizers were better and more interesting than the main dishes. I thought it was weird that most things on the sampler platter came in threes. Why not fours? I rarely have a group of three at dinner. The schnitzel was fine. The chicken roulade was forgettable and also an example of what's new and not necessarily German here: it includes quinoa and peaches. The artichoke dish was tasteless. The pistachio cake was so small that I took a picture of it next to a quarter to make my point. 2) Service. As others have reported, indeed, it took about 20 minutes to receive our beers and it wasn't busy. Remarkable. Also, we expressed our desire to try a lot of appetizers and just see before we ordered main dishes. Our waitress told us to please decide on main dishes soon so she could "tell the kitchen." What? Why? She came back with the same request a few minutes later. (This was around 8 PM on a very not-busy night, btw.) So I said, really, we just want to eat the appetizers first and we will be fine if it takes a while for the entrees to come after that if we order any later. And she shot me a look so rude that leaving that moment wouldn't have been out of the question. She had a different waitress handle us for the rest of the night--fine by us. Definitely not worth the trip to the Fi-Di--better German options in town if we want German and better San Francisco fare options if we want that.
author: Megan M.

description: i was blown away on my first visit to schroeder's. the space is huge without feeling like a warehouse, and will be a great place for big groups/events. i arrived a little earlier than the rest of my group to spend some time in the bar sampling beers before dinner, and i was impressed with the assortment and suggestions the bartender made. once seated, we switched to cocktails...they make a mean old fashioned. our server was great and walked us through the menu pointing out her favorites while fielding any question we threw her way. i ended up going with the pork loin, which was perfectly seasoned and cooked. we had to try the kraut, too, and in my opinion it made the meal. overall, the atmosphere, service, and eats/drinks were great. i'll be making my way back here soon and often!
author: Ben H.
